headline: North Carolina to Investigate After Concerns Raised at Children’s Hospital
abstract: The state health secretary announced an inquiry after a report in The New York Times revealed doctors’ fears that children seemed to fare poorly after heart surgery.
lead_paragraph: North Carolina’s secretary of health on Friday called for an investigation into a hospital where doctors had suspected children with complex heart conditions had been dying at higher than expected rates after undergoing heart surgery.

headline: A New Threat From Trump and Old Questions About Its Effectiveness
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Asylum, Right of', 'United States Politics and Government', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Customs (Tariff)']
abstract: Time and again, the president has engaged in a game of geopolitical chicken with Mexico. But there was no more guarantee that the tactic will be any more effective this time than in the past.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The last time President Trump vowed all-out retaliation against Mexico for the illegal immigrants crossing the border, he backed off. In April, he gave America’s southern neighbor a year to fix the problem.

headline: There Are 472,000 Words in the Dictionary. For the Spelling Bee, That May Not Be Enough.
abstract: The winners of the 2019 Scripps National Spelling Bee had more in common than an aptitude for spelling: six of the eight used the same coaching program.
lead_paragraph: Seemingly unfazed by the stage lights and television cameras, one gifted adolescent after the next approached the microphone on Thursday night and without a hint of timidity correctly spelled daunting words like “erysipelas” and “aiguillette.”

headline: What to Watch Today at the French Open
abstract: Day 7 at Roland Garros will feature Serena Williams, Novak Djokovic, warmer weather and the end of the third round.
lead_paragraph: Williams received a comfortable welcome to the tournament, facing players ranked 83rd and 238th in her first two matches. She has a far sterner test in the third round against Kenin, a 20-year-old American who has steadily climbed the rankings to her current spot, No. 35. As a child, Kenin trained with Rick Macci, the same coach with whom Williams spent many of her teenage years. She will know Williams’s game well. This match will close Saturday’s play on the main Philippe Chatrier Court, probably so it can be in NBC’s broadcast window for the American audience.

headline: Let’s Hear It for the Average Child
abstract: In this season of prizes and trophies, we salute all the students whose talents lie outside the arena.
lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — Parents, we ask you to hold your applause until the names of all the medal winners have been announced. When the ceremony is over and your child has not left her seat, though nearly every other kid is taking home ribbons and trophies and enough scholarship offers to make a real dent in the national debt, please take a few moments to congratulate the winners as they head off to their well-earned celebrations. Then we ask that you return to your seats. We have a few special achievements left to acknowledge.

headline: Army Corps Under Fire: In a Flood, It Released More Water
abstract: The Army Corps of Engineers has been struggling on two fronts — taming America’s rain-swollen rivers, and taming the fallout from mass water releases and breached levees.
lead_paragraph: SAND SPRINGS, Okla. — People whose homes had flooded filled the pews of a Baptist church that was still standing on dry ground. They bowed their heads as Oklahoma’s junior senator, James Lankford, led everyone in a prayer.

headline: Justice Dept. Keeps Wiretaps Secret in Flynn Case, Rejecting Judge’s Order
keywords: ['Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods', 'Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Special Prosecutors (Independent Counsel)']
abstract: The release of transcripts of calls between President Trump’s former adviser and Russia’s ambassador would have provided a highly unusual confirmation of a government secret.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Federal prosecutors rebuffed a judge’s order to release by Friday highly classified transcripts of discussions that Michael T. Flynn, the president’s former national security adviser, had with the Russian ambassador during the presidential transition.

headline: The High Church of the Low Blow
abstract: Sohrab Ahmari embraces Trump’s sucker punch politics.
lead_paragraph: Until recently, Sohrab Ahmari was a mainstream conservative — urbane, intelligent and unfailingly good-humored — who wrote energetic defenses of classical liberalism against its enemies on both the progressive left and populist right, including Donald Trump. For several years he was also my colleague, and in some ways my protégé, at the editorial page of The Wall Street Journal.

headline: Trump to Give Arthur Laffer, Tax-Cut Champion, the Presidential Medal of Freedom
keywords: ['Taxation', 'United States Economy', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Medal of Freedom', 'Economics (Theory and Philosophy)', 'Awards, Decorations and Honors']
abstract: The nation’s highest civilian award will go in June to an economist who has shaped decades of Republican tax policy.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump will award the Presidential Medal of Freedom, the nation’s highest civilian honor, to the economist Arthur Laffer, whose tax-cutting enthusiasm has shaped decades of Republican policymaking, including Mr. Trump’s.

headline: Justice Dept. Explores Google Antitrust Case
abstract: A case would renew scrutiny of the company amid a growing chorus of criticism about the power of big tech.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department is exploring whether to open a case against Google for potential antitrust violations, putting renewed scrutiny on the company amid a growing chorus of criticism about the power of Big Tech, three people with knowledge of the deliberations said Friday.

headline: N.S.A. Denies Its Cyberweapon Was Used in Baltimore Attack, Congressman Says
keywords: ['Cyberwarfare and Defense', 'Cyberattacks and Hackers', 'Computer Security', 'Classified Information and State Secrets', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services']
abstract: A stolen N.S.A. hacking tool was a component in a cyberattack on the city, people involved in the investigation have told The Times.
lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — A Maryland congressman said on Friday that the National Security Agency had denied that one of its hacking tools, stolen in 2017, was used in a ransomware attack on Baltimore’s government that had disrupted city services for more than three weeks.

headline: Corrections: June 1, 2019
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Saturday, June 1, 2019.
lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Takes Heat From
abstract: Ari Richter. Tough. Terse. Debut.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — This puzzle, Ari Richter’s debut, made me think of the kind of weight lifting where you’re supposed to lift something so heavy that after a couple of tries you’re exhausted, but you’re done, you get your endorphins and you get out of there. Or so I’ve been told. Builds muscle tone, bone density or, in this case, mental fortitude.

headline: El Paso Immigration Center Is Dangerously Overcrowded, Inspector General Warns
abstract: A federal watchdog’s report said immigration officials needed to take “immediate” action. Some people had been held in the facility for weeks.
lead_paragraph: Severe overcrowding at an immigration facility in El Paso presents an immediate risk to the health and safety of hundreds of migrants being held there, with some of those detained standing on top of toilets in crowded rooms just to find air to breathe, a federal watchdog said this week.

headline: Trump Administration Strips India of Special Trade Status
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Customs (Tariff)', 'Protectionism (Trade)']
abstract: The status exempts billions of dollars of India’s products from American tariffs, part of a deepening clash over the country’s protections for its market.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration announced on Friday that it was stripping India of a special status that exempts billions of dollars of its products from American tariffs, part of a deepening clash over India’s protections for its market.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Push to End Penalties for Oldest Profession
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, June 1, 2019.
lead_paragraph: “This is about the oldest profession, and understanding that we haven’t been able to deter or end it, in millennia. So I think it’s time to confront reality.”

headline: Prosecutors, Wary of Appearances, Deliberated On How to Explain Smollett Decision
abstract: Emails released on Friday show prosecutors carefully constructing their statement on why the actor Jussie Smollett would no longer face charges of staging a hate crime.
lead_paragraph: Documents released on Friday showed that the day before they dropped all charges against the actor Jussie Smollett, who had been accused of staging a hate crime, prosecutors deliberated over the precise wording of their explanation, cognizant of how the public might perceive their sudden withdrawal from the case.

headline: On Politics: The Biggest Stories of the Week
abstract: It’s been a busy week in American politics. Here are some of the stories you might have missed.
lead_paragraph: From escalating trade wars to Mueller, it’s been a busy week in American politics. Here are some of the biggest stories you might have missed (and some links if you’d like to read further).

headline: Alexander Wang: Spring 2020
abstract: Alexander Wang Spring 2020 Collection
lead_paragraph: Alexander Wang Spring 2020 Collection

headline: What’s on TV Saturday: ‘Ask Dr. Ruth’ and ‘Bad Times at the El Royale’
abstract: A documentary following the sex therapist Dr. Ruth Westheimer comes to Hulu. And “El Royale” makes its television debut on HBO.
lead_paragraph: ASK DR. RUTH (2019) Stream on Hulu. When everyone else treated sex and female sexuality as a dirty secret, Dr. Ruth Westheimer was bringing it center stage. In the 1980s, the sex therapist was everywhere — on late-night TV, on the radio and on morning talk shows. This documentary, directed by Ryan White, follows Dr. Ruth continuing her career even as she approaches her 90th birthday. The film also delves into her past as a Holocaust survivor and explores how she paved the way for a sexual revolution. In her New York Times review, Jeannette Catsoulis wrote that the documentary “feels more like an encomium than a thoughtful probe of a brilliantly mutinous mind.”

headline: The Week in Arts: Idris Elba Revives Luther; Margaret Thatcher Sees the Queen
abstract: Pauline Kael’s film criticism is celebrated at the movies, and it’s all Bach all the time for the Orchestra of St. Luke’s.
lead_paragraph: June 1, 3; sab.org/workshop

headline: ‘Balkan Spring’ Turns to Summer, and Hopes for Change Dim
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Corruption (Institutional)', 'Foreign Investments', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots']
abstract: From Serbia to Montenegro and Albania, thousands have taken to the streets for months to protest corrupt, autocratic leaders. Yet nothing has budged.
lead_paragraph: TIVAT, Montenegro — Several dozen protesters had gathered on the promenade of the coastal town of Tivat, wedged between Montenegro’s rugged mountains and a sparkling Adriatic Sea. Behind them, as if in cue, a superyacht was pulling into port.

headline: The Doctor Who Stayed Behind to Save Babies in His Long-Suffering Homeland
abstract: In the Central African Republic, which ranks next to last in the world on quality of life indicators, a peace accord allows a pediatrician and his trainees to build a future.
lead_paragraph: BANGUI, Central African Republic — Dr. Jean Chrysostome Gody bounds down a stench-filled hallway in the Central African Republic’s only pediatric hospital, his daily soundtrack the high-pitched crying of dozens of babies in the malnutrition wing.

headline: Fact-Checking Elizabeth Warren on the Campaign Trail
keywords: ['Medical Marijuana', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'United States Economy', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Student Loans']
abstract: The Massachusetts senator has emphasized her wealth tax on millionaires and defended her past stance on marijuana. Here’s a fact check.
lead_paragraph: Senator Elizabeth Warren has climbed in recent polls as she churns out a stream of ambitious policy proposals and renews calls for President Trump’s impeachment.

headline: Elizabeth Gilbert’s ‘City of Girls’ Delivers a Love- and Booze-Filled Romp Through 1940s New York
abstract: The best-selling author’s new novel features a rebellious ingénue and a demimonde of hard-living showgirls and theater people.
lead_paragraph: CITY OF GIRLS By Elizabeth Gilbert

headline: In the Kentucky Governor’s Race, It’s an Unpopular Man vs. an Unpopular Party
abstract: The governor of Kentucky is not popular, even within his own party. But party ID and a friendship with the president may be enough for his re-election.
lead_paragraph: PIKEVILLE, Ky. — Under normal circumstances, the Kentucky governor’s race would be all but over except for the concession phone call. The incumbent running for re-election this year is a conservative Republican in a state that has recently become as red as hot coal, where unemployment is as low as it has been in nearly two decades and most of the voters are still crazy about the governor’s ally, President Trump.

headline: What Kenan Thompson Can’t Travel Without
abstract: His family, to start with.
lead_paragraph: The actor and comedian Kenan Thompson has been a star on “Saturday Night Live” for a record-breaking 16 seasons. In July, he’ll also be a judge, along with Chrissy Teigen and Jeff Foxworthy, on “Bring the Funny,” a new television series where comedians will compete in a talent show for fame and money. Next season, he will start in a new family sitcom, "The Kenan Show."

headline: How Can I Avoid a Rent Increase?
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Rent Control and Stabilization', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)']
abstract: Landlords always want to raise the rent when a lease is renewed, but a little research could earn you a lot of leverage.
lead_paragraph: Q: I live in a market-rate apartment in Kensington, Brooklyn, with reasonable rent. My lease is up for renewal soon and I want to stay. But I haven’t heard anything from my landlord yet, and I’m worried the rent will go up a lot. What’s the best way to approach the property manager about a lease renewal? Would it help if I agree to a two-year lease?

headline: Champions League Final Preview: Liverpool or Tottenham?
abstract: The Premier League rivals meet Saturday in the Champions League final in Madrid. Rory Smith makes the case for each side.
lead_paragraph: [Sign up for Rory Smith’s weekly newsletter on world soccer: Rory Smith on Soccer.]

headline: 11 of Our Best Weekend Reads
abstract: A Peter Max mystery. On the trail of Tupelo honey. “Star Wars” at Disneyland. Opera and race. An autoworker grapples with his plant’s closing. And more.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the weekend. It’s been a week: Storms of the literal and verbal kind. We heard from Robert Mueller. And in internal news, The Times hosted its Student Journalism Institute. We also had several great stories that you should read if you haven’t yet.

headline: Hotel Review: Kartrite Resort & Indoor Waterpark, Monticello, N.Y.
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'AMUSEMENT AND THEME PARKS', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings']
abstract: Small children, big children and adults who enjoy behaving like children will find much to like at the New York resort. Others may notice the rough edges.
lead_paragraph: Junior suite rates during the low-season start online at $179; prices jump considerably for the high-season and for larger suites. A resort fee per room per night is $35.

headline: Man Who Posed as Saudi Prince and Defrauded Investors Out of $8 Million Is Sent to Prison
keywords: ['Frauds and Swindling', 'Securities and Commodities Violations', 'Identity Theft']
abstract: Anthony Gignac, 48, once called “The Prince of Fraud,” was sentenced to more than 18 years in prison. Prosecutors said he had spent most of his life impersonating Prince Khalid al-Saud.
lead_paragraph: The man who called himself Prince Khalid al-Saud of Saudi Arabia liked the finer things in life: Rolex watches and Cartier bracelets, a Miami penthouse with a door buzzer labeled Sultan and expensive outfits for his Chihuahua, Foxy, whose life he chronicled on Instagram.

headline: As Trade War Spreads to Mexico, Companies Lose a Safe Harbor
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'Customs (Tariff)', 'United States Economy', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Automobiles', 'Agriculture and Farming', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Natural Gas', 'Medical Devices', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Trade tensions led American companies to shift operations to Mexico from China. President Trump’s latest tariff threat has upended that strategy.
lead_paragraph: When trade tensions with China flared last year, many companies sought refuge in a country with a long, stable relationship with the United States: Mexico.

headline: 5 Writers on the Summers They Will Never Forget
abstract: In the pool, by the sea, tales of long summer days on the water.
lead_paragraph: Longer, warmer days are finally here, and the beach beckons. But what makes a beach trip truly unforgettable? We asked five writers for their favorite memories about sand, surf and summertime.

headline: After SpaceX Starlink Launch, a Fear of Satellites That Outnumber All Visible Stars
keywords: ['Space and Astronomy', 'Satellites', 'Stars and Galaxies', 'Research', 'Telescopes and Observatories', 'Private Spaceflight', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Radio']
abstract: Images of the Starlink constellation in orbit have rattled astronomers around the world.
lead_paragraph: Last month, SpaceX successfully launched 60 500-pound satellites into space. Soon amateur skywatchers started sharing images of those satellites in night skies, igniting an uproar among astronomers who fear that the planned orbiting cluster will wreak havoc on scientific research and trash our view of the cosmos.

headline: A ‘Leap of Faith’ for Two Scholars of Theology
abstract: The couple were introduced on a blind date in January 2015 while both lived in New York.
lead_paragraph: The Rev. John Russell Stanger and Guthrie Graves-Fitzsimmons were married June 1 at Louisville Presbyterian Theological Seminary in Kentucky. The Rev. Lauren Jones Mayfield, a United Church of Christ minister, performed the ceremony.

headline: With the Blessing of a Power Ranger
abstract: The couple met at a gay bar in Portland, Ore., in February 2018, after the Tinder app pinpointed their location “50 feet away.”
lead_paragraph: Darren Garrett Davis and Daniel Wade Sene are to be married June 2 at Portland White House, a bed-and-breakfast in Portland, Ore. Alyson Sullivan, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the event, is to officiate. The singer Debbie Gibson, a friend of the couple, is to walk them down the aisle.

headline: A Golf Lesson With Bridget Moynahan
abstract: The actress and co-author of “Our Shoes, Our Selves” teed up at Chelsea Piers.
lead_paragraph: Bridget Moynahan doesn’t understand people who don’t understand the appeal of watching golf. “I don’t think it’s boring,” said Ms. Moynahan, 48, a star of the police drama “Blue Bloods,” which was just renewed for a 10th season. “I find it really relaxing.”

headline: A Conversation With the ‘Queen of Cake’
abstract: Sylvia Weinstock, whose first job was as a schoolteacher, has baked wedding cakes for high-profile clients like Mariah Carey and Billy Joel. Oh, and she hates fondant.
lead_paragraph: Sylvia Weinstock is known among fans as the “queen of cake,” for her ornate, colorful and realistic confectionery designs. But she didn’t start out in the baking business.

headline: The Paparazzi Staked Outside Ivanka Trump and Jared Kushner’s D.C. Home
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Celebrities', 'News and News Media']
abstract: Tabloid photographers are there when they leave for work, when they return at night, when Kim Kardashian West or Steven Mnuchin drops by.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — On a recent Monday morning, Ivanka Trump began her day as usual, with bad media coverage, a good get-up and a greeting at her front door by the paparazzi.

headline: Pope Francis Seeks to Mend Open Wounds With Orthodox Church in Romania
abstract: After centuries of schism and decades of Communist rule that imprisoned, killed and otherwise persecuted Catholics, hard feelings remain.
lead_paragraph: BUCHAREST, Romania — When Pope John Paul II made history in Romania 20 years ago by becoming the first leader of the Roman Catholic Church to visit a predominantly Orthodox nation since the schism of 1054, he was welcomed as the global figure who helped bring down Communism.

headline: Is This the End for Netanyahu?
abstract: Benjamin Netanyahu has rebounded from so many political defeats that he is called a magician. This time, the Israeli prime minister may not have another rabbit in his hat.
lead_paragraph: TEL AVIV — “He’s a magician! He’s a magician!”

headline: Fairy-Tale College Applications
abstract: A school made headlines for sending black students to elite campuses, but it was too good to be true.
lead_paragraph: The Times debuts a new TV show, “The Weekly,” Sunday night on FX and Monday on Hulu. The premiere episode tells the story of two Washington correspondents, Katie Benner and Erica Green, investigating a small Louisiana school, T.M. Landry, which falsified transcripts, made up student accomplishments and trafficked in the worst stereotypes of black America to manufacture Cinderella stories.

headline: A Foul Ball, an Injured Little Girl and Another Cycle of Anguish
abstract: Despite additional netting at baseball parks, spectators remain vulnerable, and some players and fans are wondering what it will take to spur more change.
lead_paragraph: After a young girl was hurt by a line drive Wednesday night in Houston, leaving the batter who hit the ball into the stands — Albert Almora Jr. of the Chicago Cubs — on his knees in horror, a tiny corner of the social media world lit up.

headline: A Drug Prolonged Life in Younger Women With Advanced Breast Cancer
abstract: Adding a newer medicine to the standard hormonal treatment helped women who had not reached menopause or were still going through it.
lead_paragraph: A drug that can slow the progression of advanced breast cancer has been shown for the first time to lengthen survival in women whose disease started before or during menopause, researchers reported on Saturday.

headline: Happy Global Running Day
abstract: Wednesday is the day to celebrate the sport.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the Running newsletter! Every Saturday morning, we email runners with news, advice and some motivation to help you get up and running. Sign up here to get it in your inbox.

headline: José Antonio Reyes, Former Arsenal Player, Dies in Car Crash at 35
abstract: Mr. Reyes’s car ran off the highway south of the Spanish city of Seville on Saturday, according to local news reports.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — José Antonio Reyes, a Spanish soccer star who played for several of the biggest clubs in Europe, including Arsenal in the Premier League, died on Saturday in a car crash, his former club Sevilla FC announced. He was 35.

headline: Philip Green, U.K. Fashion Mogul, Charged With Assault in U.S. in Groping Case
abstract: The Top Shop owner faces four counts of misdemeanor assault in Arizona after a Pilates instructor accused him of unwanted groping and sexually inappropriate behavior.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A British businessman known as the King of Retail Fashion and dogged by claims of sexual harassment and racist abuse has been charged in the United States with four counts of misdemeanor assault after a fitness instructor in Arizona accused him of unwanted groping and sexually inappropriate behavior.

headline: ‘You Don’t Have to Be in Des Moines.’ Democrats Expand Primary Map, Spurred by Social Media.
keywords: ['Debates (Political)', 'States (US)', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: With voters increasingly getting information online and from TV, candidates are traveling to a wide range of states, viewing them as sound stages for delivering their message.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Sunday marks exactly eight months until the Iowa caucuses, but only a single, long-shot Democratic candidate in the party’s sprawling field, Representative Tim Ryan, spent the weekend campaigning there.

headline: Suspect in Virginia Beach Shooting Was a Longtime City Employee
keywords: ['Virginia Beach, Va, Shooting (2019)', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: DeWayne Craddock, an employee with the Public Utilities Department, killed at least 12 people and injured several others, according to the police.
lead_paragraph: Before DeWayne Antonio Craddock stormed a Virginia Beach municipal complex on Friday, where law enforcement officials said he slaughtered a dozen people and injured several others, he had made his living in public service.

headline: What Are Mexico’s Biggest Exports to the United States?
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'Politics and Government', 'Customs (Tariff)']
abstract: President Trump’s 5 percent tariff on Mexican goods could shake producers of cars, electronics, apparel, alcohol and more.
lead_paragraph: It’s not just avocados.

headline: Virginia Beach Shooting: A City Grieves Its Workers a Day After Horror
keywords: ['Virginia Beach, Va, Shooting (2019)', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: Most of the victims, city officials said, worked for the Virginia Beach government, several of them for decades.
lead_paragraph: VIRGINIA BEACH — Eleven of them were civil servants, the kind of people who worked on construction projects and water quality and right of way issues. Another was a local contractor who had come by to talk about a permit.

headline: Former N.F.L. Player Keith Mumphery, After Settling Lawsuit, Plots a Comeback
abstract: Cleared, then convicted of relationship violence in absentia, then cut from the N.F.L., Mumphery has once again been cleared. Now he needs a job.
lead_paragraph: Keith Mumphery, a once and perhaps future pro football receiver, stands vindicated, cleared of charges of sexual assault that nearly wrecked him. Now he needs someone to hand him back two years of his life.

headline: 12 New Books to Watch For in June
abstract: A new novel by the author of “Eat, Pray, Love,” a former Jehovah’s Witness reflects on her faith and more.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to June. Hopefully there will be some quiet afternoons in your future this summer, or at the very least, plenty of moments for you to grab a book. We’ve put together a list of exciting new titles coming out this month that will make any reader happy.

headline: Summer Baking Bucket List
abstract: Rainbow cake, lemon-raspberry danish and more recipes.
lead_paragraph: Baking in the summer? We’re all about it, braving the heat for delicious treats to share. Turn on the oven (and maybe open a window) and make lemon-raspberry danish, speculoos cookie butter pie and rainbow cake (click on the image above for a beautiful, colorful and helpful video). You’ll find many more recipes in the collection below.

headline: A Gun Killed My Son. So Why Do I Want to Own One?
keywords: ['Gun Control', 'Firearms', 'School Shootings and Armed Attacks', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Second Amendment (US Constitution)']
abstract: While fighting for stricter gun laws, I was always told I didn’t understand. Maybe now I do.
lead_paragraph: To be clear, there was nothing I could’ve done to save him. It’s just a fantasy that has been circling my brain in a holding pattern for decades — that somehow I could have intervened.

headline: 2019 French Open: Serena Williams and Naomi Osaka Lose in the Third Round
abstract: Sofia Kenin’s 6-2, 7-5 win over Williams and Katerina Siniakova’s 6-4, 6-2 victory over Osaka underscored the wide-open nature of women’s tennis.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Whether you were watching Naomi Osaka lose in the sunshine or watching Serena Williams lose in the shadows, the view of women’s tennis on Saturday at the French Open was the same.

headline: Congress Weighs Whether to Allow Guantánamo Prisoners to Travel to the U.S. for Medical Care
keywords: ['Detainees', 'United States Politics and Government', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Terrorism', 'Medicine and Health']
abstract: The Pentagon has been putting a new focus on the health care needs of aging detainees, but there is still considerable political opposition to allowing them on American soil.
lead_paragraph: This article was produced in partnership with the Pulitzer Center on Crisis Reporting.

headline: The Scripps Spelling Bee Is Broken. Please Don’t Fix It.
abstract: Too many winners is not always a bad thing.
lead_paragraph: The 2019 Scripps National Spelling Bee wasn’t supposed to end like this. For the 2016 competition, following two years in a row with two co-champions (not seen since 1962), the contest changed to increase the final round of words and make them even harder. Yet that year, again, it was a tie. After single champions in 2017 and 2018, a remarkable number of contestants were crowned as winners earlier this week.

headline: Cameras Came to the Newsroom. What if They Catch Us Printing Springsteen Tickets?
abstract: My bosses put security monitors around the office. An uproar failed to ensue.
lead_paragraph: They emerged in profusion seemingly overnight, like mushrooms after a good rain — if mushrooms could grow upside down. From ceiling tiles. And monitor your every movement.

headline: The Myth That Defines Our Age
abstract: In the digital world, to believe that you have power is to have it.
lead_paragraph: A myth, if widely accepted enough, can become real.

headline: Breakthroughs Are Not Just for the Young at the French Open
abstract: Jan-Lennard Struff, 29, reached the fourth round of a Grand Slam tournament for the first time on Saturday. His next obstacle is No. 1 Novak Djokovic.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Jan-Lennard Struff has been competing at Grand Slam events since 2011, when he first tried and failed to qualify for the United States Open at age 21. Since then, he has entered more than two dozen major tournaments but had never made it past the third round until Saturday.

headline: A Tale of Murder, Revenge and a Canadian Immigrant Dream Gone Wrong
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Frauds and Swindling']
abstract: Vancouver is riveted by the murder trial of a Chinese immigrant, accused of killing his wealthy relative. The story pulls together many strands of recent changes in the city.
lead_paragraph: VANCOUVER, British Columbia — After he had chopped up the body into 108 pieces and taken a long nap, Zhao Li cooked himself some noodles for breakfast.

headline: Variety: Cryptic Crossword
abstract: Richard Silvestri sets us up for a difficult endeavor.
lead_paragraph: CRYPTIC CROSSWORD  — Today’s puzzle by the master setter Richard Silvestri is truly challenging. Personally speaking, it’s the toughest cryptic I’ve finished in a long time, and I’ll be interested in hearing if others agree. If you’re just dipping your toe into cryptic waters, I give you a hearty “Cowabunga!” and direct you to this cryptic explainer that elucidates the various clue styles. Don’t be daunted, it’s all doable and your brain will feel happy and complete once you’ve surfed these mega waves and made it back to shore.

headline: Trump’s Middle East Peace Plan Faces a Crossroads After Coalition Talks in Israel Crumble
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Elections']
abstract: The administration’s plan could end up becoming a vehicle to resurrect the political fortunes of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and protect those of President Trump.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump plans to throw his full weight behind Benjamin Netanyahu’s campaign to save his job as prime minister of Israel. But to do that, analysts and former diplomats said, the president will have to sacrifice any last hopes of proposing a peace plan that is acceptable to both Israelis and Palestinians.

headline: U.S. Promises Security Aid, but No Funds, to Guatemala to Curb Migration
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Foreign Aid', 'Illegal Immigration', 'United States Politics and Government', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: In Guatemala, the homeland security secretary offset requests for restoring funding cuts by offering hands-on assistance from United States agents and investigators.
lead_paragraph: GUATEMALA CITY — The tears that migrants tried to cover with their shirts as they stepped off the plane that had deported them from the United States turned to smiles and applause as they were welcomed home, and told how crucial they are to Guatemala’s growth.

headline: Who Were the 12 Victims in the Shooting in Virginia Beach?
keywords: ['Virginia Beach, Va, Shooting (2019)', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: All but one of the dead were city workers. Here is the full list of names.
lead_paragraph: A public works employee opened fire in a Virginia Beach municipal building on Friday, killing 12 and injuring at least four. All but one of the dead were city workers.

headline: Good Causes and Bad Money
abstract: Readers debate an issue raised by the Met’s announcement that it would no longer accept donations from the Sackler family.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: An AIDS Symphony: The Week in Classical Music
abstract: Corigliano’s First, an update from Amsterdam and a Handel rarity were among the highlights.
lead_paragraph: Readers and listeners! Hopefully you’re enjoying your weekend. Tonight (Saturday) brings a final performance of John Corigliano’s AIDS-inspired Symphony No. 1 at the New York Philharmonic.

headline: Boeing Built Deadly Assumptions Into 737 Max, Blind to a Late Design Change
keywords: ['Boeing 737 Max Groundings and Safety Concerns (2019)', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Aviation Accidents, Safety and Disasters', 'Pilots', 'Sensors']
abstract: A system that doomed two flights was expected to engage only rarely and originally used two sensors. Critical decisions were based on those factors even when they no longer applied, employees said.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — The fatal flaws with Boeing’s 737 Max can be traced to a breakdown late in the plane’s development, when test pilots, engineers and regulators were left in the dark about a fundamental overhaul to an automated system that would ultimately play a role in two crashes.

headline: Scoring Early and Late, Liverpool Wins Sixth Champions League Title
abstract: Overcoming Tottenham in Madrid, Jürgen Klopp and Liverpool claim the prize they had coveted for so long.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — There was a moment, as most of Liverpool’s players drew themselves up in line in the middle of the field, ready to offer a guard of honor to Tottenham Hotspur, when Trent Alexander-Arnold was far away, all by himself, in a world all of his own.

headline: The Cautionary Tale of the ‘Female Byron’
keywords: ['Poetry and Poets', 'Women and Girls', 'Writing and Writers', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: Letitia Landon won fame by crafting multiple identities for herself. But she couldn’t escape the confines of a male-dominated English society.
lead_paragraph: We tend to think of women poets of the 19th century as unworldly creatures: Emily Dickinson, all in white, running away at the sight of strangers, or the equally reclusive Emily Brontë, writing out her poems in microscopic handwriting in tiny private notebooks. Neither wrote poetry for money or even with an eye to publication. As Brontë put it, “Riches I hold in light esteem / And love I laugh to scorn, / And lust of fame was but a dream / That vanished ere the morn.”

headline: I Am the World’s Oldest Millennial
abstract: It’s a burden one of us has to bear, and I am sorry to report that I have realized it is me.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes, it feels as though I am older than everyone else my age. Or at least the world conspires to make me feel that way.

headline: Family Dollar Plans to Sell Alcohol at 1,000 Stores
abstract: “It’s basically damaging to the neighborhood,” said one woman about news that the retailer will sell alcohol in 1,000 of its stores.
lead_paragraph: Dollar Tree, the company that purchased Family Dollar in 2015, this week announced plans to sell alcohol in 1,000 select stores across the country.

headline: Lowering the Barr
keywords: ['Special Prosecutors (Independent Counsel)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates']
abstract: An odyssey into the dark heart of William Barr.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When I was a political reporter at The Times, I had an editor who told me never to give anyone a Homeric epithet.

headline: Modi’s Problems at Home Overshadow Trump’s Latest Trade Threat to India
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'United States International Relations', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Customs (Tariff)', 'Agriculture and Farming', 'Embargoes and Sanctions']
abstract: President Trump ended India’s special trade status, hoping to jolt stalled trade talks. But the prime minister is focused on India’s sluggish economy.
lead_paragraph: MUMBAI, India — President Trump has made India the latest target in his widening global trade war, but the country’s newly re-elected prime minister, Narendra Modi, has bigger problems to address.

headline: Stop Creating Corporate Goliaths
keywords: ['Wireless Communications', 'Cellular Telephones', 'Telephones and Telecommunications', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues']
abstract: Letting T-Mobile merge with Sprint would hurt consumers, workers and the economy.
lead_paragraph: For years, T-Mobile’s chief executive, John Legere, has gleefully bad-mouthed his much larger mobile phone competitors, Verizon Wireless and AT&T, for their high prices and profit margins, and their low-quality service. Decked out in magenta sneakers and T-shirts, sporting long hair like an aging rocker, Mr. Legere promoted T-Mobile and himself to his 6.2 million Twitter followers as renegades — telephonic cool kids.

headline: Why Isn’t Instagram More Witty?
keywords: ['Poetry and Poets', 'Writing and Writers', 'Social Media', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: Clever and vaguely profound, aphorisms should be the ideal expression for our distracted moment.
lead_paragraph: This should be the golden age of the aphorism. Constrained as we all are by time, attention and social media platform character limits, when we pull out our smartphones and stare into their illuminated fields, we can take in only so much. Shouldn’t those words be perfectly chosen to vibrate with hidden meanings?

headline: Everything a Drag Queen Taught Me About Parenthood
abstract: The first lesson was pride.
lead_paragraph: My son has a scar. It’s a pale line down the center of his nose that’s visible only in certain light, but I know it’s there. He got it at a park in Brooklyn, where no dogs are allowed, but where an unleashed pit bull charged at him, full speed, when he crawled a few feet from our blanket onto the grass.

headline: Politics Is Not Total War
abstract: Or at least it shouldn’t be.
lead_paragraph: Every time I left a job in government — in the Reagan administration and in both Bush administrations — my I.Q. rose by 30 points. Or so it seemed.

headline: 8 Siblings. 4 Time Zones. One WhatsApp Group.
keywords: ['Instant Messaging', 'Social Media', 'Families and Family Life', 'Immigration and Emigration']
abstract: The chat lets us know the small stuff and keeps us company wherever we are.
lead_paragraph: I have one brother and half a dozen sisters, which meant a childhood of battling it out for the top bunk, sharing every pork chop, and once, breathing into a paper bag, having found myself alone in the car with my parents’ undivided attention for the first time. Most important, it means I now possess an army of best friends seven strong.

headline: When China Massacred Its Own People
abstract: Thirty years ago, I was there when the Chinese Army invaded its capital.
lead_paragraph: Thirty years ago in the spring of 1989, as the world’s most populous country teetered on the edge of freedom, I received a late-night phone call in my apartment in Beijing: The Chinese Army was invading its own capital.

headline: Clarence Thomas’s Dangerous Idea
abstract: Does anything link the eugenics of the past to abortion today?
lead_paragraph: Criticizing his fellow justices’ decision to block part of an Indiana law that banned abortion based on sex, race or disability, Clarence Thomas performed a public service: He brought two competing historical narratives into contact with one another, on an issue where ideological arguments often pass like trains in the night.

headline: It’s Time to Tackle the Traffic Problems on Mount Everest
abstract: Too many bodies are piling up on the world’s highest peak. Authorities should screen climbers and limit the numbers.
lead_paragraph: “Because it’s there.” For those who grew up on George Mallory’s famous explanation for his yearning to scale Mount Everest, with all the romance, danger and spirit of exploration it implied, that viral photograph of an endless line of climbers in puffy parkas inching their way to the summit came as a profound shock.

headline: The Economics of Rihanna’s Superstardom
abstract: The music industry can tell us a lot about our winner-take-all economy.
lead_paragraph: The hit song “The Winner Takes It All” was released by the Swedish pop group Abba in 1980. That year also happened to be a turning point for economic inequality. Since 1980, more than 100 percent of the total growth in income in the United States has gone to the top 10 percent of families. A whopping two-thirds of all income gains have gone to the top 1 percent. The bottom 90 percent saw their combined income actually shrink.

headline: What I Learned Leading the Tiananmen Protests
abstract: I paid a hefty price for the demonstrations three decades ago. So did China.
lead_paragraph: I learned that I was China’s most wanted criminal while having my hair cut aboard a crowded, decrepit steamboat on the Yangtze River. The P.A. system suddenly blared that the Beijing Public Security Bureau had ordered the arrest of 21 students who were charged with instigating “counterrevolutionary riots” in Tiananmen Square. My name topped the list.

headline: Twitter Takes Down Accounts of China Dissidents Ahead of Tiananmen Anniversary
abstract: The company said the suspensions were an accident. But the move showed starkly the global political ramifications of Silicon Valley slip-ups.
lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — Three days before the most sensitive political anniversary on the Chinese calendar, Twitter suspended the accounts of Chinese political commentators in what it said was an accident. The move showed starkly the global political ramifications of Silicon Valley slip-ups.

headline: Trump Is Said to Have Overruled Kushner and Other Aides in Threatening Mexico With Tariffs
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Customs (Tariff)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'United States Economy', 'Illegal Immigration']
abstract: President Trump sided with hard-liners in the administration over the objections of top aides, who said punishing Mexico with tariffs would be risky, multiple officials and people briefed on the plan said.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump pushed ahead with plans to impose tariffs  on Mexico over the objections of several top advisers, including his son-in-law, Jared Kushner, opting to side with hard-line officials who were advocating the move, according to multiple administration officials and people briefed on their plans.

headline: The Terror of Getting Lettuce Wrong
abstract: Wait, gardening is supposed to be fun?
lead_paragraph: I spent many winter mornings this year staring at my big, empty yard from my kitchen window, fantasizing about the summer that’s now almost here and wondering what I could do with all that space. Build a giant slip and slide? Raise a small family of goats? I settled on what I thought was something modest: planting a legit garden despite having absolutely no gardening know-how or experience.

headline: The Week in Business: A Surprise Tariff War, and the Future of iPhone Screens
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Mobile Applications', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Car Services and Livery Cabs', 'Customs (Tariff)', 'Family Leaves', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: Plus, Uber will give rude customers the boot, and a victory for gender-neutral parental leave.
lead_paragraph: Happy June! And sorry about your stock portfolio, which probably isn’t looking too hot after President Trump’s latest tariff threats. Here’s what you need to know about the week’s business news.

headline: Trump’s Celebration of L.G.B.T. Rights Is Met With Criticism
keywords: ['Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Civil Rights and Liberties']
abstract: He triggered condemnation from activists who said his celebratory words did little to undo the damage his administration has caused to L.G.B.T. people.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump has said that his administration would lead an effort to decriminalize homosexuality around the world, eliciting condemnation from activists who pointed to the administration’s moves to dismantle protections for gay, bisexual and transgender people.

headline: Stoners’ Film Festival
abstract: Erik Agard doesn’t Bogart this puzzle.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY PUZZLE — As Will Shortz tells us in the print introduction to this puzzle, Erik Agard is the most prolific constructor of 2019 — this is his ninth grid so far. It is his second Sunday puzzle, and it solved almost as fast as a daily for me, even though its subject matter isn’t really my strong suit. I found it only slightly sticky, but the puzzle life isn’t always about staggering through stressful obstacle courses. Sometimes you’ve got to kick back and relax a bit, you know?

headline: Colorado Bans ‘Conversion Therapy’ for Minors
keywords: ['Law and Legislation', 'Discrimination', 'Transgender and Transsexuals', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Therapy and Rehabilitation']
abstract: Colorado on Friday became the 18th state to ban “conversion therapy,” a discredited practice that aims to change a person’s sexual orientation or gender expression.
lead_paragraph: Colorado on Friday became the 18th state to ban “conversion therapy” for minors, a discredited practice that aims to change a person’s sexual orientation or gender expression.

headline: Emmet T. Flood to Step Down as White House Lawyer
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates', 'Executive Privilege, Doctrine of']
abstract: The departure of Mr. Flood, who rose to prominence defending President Bill Clinton during his impeachment in the 1990s, was always expected.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Emmet T. Flood, the White House lawyer who oversaw the administration’s response to the special counsel investigation into the Trump campaign’s ties to Russia, will step down from the job this month, President Trump said on Saturday.

headline: Fading Memories of When Motown Was No. 1
abstract: All four of Detroit’s major sports teams reside within the city limits now. They have something else in common: They’re all trying to recapture championship glory.
lead_paragraph: Little Caesars Arena opened two years ago in downtown Detroit, becoming the shiny new home of the Red Wings and the Pistons and ensuring that for the first time since 1975, all four of Detroit’s major sports teams would reside within the city limits. The franchises have something else in common: They’re all rebuilding, trying to recapture championship glory.

headline: When Detroit Was on Top of the Sports World
abstract: Boston is attempting to join 1936 Detroit as the only American city to hold titles in three major sports at once.
lead_paragraph: More than half a century before Boston goalie Tuukka Rask first stepped onto Finnish ice, Detroit staged one of its grandest banquets, a jubilant affair celebrating unparalleled sports excellence.

headline: Soccer Star Neymar Denies Rape Accusation and Releases Messages From Accuser
abstract: A woman, who said she met the soccer star on Instagram, is accusing Neymar of raping her in a Paris hotel room last month. He took to Instagram to accuse the woman of extortion.
lead_paragraph: Neymar, the soccer star who is one of the world’s best-paid and well-known athletes, has been accused of rape by a woman in São Paulo, Brazil. The woman filed a complaint with the Brazilian police over the incident, which she said happened in a Paris hotel room.

headline: What to Watch Today at the French Open
abstract: Rafael Nadal, Roger Federer and a fourth-round meeting of Grand Slam champions highlight Day 8, expected to be the hottest of the tournament.
lead_paragraph: Though the women’s tennis is often associated with flat, baseline hitting, many different playing styles are thriving atop the game these days, as evidenced by the first match on Suzanne Lenglen Court (5 a.m. Eastern Time). The Czech left-hander Marketa Vondrousova, who has a proclivity for drop shots, and Anastasija Sevastova, a U.S. Open semifinalist last year with a carving backhand, both seek their first quarterfinal at Roland Garros. Vondrousova scored an impressive win over Simona Halep in Rome last month, which announced her readiness to be a threat on clay. Sevastova won the best women’s match so far at this tournament when she topped Elise Mertens, 11-9, in the third set of the third round.

headline: Trump Calls on Britain to ‘Walk Away’ if E.U. Does Not Concede to Its Demands
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)']
abstract: President Trump subverted diplomatic norms in a newspaper interview, also suggesting that the far-right populist Nigel Farage be sent in to negotiate.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Just before his state visit to Britain was to begin, President Trump subverted diplomatic norms by rattling an already precarious political situation there: He suggested that the next prime minister of Britain “walk away” from trying to reach a deal to withdraw from the European Union and that the far-right populist Nigel Farage be sent in to negotiate.

headline: China Strikes Defiant Stance on Trade Against Trump
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'United States International Relations', 'Customs (Tariff)']
abstract: In a new white paper, Beijing blamed the United States for the breakdown in trade talks. Some companies, like FedEx, are already feeling pressure from the Chinese government.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — China struck a defiant stance on Sunday in response to President Trump’s growing pressure on trade, blaming the United States for a breakdown in negotiations and saying it must withdraw its latest round of tariffs before a deal can be reached.

headline: This Week’s Wedding Announcements
abstract: All of the weddings right here on one handy page for you.
lead_paragraph: The Rev. John Russell Stanger and Guthrie Graves-Fitzsimmons were introduced on a blind date in January 2015, while both were living in New York, and immediately connected over a shared love of theology.

headline: Anthony Joshua Upset by Andy Ruiz Jr. in Stunning Seventh-Round Knockout
abstract: Joshua, the previously unbeaten heavyweight world champion, was left staggering by Ruiz in a humiliating loss.
lead_paragraph: Andy Ruiz Jr. pulled off a spectacular upset on Saturday night at Madison Square Garden, defeating Anthony Joshua, the previously unbeaten heavyweight world champion, by technical knockout after the referee stopped the fight in the seventh round.

headline: What’s on TV Sunday: ‘The Weekly’ and ‘NOS4A2’
abstract: A new series from The New York Times debuts on FX. And hop over to AMC to see Zachary Quinto eat children’s souls.
lead_paragraph: THE WEEKLY 10 p.m. on FX. The debut episode of this TV show from The New York Times centers on an article by Erica L. Green and Katie Benner about a school in rural Louisiana that took advantage of racial stereotypes in applications and falsified transcripts to send underprivileged students to elite colleges. Green and Benner are two of the more than 30 reporters featured in the first season of “The Weekly,” which looks at one article each week, going behind the scenes for reporting in the United States and around the world. Some episodes later in the season focus on New York City taxi medallions, immigration and terrorism.

headline: What to Know About Prince Mohammed bin Zayed, the Arab Ruler Swaying Trump
abstract: Prince Mohammed, the de facto ruler of the United Arab Emirates, is one of the most influential Arab leaders in Washington. Here are five takeaways from a Times report.
lead_paragraph: The United Arab Emirates has fewer citizens than Rhode Island, but its de facto ruler, Crown Prince Mohammed bin Zayed of Abu Dhabi, is widely regarded as one of the most influential Arab leaders in Washington and across the Middle East.

headline: The Most Powerful Arab Ruler Isn’t M.B.S. It’s M.B.Z.
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates', 'Royal Families']
abstract: Prince Mohammed bin Zayed expanded the U.A.E.’s power by following America’s lead. He now has an increasingly bellicose agenda of his own. And President Trump seems to be following him.
lead_paragraph: ABU DHABI, United Arab Emirates — Prince Mohammed bin Zayed, the 29-year-old commander of the almost negligible air force of the United Arab Emirates, had come to Washington shopping for weapons.

headline: Confirm or Deny: Russell Harvard
abstract: On Madonna, drag and guerrilla acts of philanthropy.
lead_paragraph: Maureen Dowd: You keep a stack of two-dollar bills to randomly hand out to hard-working people.

headline: Russell Harvard, Reaching Beyond ‘King Lear’
abstract: An actor rightly wonders: Why is there a TV show about meerkats but not one about deaf people?
lead_paragraph: Even though he gouges out eyeballs eight times a week, Russell Harvard seems like a really nice guy.

headline: Warriors Alumni Hold Tight to Their Place in a Dynasty
abstract: Golden State has cycled through 38 players over a five-year stretch of dominance. Those who have left, like Leandro Barbosa and David West, try to explain the experience.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — At 31, Leandro Barbosa was the oldest player on the roster when he joined the Golden State Warriors before the start of the 2014-15 season. His teammates were so young, they might as well have practiced at recess. Stephen Curry was just beginning to edge toward global stardom, and the Warriors had not won an N.B.A. championship since 1975. Nobody was using the word “dynasty.”

headline: Match-Fixing Whistle-Blower Goes From Feel-Good Story to Pariah
abstract: Marco Trungelliti charmed the French Open last year as the luckiest lucky loser. But he has spent much of the year since isolated and ostracized.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Marco Trungelliti was the feel-good story of last year’s French Open.

headline: From Instagram to 5,000 Theaters: Diana Silvers on ‘Ma’ and ‘Booksmart’
abstract: The 21-year-old actress suddenly finds herself being noticed by women she had long admired. “Taylor Swift has seen my face. Cool! Sick!”
lead_paragraph: Diana Silvers has been seen in just three movies in her short career, but she has quickly ascended from a bit part in the superhero thriller “Glass” earlier this year to major roles putting her on thousands of screens this weekend: she plays a high school love interest in the female-centric comedy “Booksmart,” and the main teenager menaced by Octavia Spencer’s psycho in the horror tale “Ma.”

headline: Surrender to a Boundary-Blurring Tour of Europe, War and Peace
abstract: Heiner Goebbels’s sprawling “Everything That Happened and Would Happen” brings music, dance and chance to the Park Avenue Armory.
lead_paragraph: Long before “interdisciplinary” became a cultural buzzword, Heiner Goebbels was smudging all manner of artistic boundaries. For the past three decades, Mr. Goebbels, 66, has been puzzling and invigorating audiences with works that aren’t quite concert music, theater, installation or performance art. His music has embraced rock, jazz, classical styles, voice, text and ambient sound with equal vigor.

headline: Leader of Social Democrats, Merkel’s Coalition Partner, Is Resigning
abstract: Andrea Nahles announced she was stepping down after a dismal showing in the European election, raising questions about the future of Chancellor Angela Merkel’s government.
lead_paragraph: The leader of Germany’s Social Democrats, the junior partner in Chancellor Angela Merkel’s governing coalition, announced her resignation on Sunday, raising new questions about the government’s future, a week after the parties lost support in the elections for the European Parliament.

headline: Insurgent Democrats, Many of Them Women, Worry a New Party Policy Will Block Them
keywords: ['Elections, House of Representatives', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Women and Girls', 'Primaries and Caucuses']
abstract: Democratic primary challengers are often female, young and nonwhite. Many fear a recent move by House Democratic leaders will prevent them from being elected.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A move by House Democratic leaders to thwart party members from mounting primary challenges to incumbents, even in safe Democratic districts, could have the unintended consequence of arresting the party’s shift toward a more female and racially diverse caucus, one of its most striking achievements of the last election.

headline: Homes That Sold for Around $750,000
abstract: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
lead_paragraph: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.

headline: Google and Amazon Are at the Center of a Storm Brewing Over Big Tech
keywords: ['Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Search Engines', 'E-Commerce', 'Online Advertising']
abstract: Support for scrutiny of the tech giants is coming from across the political spectrum. For Google and Amazon, any investigations would be a major distraction, or worse.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Google and Amazon have thrived as American regulators largely kept their distance. That may be changing.

headline: Virginia, Trade, Stonewall: Your Weekend Briefing

lead_paragraph: Here are the week’s top stories, and a look ahead.

headline: Quotation of the Day: The Most Powerful Prince in Washington
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, June 2, 2019.
lead_paragraph: “He thinks he is Machiavelli but he acts more like Mussolini.”

headline: Afghan Peace Marchers Take Cease-Fire Plea Directly to Taliban
abstract: About three dozen activists are heading toward Taliban-controlled territory in southern Afghanistan to ask for a halt to the country’s violence.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — For almost a year, Taliban leaders in Afghanistan have consistently rejected calls for a cease-fire by officials working to negotiate peace. So a group of grass-roots Afghan activists is going to try asking them in person.

headline: Acting Defense Chief Sees No Need to Restart Big Military Exercises With South Korea
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'United States International Relations', 'Nuclear Weapons']
abstract: Patrick Shanahan said he was confident troops were well prepared despite the halt to large-scale war games in a concession to North Korea.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — Acting Defense Secretary Patrick Shanahan said on Sunday that he did not see a need to restore the large-scale joint military exercises that the United States and South Korea suspended over the past year as a concession to North Korea.

headline: Trump State Visit to U.K. Faces Turbulence Amid Brexit Chaos
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)', 'United States International Relations', 'Royal Families', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: When the American president arrives in London on Monday, it’s not clear how much more he can shake up a country that is already roiled by the Brexit debacle.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — President Trump prides himself on being the great disrupter, but when he arrives in London on Monday for a state visit, it’s not clear how much more he can shake up a country that is already convulsed, divided and utterly exhausted by the long debate over its departure from the European Union.

headline: Algeria Cancels Presidential Election, Setting Up New Impasse
abstract: The Constitutional Council scrapped the July 4 vote, giving in to the demands of protesters who had no faith in the process.
lead_paragraph: CAEN, France — Algeria’s Constitutional Council on Sunday canceled elections planned for next month, acceding to demands from protesters who since February have upended the country’s politics.

headline: Anthony Joshua’s Upset Loss to Andy Ruiz Scrambles Heavyweight Boxing
abstract: The heavyweight division was poised for a mainstream comeback with exciting matches among three contenders not named Andy Ruiz Jr., who scored a shocking seventh-round TKO over Joshua on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: It was supposed to be a coming-out party of sorts. A brand-building exercise. The dawn of the next great era in heavyweight boxing.

headline: Stan Wawrinka’s Reward for a Marathon Win? A Match With Roger Federer
abstract: Wawrinka edged Stefanos Tsitsipas in five sets to reach the quarterfinals at a Grand Slam tournament for the first time in two years.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The match began in oppressive midday heat on Sunday and continued for more than five hours until the sun had made its descent behind the walls of Suzanne Lenglen Court, providing the competitors with a cloak of shade to continue their duel.

headline: Cruise Ship Rams Into Tourist Boat and Dock in Venice, Injuring at Least 4
abstract: The huge vessel plowed into a smaller boat on the Giudecca Canal and had people fleeing in panic, reigniting a debate about the dangers of allowing giant ships to pass through the lagoon city.
lead_paragraph: ROME — A colossal cruise liner plowed into a smaller tour ship and a wharf on a canal in Venice on Sunday morning, injuring four people and reigniting arguments about the dangers of allowing the huge vessels to pass through the fragile lagoon city.

headline: What to Cook This Week
abstract: Shop early, cook in the afternoon and get ready for the days ahead: Make cucumber salad, dirty horchatas and roast chicken two ways.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. I’ve been hitting the supermarket late on Sundays these last few weeks, buying supplies in twilight before heading home to cook. The tardiness leaves me a little off the beat, late to serve dinner, late to bed. Mondays come too quickly. It’s not a good way to work or live.

headline: Democrats Are Determined to Spotlight Trump’s Misdeeds, but Remain Divided on How
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates', 'Special Prosecutors (Independent Counsel)', 'Impeachment']
abstract: House Democrats, returning from a weeklong recess, see an opening to focus public attention on presidential misconduct, but they are split over impeachment.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Congress returns on Monday from a weeklong recess with Democrats in broad agreement that they must do a better job of presenting to the public the details of Robert S. Mueller III’s findings but starkly at odds over how to do that.

headline: California Is Now an ‘Early Primary State.’ Democrats Are Grappling With How to Compete.
abstract: After years of voting late in the presidential nominating process, most California Democrats can start casting ballots by mail in February as Iowans head to their caucuses.
lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — Senator Elizabeth Warren bounded onto stage before a crowd of more than 6,000 here — “the biggest one so far,” she announced excitedly — and stayed for nearly two extra hours, past 11 p.m., until everyone who wanted a picture with her had gotten one.

headline: Leah Chase, 96, Creole Chef Who Fed Presidents and Freedom Riders, Dies
abstract: In New Orleans, Dooky Chase’s was the only upscale restaurant that welcomed African-Americans, and it became a gathering place for civil rights leaders.
lead_paragraph: Leah Chase, the nation’s pre-eminent Creole chef, always knew what to feed her famous customers.

headline: The Last Word: Leah Chase
abstract: In 2007, Leah Chase, the pioneering New Orleans chef, sat down with a New York Times reporter to discuss her restaurant, Dooky Chase’s, which served as a meeting place for civil rights workers and entertainers, and was visited by presidents.
lead_paragraph: In 2007, Leah Chase, the pioneering New Orleans chef, sat down with a New York Times reporter to discuss her restaurant, Dooky Chase’s, which served as a meeting place for civil rights workers and entertainers, and was visited by presidents.

abstract: An investigation at Ohio State University revealed that coaches had inklings of a team doctor’s sexual abuse. But Representative Jim Jordan’s denials are assuaging his constituents.
lead_paragraph: URBANA, Ohio — Voters in this small town, a camera-ready county seat cut from the mold of a 1960s-era television set, believe in their congressman. Representative Jim Jordan calls this home, and his fellow Urbanans believe he is a man of integrity. They believe his family, a dynasty of wrestling icons, has served the community well.

headline: Filling Oreo With Toothpaste Earns YouTube Prankster a Jail Sentence
keywords: ['Hoaxes and Pranks', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'Social Media']

lead_paragraph: MADRID — It was a humiliating video that fueled outrage on social media. A YouTube prankster filmed himself offering a homeless man in Barcelona an Oreo cookie filled with toothpaste rather than cream.

headline: Plenty of Fantasy in HBO’s ‘Chernobyl,’ but the Truth Is Real

lead_paragraph: Henry Fountain is a science writer on the Climate desk of The New York Times. He toured the Chernobyl plant and the exclusion zone around it in 2014.

headline: Estranged Husband Arrested in Disappearance of Connecticut Mother of 5
abstract: The police continued to search the home of Fotis Dulos for clues in the disappearance of his wife, Jennifer. Ms. Dulos went missing on May 24 after dropping off her children at school.
lead_paragraph: More than a week ago, Jennifer Dulos disappeared after she dropped her five children off at school in a wealthy town in Connecticut. The police soon began investigating her estranged husband, with whom she had been involved in a bitter divorce and custody battle.

headline: On Chicago’s Stages, Women With Problems
abstract: Working opposite ends of the volume spectrum, two musicals, the new “Six” and a reinterpreted “Next to Normal,” find their levels.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Musicals depend on extremes. Without big emotion, there’s no call for big expression. And without big expression, how do we get big belting and confetti?

headline: Review: ‘The Haunting’ Has a Big Problem With ‘Hamilton’
abstract: Lin-Manuel Miranda is a character, and his hit musical is a punching bag, in Ishmael Reed’s didactic play about historical correctness.
lead_paragraph: In the four years since his musical “Hamilton” first opened at the Public Theater, Lin-Manuel Miranda has become one of America’s most successful and ubiquitous entertainers. There he is, serenading President Obama at the White House, triumphantly taking his show to a recovering Puerto Rico, portraying a chimney sweep in “Mary Poppins Returns.” And, in a true sign that he has made it to the top of the celebrity mountain, Mr. Miranda has proactively counterpunched potential critiques by playing comedic versions of himself, most notably in “Curb Your Enthusiasm.”

headline: Review: ‘Luther,’ Back From the Dead
abstract: The crazy cop show returns to BBC America after a four-year hiatus, reuniting Idris Elba and Ruth Wilson for one (last?) season
lead_paragraph: “Luther,” the loony British cop show in which Idris Elba has been starring over the last decade, is very hard to kill. It rises from the dead again Sunday on BBC America after four years. This season, the fifth, is a typically tidy four episodes — short arcs being advisable when you routinely suspend all the laws of logic, psychology and police procedure.

headline: In China, Public Talk of Sex Is Rare. Could a ‘Pleasure Community’ Change That?
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Sex', 'Sex Education', 'Censorship', 'Birth Control and Family Planning', 'Sexually Transmitted Diseases']
abstract: Strangers gathered in Beijing to discuss a subject rarely addressed publicly in China: how to satisfy a woman. These workshops come at a fraught time for Chinese feminists.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — In a room with soft lighting, decorated with fuzzy blankets and turquoise balloons, a group of 30 or so strangers gathered on a recent afternoon in Beijing to discuss a subject that is largely taboo in China: how to satisfy a woman sexually.

headline: F.B.I. Is Said to Be Investigating College Admissions Practices at T.M. Landry
abstract: The private school in Louisiana, once celebrated for helping underprivileged and minority students attend elite colleges, is now under federal investigation over its college applications.
lead_paragraph: LAFAYETTE, La. — T.M. Landry College Preparatory School, a private school in Louisiana that garnered national attention for helping underprivileged and minority students attend elite colleges, is under federal investigation over its college admissions practices after disclosures that it cut corners and doctored applications, according to multiple people contacted by the F.B.I.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Mick Mulvaney, President Trump’s acting chief of staff, sought on Sunday to play down the White House’s directive to hide a Navy destroyer named after Senator John McCain during the president’s visit to a naval base in Japan last week.

headline: What to Watch Monday at the French Open
abstract: The last of the fourth-round matches will determine the slate of quarterfinalists at Roland Garros.
lead_paragraph: The two women who shook up the women’s field with upset wins on Saturday will start the day’s play (5 a.m. Eastern), hoping to continue their world-beating form. Sofia Kenin, the 20-year-old American who beat Serena Williams, will seek a quarterfinal berth in the first match on Philippe Chatrier Court against the eighth-seeded Ashleigh Barty, who is translating her strong play in the hardcourt season onto clay.

headline: After Tiananmen, China Conquers History Itself
abstract: Young people question the value of knowledge, a victory for Beijing 30 years after the crackdown on student protests.
lead_paragraph: I was giving a talk about Tiananmen Square’s legacy at an Australian university about two years ago when a young Chinese student put up her hand during the question-and-answer session. “Why do we have to look back to this time in history?” she asked. “Why do you think it will be helpful to current and nowadays China, especially our young generation? Do you think it could be harmful to what the Chinese government calls the harmonious society?”

headline: When Defending Vaccines Gets Ugly
abstract: Dr. Peter Hotez has devoted his career to making vaccines more widely available. He routinely gets attacked for it.
lead_paragraph: Peter Hotez is no stranger to vitriol. An outspoken proponent of vaccines in a state with one of the most vocal anti-vaccine lobbies in the country, Dr. Hotez, dean of the National School of Tropical Medicine at the Baylor College of Medicine in Texas, has been harassed at lectures, threatened online and blamed for his daughter’s autism.

headline: China Cannot Erase the Truth of Tiananmen
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: The Communist government wants to control the future by suppressing the past.
lead_paragraph: Even after 30 years, erasing the history of the massacre in Tiananmen Square remains an obsession of the Chinese Communist Party. To a degree, it has succeeded: The Chinese raised in the extraordinary boom times since that day often know little about what happened on June 4, 1989, or accept the official line that curbing the “counterrevolutionaries” was needed to facilitate the economic miracle.

headline: Bernie Sanders: I Know Where I Came From. Does President Trump?
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Income Inequality', 'United States Economy', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: My political agenda has been shaped by my family’s experiences of struggling to make ends meet.
lead_paragraph: My father came to this country from Poland at the age of 17 with barely a nickel in his pocket. I spent my first 18 years, before I left home for college, in a three-and-a-half-room, rent-controlled apartment in Brooklyn. My mother’s dream was to own her own home, but we never came close. My father’s salary as a paint salesman paid for basic necessities, but never much more.

headline: The Fox News Primary? How Trump’s Favorite Network Became a Democratic Power Player
abstract: A Sunday town hall with Senator Kirsten Gillibrand was another sign of Fox News’s ability to influence the Democratic primary, despite a ban by party leaders.
lead_paragraph: Three months ago, Democratic Party leaders took a stand: Fox News, President Trump’s favorite channel, and a reliable soapbox for attacks on liberals, was barred from participating in the party’s 2020 presidential debates. The move would ice out the network derided by critics as “state TV” from influencing the outcome of the Democratic primary.

headline: Trump Administration Considered Tariffs on Australia

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration considered imposing tariffs on imports from Australia last week, but decided against the move amid fierce opposition from military officials and the State Department, according to several people familiar with the discussions.

headline: For the Chao Family, Deep Ties to the World’s 2 Largest Economies
abstract: The family of Elaine Chao, the transportation secretary, has forged high-level political connections not only in the United States but also in China, where their shipping business has prospered.
lead_paragraph: The family of Elaine Chao, the transportation secretary and wife of Mitch McConnell, the Senate majority leader, has high-level political connections not only in the United States but also in China. That gives the family unusual status in the world’s two largest economies.

headline: The Princess vs. the Demagogue
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Royal Families', 'Women and Girls', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Trump again shows his attitude toward women who dare to stand up to him.
lead_paragraph: In an interview Saturday with Rupert Murdoch’s right-wing British tabloid, The Sun, President Trump characterized statements by Meghan Markle, before she became Duchess of Sussex, as “nasty” during the 2016 campaign.

headline: ‘Billions’ Season 4, Episode 11: Trader, Taylor, Lawyer, Spy
abstract: The penultimate episode of this season, like Chuck, indulged in temptation, misdirection and obfuscation.
lead_paragraph: Chuck Rhoades has issued his own mission statement. “I myself will be doing my usual boogie,” he tells the gaggle of favor-trading power brokers he’s assembled to help him take down Jock Jeffcoat. “Inducing mistakes through temptation, misdirection, obfuscation and conflation-slash-corruption of the ideals that built this great nation.” A brief pause for breath follows, before he adds, “For a good and noble purpose, of course.”

headline: 5 Cheap(ish) Things for a Dip in the Pool
abstract: Pool season is finally here.
lead_paragraph: The weather is finally warming and that means pool season is upon us. As a warning to all who plan to invite me over this summer, I don’t pack light. At a minimum, I’ll bring my sunglasses, my favorite beach towel, my biggest wide-brimmed hat and a pair of flip-flops.

headline: Witnessing China’s 1989 Protests, 1,000 Miles From Tiananmen Square
abstract: As a student, Representative Andy Levin of Michigan experienced firsthand the bloody crackdown against pro-democracy demonstrators.
lead_paragraph: The Chinese student protests in the spring of 1989 are remembered mostly for how they ended — the bloody military assault around Tiananmen Square in which hundreds, perhaps thousands, were killed. But the pro-democracy movement spread far beyond Beijing before it was crushed. More than 1,000 miles away in Chengdu, a sprawling metropolis in southwest China, as in scores of other cities across the country, young workers and students concerned with corruption and unemployment gathered to demand accountability and democracy.

headline: Yankees Lose to Red Sox as Answers, and the Ball, Elude Clint Frazier
abstract: The outfielder’s defensive struggles returned, helping blunt the Yankees’ chances of a rally against Boston.
