headline: Who Can Adopt a Native American Child? A Texas Couple vs. 573 Tribes
keywords: ['ADOPTIONS', 'Native Americans', 'Child Custody and Support', 'Navajo Indians', 'Law and Legislation', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'your-feed-science']
abstract: A bitter custody battle threatens affirmative action laws, tribal rights, and the future of one little girl.
lead_paragraph: FORT WORTH — The 3-year-old boy who could upend a 40-year-old law aimed at protecting Native American children barreled into the suburban living room, merrily defying his parents’ prediction that he might be shy. He had a thatch of night-black hair and dark eyes that glowed with mischievous curiosity. As he pumped a stranger’s hand and scampered off to bounce on an indoor trampoline, his Superman cape floated behind him, as if trying to catch up.

headline: Back-Country Greenwich, Conn.: Where Privacy Doesn’t Come Cheap
abstract: This Fairfield County area offers lots of green space to those who can pay the price. And thanks to changing tastes, it’s now (slightly) more affordable.
lead_paragraph: When Tyler and Stephanie Mitchell decided to leave San Francisco for a family business opportunity in Greenwich, Conn., they looked forward to the possibility of privacy. “In San Francisco, people are living on top of each other, even in the nicest parts of the city,” said Mr. Mitchell, 40, an owner of the Mitchells chain of high-end clothing stores, including Richards of Greenwich. “You can hear each other’s TVs.”

keywords: ['Civilian Casualties', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'your-feed-opinionvideo']
abstract: The United States, British and French militaries were successful in pushing ISIS out of Raqqa, Syria. But will they acknowledge the cost?
lead_paragraph: Western forces have failed to acknowledge the extent of civilian deaths they caused and have yet to make a long-term commitment to help the survivors rebuild. The video op-ed above argues that they must further investigate what happened: If so may civilians died, clearly something went terribly wrong.

headline: One Hospital’s Plan to Reduce C-sections: Communicate
abstract: There might be fewer unneeded cesarean sections if doctors learned to keep mothers informed at every stage of labor.
lead_paragraph: Erica Rice calls her 2017 V.B.A.C., or vaginal birth after cesarean, “a herculean team effort.” Not least of which because she delivered twins.

keywords: ['Midterm Elections (2018)', 'Elections, House of Representatives', 'Elections, Senate', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Regaining control of the upper chamber may lie just outside the party’s grasp, but it is not out of reach.
lead_paragraph: For Democrats to overcome the Republican advantage in the struggle for control of the Senate, they will need a massive turnout effort and a wave election even more powerful than the one that won them the House in 2018.

headline: The Problem With ‘Sharenting’
abstract: Fears about troubling videos and excessive screen time are legitimate. But the real threat is adults’ disregard for their children’s rights and best interests.
lead_paragraph: Parents this year were introduced to a goblin for the digital era: Momo, a bird-woman with an eerie grin who commanded the children who watched her videos on YouTube to harm themselves. The story turned out to be essentially a hoax, but it went viral in the first place because it seemed to validate a widely held belief: Our kids are in danger because of threats associated with the dark corners of social media and risk of addiction to phones and tablets.

headline: Trump’s Split-Screen Persona on Blaring Display in U.K. Visit
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Over his three-day trip, the president embraced regal respectability on one side, and settling scores on the other.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — He quoted Roosevelt and gently greeted frail veterans at a D-Day commemoration, hours after proclaiming Bette Midler a “psycho” and Chuck Schumer a “creep.” He exalted soldiers’ bravery while dismissing his avoidance of service in Vietnam, calling it a country “nobody heard of.” He toasted Britain’s queen at a Buckingham Palace banquet, after calling London’s mayor a loser.

headline: DealBook Briefing: A Rate Cut Isn’t a Done Deal
abstract: The Fed’s chairman hinted that the central bank could act to sustain economic expansion — but he did not explicitly say that it would cut rates.

headline: Australia May Well Be the World’s Most Secretive Democracy
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Freedom of the Press', 'News Sources, Confidential Status of']
abstract: Raids targeting journalists this week are the latest examples of how far the country’s government will go to scare officials and reporters into submission, media experts say.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — One journalist is being investigated for reporting that several boats filled with asylum seekers recently tried to reach Australia from Sri Lanka. Another reporter had her home raided by the authorities this week after reporting on a government plan to expand surveillance powers.

headline: Kim Jong-un Pans Mass Games, and the Spectacle Is Suspended
abstract: The propaganda show that features thousands of children in synchronized events has been a hit with foreign tourists and North Korea’s elites.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea will temporarily suspend its epic mass gymnastics show, a rare foreign tourist attraction in the isolated country, after the propaganda-filled festival was panned by the North’s leader, Kim Jong-un, travel agencies said on Wednesday.

headline: U.N. Aid Chief Warns of Looming ‘Horror’ as Somalia Again Faces Famine
abstract: Mark Lowcock, the emergency relief coordinator at the United Nations, said that more than five million people were at risk in the Horn of Africa, mostly Somalis.
lead_paragraph: The top humanitarian official at the United Nations sounded the alarm on Wednesday about the looming risk of famine in the Horn of Africa because of drought, warning that more than five million people are threatened, mostly Somalis.

headline: $1.8 Million Homes in Connecticut, California and Michigan

lead_paragraph: This Litchfield County house is in an area popular with second-home owners, who enjoy the nearby lakes and mountains year-round. It is just south of the Massachusetts border, on the edge of the Berkshires, about two and a half hours west of Boston and the same distance northeast of Manhattan. The village of Millerton, N.Y., with its shops and services, is about 10 minutes southwest.

headline: Trump Says No Deal With Mexico Is Reached as Border Arrests Surge
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Customs (Tariff)', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Illegal Immigration', 'United States Politics and Government']

lead_paragraph: Updated June 6, 2019: After this story was published, officials from Customs and Border Protection said on Thursday that illegal border crossings have risen to a 13-year high, not a seven-year high as they had reported earlier.

headline: Parkland Shooting ‘Changed the Whole Conversation’ in Florida Politics
abstract: The mass shooting in 2018 that left 17 dead forced elected officials to talk about gun control and school safety. Politics in the state has been changed.
lead_paragraph: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla. — One horrific afternoon at a Parkland, Fla., high school changed the politics of this state.

headline: President Trump, Unloved in Britain, Still Tries to Play Kingmaker
abstract: As if in an episode of “The Apprentice,” Mr. Trump evaluated the candidates vying to replace Theresa May as prime minister, as the candidates themselves competed for his favor.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — It looked for all the world like a boardroom scene from “The Apprentice,” with President Trump appraising the candidates to succeed Prime Minister Theresa May, even as she stood by his side at a news conference on Tuesday.

headline: Ford Is Fined in China as Trade Fight With U.S. Rages
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Politics and Government', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues']

lead_paragraph: BEIJING — China’s antitrust regulator on Wednesday announced a fine of around $25 million on Ford’s main joint venture in the country, the latest action against an American company amid the widening economic battle between China and the United States.

headline: Three Bedrooms and a Pool in Croatia

lead_paragraph: This traditional stone house is in Sveti Lovrec, a fortified medieval village on the Istrian Peninsula in Croatia, about 10 miles from the Adriatic Sea.

headline: For U.S. Women, a Rare Question Mark Comes With a Ready Answer
abstract: Alyssa Naeher has big shoes to fill as the United States’ goalkeeper. Her coaches and teammates have no doubt she is up to the job.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Erica Dambach recognized that the words she was using to describe her former player Alyssa Naeher — “very quiet and reserved,” “unassuming,” “very, very humble” — were not ones most people immediately associate with an indomitable athlete.

headline: They Shared a Tony for ‘Billy Elliot’. What Did They Do for an Encore?
abstract: In 2009, three unknown adolescent boys were the toast of Broadway in the musical’s title role. Where have they been? And where are they going?
lead_paragraph: It was — good gosh, can this possibly be right? — 11 years ago that I met the Billys Elliot, all of us gathered in the fluorescent delirium of Dave & Buster’s in Times Square. They ate pizza and drank milkshakes, because that is how old they were, three kids unknown to Broadway at that point, the last boys standing from a nationwide culling of young dancers. They were on the verge of being huge.

headline: What to Cook Tonight
abstract: You don’t need a recipe to make broiled salmon, with tamari and lemon — just narrative instruction.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. Julia Moskin has a fascinating profile of the Mexican chef and restaurateur Gabriela Cámara in The Times today. Among other things it prompts me to suggest that you make her recipes for the beautiful sweet buns called conchas (above), and for a relatively simple, stovetop version of tacos al pastor.

headline: James Corden Still Loves Theater, Even if His Left Eye Is in Pain
abstract: From a Paris crosswalk to Radio City Music Hall, the TV funnyman and Tony Awards host reminds us that he started on the stage.

headline: Nations League Seeks Foothold in Crowded Soccer Landscape
abstract: The new European event, which concludes on Sunday, is expected to be held every two years, and the 2020-21 event may even be a part of World Cup qualifying.
lead_paragraph: It’s a crowded soccer summer: The Women’s World Cup starts on Friday; South America will determine its men’s champion in the Copa América; and North America, Central America and the Caribbean will do the same in the Concacaf Gold Cup.

headline: Meet the Deep-Sea Dragonfish. Its Transparent Teeth Are Stronger Than a Piranha’s.
keywords: ['Fish and Other Marine Life', 'Teeth and Dentistry', 'Crystals', 'Oceans and Seas', 'Chemistry', 'Biology and Biochemistry', 'your-feed-science']
abstract: Researchers say the tiny crystalline structures in the predator’s fangs could inspire strong, see-through materials.
lead_paragraph: Unassuming dragonfish lurk in the twilight zone, more than 1,600 feet under the surface of the ocean. Dark, eel-like, and roughly three and a half inches long, these deep-sea creatures glow with bioluminescence and have evolved a complex sensory system that allows them to detect even the subtlest movements in the ocean’s shadowy realms, then attract and capture their prey.

headline: These Artists Want to Blow Up the Whole Financial System
abstract: But first they bought bad debts and exploded a van.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — “3 … 2 … 1 …” A deafening bang echoed around the deserted Royal Docks marina in East London, as a crowd of onlookers cheered and whooped.

headline: ‘Archaeology of D-Day’ Aims to Preserve What the Soldiers Left Behind
keywords: ['World War II (1939-45)', 'ARCHAEOLOGY AND ANTHROPOLOGY', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: For the past 10 years, a cadre of field researchers in France has been digging up, documenting and cataloging the physical remains of the Normandy invasion.
lead_paragraph: MALTOT, France — What is left over, 75 years after the fighting ended, comes down to this: pockmarked leather fragments from a dead German soldier’s shoe scattered by his shallow battlefield grave.

keywords: ['Environment', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Waste Materials and Disposal', 'Recycling of Waste Materials', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: The government plans to outlaw the destruction of brand-new consumer products, a practice that companies use to stop goods from being stolen or sold at steep discounts.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — France plans to outlaw the destruction of unsold consumer products, a practice that currently results in the disposal of new goods worth 800 million euros, or more than $900 million, in the country each year.

headline: Can Menopause Ever Be Sexy?
keywords: ['Menopause', 'Dietary Supplements and Herbal Remedies', 'Hair', 'Cosmetics and Toiletries', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: Enterprising beauty companies are targeting menopausal women in a way that’s frank, luxurious and, sometimes, even sexy.
lead_paragraph: A couple of months ago, Sonsoles Gonzalez, a former Procter & Gamble Company executive, introduced a line of hair-care products she had been working on for several years. The upscale collection, which includes shampoos, hair masks and conditioners, comes packaged in trim boxes of marine blue and goldenrod in a blobby pattern that could call to mind a Marni print.

headline: For France, a D-Day Ceremony Laced With Paradox
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'World War II (1939-45)']
abstract: Past anniversaries evoked deep feelings about liberation, sacrifice and unity among allies. Those were before Trump.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — President Trump will spend a few hours this week in Normandy, where, 75 years ago on June 6, in Ronald Reagan’s memorable words, “The Allies stood and fought against tyranny in a giant undertaking unparalleled in human history.” Unlike Mr. Reagan, though, Mr. Trump will be hard-pressed to convince skeptical European allies that today’s United States would be willing to commit itself to such an undertaking.

headline: The 1969 Tonys Was a Night to Remember. Just Ask James Earl Jones.
abstract: It was the season of “Hair” vs. “1776” and the arrival of a young actor named Al Pacino.
lead_paragraph: One performer turned down his nomination. One musical was there only because it had been barred the year before. One not-nominated director was mentioned so many times in acceptance speeches that some people thought he was dead.

lead_paragraph: THE PANDEMIC CENTURY One Hundred Years of Panic, Hysteria, and Hubris By Mark Honigsbaum 448 pp. W.W. Norton & Company. $29.95.

headline: For New York Men’s Fashion, Small Is Beautiful
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', "Men's Fashion Week", 'Suits (Apparel)', 'Shopping and Retail']
abstract: Men’s fashion week has contracted to a mere smattering of shows. For scrappy young designers, that may not be all bad.
lead_paragraph: Last Saturday afternoon, the designer Alan Eckstein, 34, was busy installing an interior decorating project he took on as a bill payer. Afterward he pulled an all-nighter at his studio, putting finishing touches on outfits for the Timo Weiland men’s wear show. On Sunday, he took a five-hour paying D.J. gig at the One Hotel in the Dumbo neighborhood of Brooklyn.

headline: Omega’s Moonwatch Enters the Stratosphere
abstract: On the 50th anniversary of the Apollo 11 moon landing, prices for the Omega Speedmaster take off.
lead_paragraph: It’s a big summer for 50th anniversaries: there’s Woodstock, the Stonewall riots and the Manson murders. But for watch geeks, only one matters: the Omega Speedmaster and its journey to the moon.

headline: YouTube to Remove Thousands of Videos Pushing Extreme Views
keywords: ['Fringe Groups and Movements', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Censorship', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Online Advertising', 'Social Media', 'Discrimination', 'Rumors and Misinformation', 'Hate Crimes']
abstract: The decision by YouTube, which is owned by Google, is the latest action by a Silicon Valley company to stem the spread of hate speech and disinformation on their sites.
lead_paragraph: YouTube announced plans on Wednesday to remove thousands of videos and channels that advocate neo-Nazism, white supremacy and other bigoted ideologies in an attempt to clean up extremism and hate speech on its popular service.

headline: ‘Tales of the City’: What to Know Before Watching the Netflix Reboot
abstract: Twenty-five years after causing a sensation with its frank depictions of sex, drugs and L.G.B.T. lives, the series has been revived for a more diverse age. Here’s a refresher on where things left off.
lead_paragraph: Like New York in “Sex and the City,” San Francisco is one of the most beloved characters in the short-lived 1994 mini-series “Tales of the City.” A soapy adaptation of the stories by Armistead Maupin, the series caused a sensation when it aired on Channel 4 in Britain and PBS in the United States, with its frank depictions of sex, drugs and the lives of Bay Area L.G.B.T. people in the late 1970s.

headline: V.A. Prepares for Major Shift in Veterans’ Health Care
keywords: ['Veterans', 'Privatization', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The Department of Veterans Affairs says it is ready for a major shift in access to private care, but veterans groups and lawmakers are concerned.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Department of Veterans Affairs on Thursday will begin allowing a broad section of its nine million enrollees to seek medical care outside of traditional V.A. hospitals, the biggest shift in the American health care system since the passage of the Affordable Care Act nearly a decade ago.

headline: Cruises to Cuba Are Abruptly Canceled, After New Travel Ban
abstract: A day after the Trump administration revised its travel regulations to Cuba, prohibiting cruises, companies began canceling sailings.
lead_paragraph: Cruise lines Royal Caribbean and Norwegian said on Wednesday that they will no longer sail to Cuba, joining Carnival Corporation, which announced earlier in the day that it will no longer operate cruises to the island, effective immediately.

headline: Elizabeth Warren and Bernie Sanders: Two Liberals Aiming for the Same Target
keywords: ['Liberalism (US Politics)', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: As Ms. Warren emerges from Mr. Sanders’s shadow, the two standard-bearers of the progressive base find themselves competing for voters, and donors.
lead_paragraph: LANSING, Mich. — When Elizabeth Warren took the stage at a rally Tuesday evening, she brought with her the kind of populist economic message that had roused working-class voters here during the presidential race three years ago.

headline: European Union Warns Italy to Reduce Spending and Borrowing
keywords: ['European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Politics and Government', 'Budgets and Budgeting', 'Euro (Currency)']
abstract: The warning by the European Commission was expected in the face of a populist government that intends to cut taxes and increase spending and despises Brussels.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — The European Union’s impatience with the populist government of Italy and its free-spending ways ratcheted up a notch on Wednesday, with Brussels warning that it would take legal action unless Italy reduces its budget deficits.

headline: Ohio Doctor Charged With Killing 25 Patients in Fentanyl Overdoses
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Opioids and Opiates', 'Doctors']
abstract: The authorities accused the doctor of deliberately prescribing fatal doses of the powerful opioid to critical-care patients. He pleaded not guilty.
lead_paragraph: In one of the largest murder cases in Ohio’s history, a doctor was charged on Wednesday with killing 25 people over four years by prescribing fatal doses of fentanyl, a powerful opioid, to critical-care patients at hospitals in and around Columbus.

headline: Bob Dylan’s Glam Hootenanny: Returning to Rolling Thunder
keywords: ['Pop and Rock Music', 'Documentary Films and Programs', 'Nineteen Hundred Seventies', 'Folk Music', 'Masks']
abstract: Dylan’s 1975 tour was his most peculiar: nostalgic, theatrical, fiery.
lead_paragraph: How distant the mid-1970s seem now. They were unkempt, hairy, hedonistic, improvisational, analog, inefficient — anything but neatly calculated and Instagram-ready. Post-psychedelic and pre-AIDS, they were a continuation of the idealistic, natural 1960s, yet they were also an immediate precursor to the polymorphous, synthetic, role-playing disco era. The bitterness of Vietnam and Watergate lingered; hippie utopianism was giving way to a more selfish search for individual satisfaction. Things were still scruffy, but not quite so communal.

headline: Biden Still Backs Hyde Amendment, Which Bans Federal Funds for Abortions
abstract: Joe Biden faced a backlash over his support for the measure, which advocates say disproportionately harms poor women and women of color.
lead_paragraph: Former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr., who has shunned today’s Democratic Party orthodoxy on issues from crime to compromising with Republicans, again broke with his party’s base and many of his campaign rivals on Wednesday when his campaign confirmed that he still backs the Hyde Amendment, a measure that prohibits the use of federal funds for abortion with exceptions for cases involving rape, incest and when the life of the mother is in danger.

headline: A Day of Rain Shuffles the Schedule at the French Open
abstract: The first rainout at Roland Garros in three years forced the postponement of the four quarterfinals in men’s and women’s singles before they began.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The French Open had its first rainout in three years on Wednesday, with daylong showers at Roland Garros forcing the postponement of the four scheduled quarterfinals in men’s and women’s singles before they began.

headline: The Age of the Internet ‘Wife Guy’
abstract: He’s not just a husband. The wife guy married a woman, and now that is his personality — perhaps even his job.
lead_paragraph: Two years ago, Robbie Tripp Instagrammed his wife. He posted a photograph of the pair embracing in swimwear in Miami and wrote, “I love this woman and her curvy body.” Then he detailed his journey toward feminism and body positivity, and his transformation into a man who can proudly post online: “This gorgeous girl I married fills out every inch of her jeans and is still the most beautiful one in the room.”

headline: A Merry Murderess Hangs Up Her ‘Chicago’ Fishnets
abstract: After more than 20 years in the musical, Donna Marie Asbury played her final Broadway performance this week.
lead_paragraph: The recently concluded FX mini-series “Fosse/Verdon” threw the private and public worlds of the choreographer Bob Fosse and his collaborator and third wife, Gwen Verdon, back into the spotlight.

headline: Thailand Junta Leader Named Prime Minister After Contentious Vote
abstract: Prayuth Chan-ocha, who once led a military coup, may find ruling more complicated now that he heads a multiparty government.
lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — The leader of the junta that seized power in Thailand five years ago, Prayuth Chan-ocha, was chosen by Parliament to be prime minister after an election marred by charges of manipulation.

headline: They Brought Us the Works That Shaped This Year’s Tony Nominees
abstract: A look at the men and women whose creations laid the foundations for shows like “Tootsie,” “The Cher Show” and “Network.”
lead_paragraph: Amid the songs, dances and celebrations, the Tony Awards ceremony on Sunday night will take a melancholy pause for the theater world people who have died in the past year. This time around, one of those will be the thrice-nominated Marin Mazzie, who died on Sept. 13 and will be granted a special Tony.

headline: Who Were the Ancestors of Native Americans? A Lost People in Siberia, Scientists Say
keywords: ['your-feed-science', 'Native Americans', 'Genealogy', 'Genetics and Heredity', 'DNA (Deoxyribonucleic Acid)', 'Skeletons', 'ARCHAEOLOGY AND ANTHROPOLOGY', 'Ice Age']
abstract: Genetic analysis of ancient teeth and bones suggests Native Americans largely descend from a vanished group called the Ancient Paleo-Siberians.
lead_paragraph: A skeleton in Siberia nearly 10,000 years old has yielded DNA that reveals a striking kinship to living Native Americans, scientists reported on Wednesday.

headline: Overlooked No More: Alan Turing, Condemned Code Breaker and Computer Visionary
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Cryptography, Codes and Ciphers', 'World War II (1939-45)', 'Mathematics', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Artificial Intelligence', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Biographical Information']
abstract: His ideas led to early versions of modern computing and helped win World War II. Yet he died as a criminal for his homosexuality.
lead_paragraph: Overlooked is a series of obituaries about remarkable people whose deaths, beginning in 1851, went unreported in The Times. This month we’re adding the stories of important L.G.B.T.Q. figures.

headline: A Nurse’s Perspective
keywords: ['Nursing and Nurses', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: A reader regrets the invisibility of nurses in the media, especially as health care is being discussed.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Wendy Red Star at the Newark Museum: A Powerful Portrait of the Crow Nation
abstract: Wrapping around the walls of the gallery, a timeline of photographs from a large annual festival turns public history into a personal narrative.
lead_paragraph: Western museums were built on a colonial foundation. One of the ways they reflect this is by presenting objects from certain cultures — African and Native American, among others — as the ethnographic remains of long-lost societies, rather than representative of living traditions. The Newark Museum began trying to break the mold in 2016 when it reconceived its Native American galleries. Now, the institution has taken another overdue step by mounting its first solo exhibition dedicated to a Native artist: a fantastic midcareer survey for Wendy Red Star.

headline: Trump Administration Sharply Curtails Fetal Tissue Medical Research
keywords: ['Fetal Tissue', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Research', 'ABORTION', 'Federal Budget (US)']
abstract: The Trump administration will be ending a major university contract involving fetal tissue research and will soon stop such work at the National Institutes of Health.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration announced Wednesday that the federal government would sharply curtail federal spending on medical research that uses tissue from aborted fetuses, mainly by ending fetal-tissue research within the National Institutes of Health.

headline: Ojai Will Never Be the Same, Thanks to His Musical Imagination
abstract: Thomas W. Morris, the artistic director of the Ojai Music Festival, is leaving after an acclaimed and influential run of 16 years.
lead_paragraph: OJAI, Calif. — On Tuesday afternoon, Thomas W. Morris, the artistic director of the Ojai Music Festival, went to church.

headline: Swastikas and Burning Pride Flags: Hate Crimes Spike in N.Y.
abstract: Even as crime has fallen overall, the sharp increase in bias incidents and vandalism has unsettled a city known for its multicultural fabric and tolerance.
lead_paragraph: In Staten Island, the phrase “Synagogue of Satan” was spray painted on a wall outside of a Jewish school. In Brooklyn, a pro-Hitler message was scrawled on a poster outside a Jewish children’s museum whose mission is to fight anti-Semitism. In Manhattan, two rainbow pride flags were set on fire outside of a gay bar.

headline: The Many Ways I Cover America’s Most Diverse Generation
abstract: I’m on the National section’s youth beat, which entails often delicate or difficult — and surprising and rewarding — reporting on those under 30.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

headline: Impeaching Trump: A Moral Imperative, or Pointless?
abstract: Like the Democrats, readers are divided over whether the party should move ahead with impeachment.

headline: An American Family Detained in Syria Is Sent Back to the U.S.
abstract: Kurdish authorities are releasing some of the 12,000 foreign women and children affiliated with the Islamic State held in detention camps in Syria.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Two American women and six children affiliated with the Islamic State have been sent back to the United States from Syria at the request of the American authorities, American officials and local forces in northeastern Syria said Wednesday.

headline: Can the Paris Climate Goals Save Lives? Yes, a Lot of Them, Researchers Say
abstract: A new study projects how many additional deaths could occur in 15 American cities if the world misses its targets for taming climate change.
lead_paragraph: Summertime heat is forecast to become even deadlier without action to drastically reduce the greenhouse gas emissions that cause climate change, according to a new study.

headline: A Day at Queens Farm (and the Restaurants You Should Dig Into Afterward)
abstract: Get in the (literal) weeds on New York City’s largest working farmland, then reward your hard work with some of the city’s finest South Asian food.
lead_paragraph: You’re reading Summer in the City, our limited-edition newsletter that rounds up the best things to do in New York City during the hottest season of the year. Sign up here to get future editions delivered to your inbox.

headline: A Hotel Bar With a (Gay) Twist
abstract: No Bar, which caters to a young queer crowd, opened a few months ago at the Standard hotel in the East Village.
lead_paragraph: Hotel bars may be as ubiquitous as A.T.M.s these days, but how many cater specifically to queer patrons? No Bar, which opened in February at the Standard hotel in the East Village, is one. In addition to the usual gay bar trappings (“RuPaul’s Drag Race” viewing party and bingo night), it also hosts speed dating and a Wednesday lesbian night called “Slather!”

headline: Their Fathers Never Spoke of the War. Their Children Want to Know Why.
keywords: ['Veterans', 'World War II (1939-45)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Archives and Records', 'Research', 'Museums', 'Families and Family Life']
abstract: Seventy-five years after D-Day, families of World War II veterans are turning to professional researchers to piece their stories together from military records.
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — All his life, Joseph Griesser hungered to hear the story of his father’s Army service in World War II.

headline: Hail Bach, and Farewell
abstract: Watch Laura Halzack, who is retiring soon, dance part of her playful solo from Paul Taylor’s radiant “Brandenburgs.”
lead_paragraph: #SpeakingInDance is a weekly visual exploration of dance on Instagram. Watch the video from our most recent post below, and follow us at @nytimes.

headline: Review: The More, Further (Final?) ‘Tales of the City’
abstract: Netflix gives Armistead Maupin’s modern-day fable of San Francisco lives and lifestyles a fourth go-round.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to “Tales of the City,” the nostalgia just keeps compounding. The original television mini-series was already a wistful evocation of a disappearing San Francisco. And even as it played on PBS in early 1994, the internet was slouching into existence down the peninsula. With Netflix offering a new, 10-episode installment — a contemporary sequel, and the fourth series based on Armistead Maupin’s novels — both the first series, and the late-bohemian 1970s San Francisco it depicted, seem lost in the fog of time.

headline: The Spirit of 1994 Is Alive and Well in Aimé Leon Dore
abstract: Heritage brands are usually in the business of looking way back. Do the mid-’90s count?
lead_paragraph: Generally, long before a clothing company makes history of its own, it channels history.

headline: A Hip-Hop Reunion for Gordon Parks
abstract: And the premiere of Netflix’s update of “Tales of the City” in New York.
lead_paragraph: And the premiere of Netflix’s update of “Tales of the City” in New York.

headline: Parks and Re-Creation
abstract: Hip-hop royalty celebrates Gordon Parks. “Tales of the City” reinvents itself a fourth time.
lead_paragraph: Cipriani 42nd Street, an Italianate former bank turned banquet hall, became an unlikely temple of old-school hip-hop on Tuesday night, at the Gordon Parks Foundation’s annual gala.

headline: Jenny Slate Will Give a Graduation Speech to a Class of One
abstract: The stand-up comic and “Parks and Recreation” actress will speak at the eighth-grade graduation of Gwen Lynch, 13, the last student on Cuttyhunk Island.
lead_paragraph: On Cuttyhunk Island, a tiny place just off Cape Cod, the only graduating eighth grader, Gwen Lynch, is the talk of the town.

headline: ‘The Secret Life of Pets 2’ Review: Funny, Furry and Forgettable
abstract: Some clever gags redeem this otherwise meandering sequel.
lead_paragraph: Too scattered narratively to cohere, and yet somehow still funny enough to justify its existence, “The Secret Life of Pets 2” makes for an entertaining trifle. In this sequel to the 2016 animated hit — which followed the misadventures of some Manhattan pets while their owners were at work — our protagonist Max (voiced by Patton Oswalt, taking over from Louis CK, who fell from favor after revelations of sexual misconduct) visits a farm where he has to tap into his more animalistic, confident side under the tutelage of a grizzled sheepdog named Rooster (voiced by a surprisingly engaged-sounding Harrison Ford).

headline: Mexico Has Tried to Avoid Trump. It Can’t Anymore.
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Customs (Tariff)']
abstract: President López Obrador has few cards to play. But any alternative is preferable to continuing to kowtow to Washington.
lead_paragraph: Last week President Trump said that beginning on June 10 the United States will impose a 5 percent tariff, which would gradually increase, on all goods coming from Mexico.

headline: How D-Day Is Defined By Movie-Laced Memories
abstract: War films may have been only “based on a true story.” But they did justice to the essential truth of what happened on the ground.
lead_paragraph: The stoicism of World War II veterans, their reluctance to share their war stories, even with those closest to them, has long been something of a cliché. Members of the “greatest generation,” as we call it, have always been terse about the seminal moments that earned them the title.

headline: Terese Hayden, Whose Guide Helped Actors Get Cast, Dies at 98
abstract: A struggling performer herself, she began publishing The Players’ Guide, a compendium of names, photographs, credits and phone numbers, in 1944.
lead_paragraph: Terese Hayden, whose Players’ Guide directory of job-seeking actors helped begin, sustain and revive the careers of generations of performers, died on May 23 at her home in Manhattan. She was 98.

headline: Putin Aims to Revive the Economy With a Plan. And Pianos.
abstract: As Russian officials unveil a spending plan aimed at doubling growth in its troubled economy, critics see a $400 billion effort in Soviet-era planning.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Even as Russia has muscled back onto the world stage politically, its economy suffers from flat growth and shrinking incomes.

headline: Republicans Against Tariffs
abstract: A reader points out that Senate Republicans seem to find their voice only when their pocketbooks are hurt.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Where a Miracle Substance Called Breast Milk Saves Lives
keywords: ['Breastfeeding', 'Women and Girls', 'Malnutrition', 'Third World and Developing Countries']
abstract: How breast-feeding transforms the lives of malnourished children in Guatemala and around the world.
lead_paragraph: CHICHALUM, Guatemala — Painted on the side of a health post in this rural town in Guatemala’s western highlands is a simple message: Breast-feeding is a lifelong gift.

headline: ‘Kids Need a Good Start’: Readers Debate Admissions at Elite N.Y.C. Schools
abstract: The drop in black and Hispanic student admissions to New York’s specialized high schools led to an impassioned discussion among readers with personal experiences at them.
lead_paragraph: The number of black and Hispanic students at New York City’s elite public high schools has declined significantly in the past four decades, leading to debates throughout the five boroughs and beyond about how to reverse the trend.

headline: I Want to Live in Elizabeth Warren’s America
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The Massachusetts senator is proposing something radical: a country in which adults discuss serious ideas seriously.
lead_paragraph: It’s early, but this much is true: Elizabeth Warren is running the most impressive presidential campaign in ages, certainly the most impressive campaign within my lifetime.

headline: ‘Late Night’ Review: Emma Thompson Takes On the Old Boys of Network TV
abstract: Mindy Kaling wrote and co-stars in a sharp and sincere comedy about sexism in broadcasting in the era of #MeToo and social media.
lead_paragraph: Katherine Newbury, the broadcasting legend played by Emma Thompson in “Late Night,” is the first-ever, longest-running female host of a post-primetime network talk show. A onetime peer and rival of Leno and Letterman, she has outlasted them, surviving into the era of Fallon and Colbert. Some of those names are dropped (and Seth Meyers shows up for a cameo), but Katherine is of course a fictional character. You might even say she’s like a sparkly unicorn or a city-crushing kaiju — a wholly fantastical creature.

headline: S.E.C. Adopts New Broker Rules That Consumer Advocates Say Are Toothless
keywords: ['Financial Planners', 'Consumer Protection', 'Financial Brokers', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Conflicts of Interest']
abstract: The commission said it was tightening standards. The advocates said the move would give customers a false sense of security.
lead_paragraph: Regulators have new rules for Wall Street brokers providing investment advice: Act in your customers’ best interest. But consumer advocates argue that the rules amount to little more than a new marketing slogan.

headline: Naomi Wolf’s Career of Blunders Continues in ‘Outrages’
abstract: Wolf’s study of the criminalization of same-sex relationships in the Victorian era grew out of her doctoral dissertation on the poet John Addington Symonds.
lead_paragraph: Naomi Wolf’s long, ludicrous career has followed a simple formula. She audits herself for some speck of dissatisfaction, arrives at an epiphany — one that might contravene any number of natural laws — and then extrapolates a set of rules and recommendations for all women. Predictable controversy ensues; grouchy reviews and much attention. Over the years her batty claims have included that a woman’s brain can allow her to become pregnant if she so desires, even if she is using birth control; that women’s intellects and creativity are dependent on their sexual fulfillment and, specifically, the skillful ministrations of a “virile man”; and that writing a letter to a breech baby will induce it to turn right side up.

headline: How China Tariffs Could Make Your Sweaters and Pants Cost More
keywords: ['Shopping and Retail', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Customs (Tariff)', 'International Trade and World Market', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: An array of added expenses may be passed on to consumers once the new trade policies are enacted.
lead_paragraph: The Trump administration’s threat to impose new tariffs on nearly everything that comes to the United States from China has sent American retailers scrambling. Many rely on China for some portion of their manufacturing, and the new tariffs — as much as 25 percent on the roughly $300 billion worth of goods that so far have been untouched by the trade war — could force the companies to change where and how they make their products.

headline: Review: A Grim Balletic Account of ‘Jane Eyre’
abstract: Cathy Marston’s telling, at American Ballet Theater, takes an admirable feminist stance, but is undone by monotonous choreography.
lead_paragraph: “Women are supposed to be very calm generally,” Charlotte Brontë wrote in “Jane Eyre,” her 1847 novel, “but women feel just as men feel; they need exercise for their faculties, and a field for their efforts.”

headline: D-Day, Mexico, Madonna: Your Thursday Briefing
abstract: Remembering D-Day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: The ‘It Books’ of Summers Past
abstract: We’ve revisited the books that defined the season over the past 50 years — and what they reveal about the country at a particular moment.
lead_paragraph: Think back to the summer of 2012. No matter where you went — the beach, the pool, the park — you saw the same book dotting beach towels and peeking out of bags and backpacks. Clad in a sleek black jacket, its title and author a slash of blood-red ink, Gillian Flynn’s ‘‘Gone Girl’’ was in the very ether, what everyone was reading and everyone was talking about: the ‘‘it’’ book of summer.

headline: Tech Giants Amass a Lobbying Army for an Epic Washington Battle
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Lobbying and Lobbyists', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Social Media', 'Corporations']
abstract: Amazon, Apple, Facebook and Google, facing the growing possibility of antitrust action and legislation to rein in their power, are spending freely to gain influence and access.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Faced with the growing possibility of antitrust actions and legislation to curb their power, four of the biggest technology companies are amassing an army of lobbyists as they prepare for what could be an epic fight over their futures.

headline: Tony Glover, Master of the Blues Harmonica, Is Dead at 79
abstract: With his fellow blues aficionados John Koerner and Dave Ray, Mr. Glover played an important role in the folk music revival of the 1960s.
lead_paragraph: Tony Glover, a harmonica player who as a member of the group Koerner, Ray and Glover was at the center of the folk music revival of the 1960s and helped introduce a new audience to the blues, died on May 29 in a hospital in St. Paul. He was 79.

headline: Patricia Battin, Lightning Rod in a Library War, Dies at 89
keywords: ['Libraries and Librarians', 'Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: A leading librarian who championed high tech, she dueled with preservationists like Nicholson Baker over how best to protect the written word for posterity.
lead_paragraph: Patricia Battin was a librarian who well knew the clutter and chaos of big institutional libraries that never threw anything away.

headline: Semyon Rozenfeld, Last Known Survivor of Death Camp Escape, Dies at 96
keywords: ['Prison Escapes', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'World War II (1939-45)', 'Deaths (Obituaries)']
abstract: Mr. Rozenfeld escaped the Sobibor camp in Poland in 1943 along with about 300 other prisoners. He was among fewer than 60 who survived the war.
lead_paragraph: Semyon Rozenfeld first escaped death in the gas chambers by inventing a trade for himself when he arrived at Sobibor, a Nazi death camp in occupied Poland, in the fall of 1943. Questioned by a German officer, he said he was a glazier and was taken aside for work detail.

headline: Migrant Children May Lose School, Sports and Legal Aid as Shelters Swell
keywords: ['Illegal Immigration', 'Children and Childhood', 'Legal Aid for the Poor (Civil)', 'Family Separation Policy (US Immigration)', 'Education (K-12)']
abstract: Citing financial constraints, the administration said it would begin restricting or canceling education, legal and recreational services for migrant children housed in shelters.
lead_paragraph: The Trump administration said Wednesday that it would begin restricting or canceling education, legal aid and playground recreation for migrant children housed in government shelters as a result of financial constraints created by the “crisis at the border.”

headline: The Making of ‘1984,’ George Orwell’s Nightmare Vision of a World Without Truth
abstract: “The Ministry of Truth,” by Dorian Lynskey, is a “biography” of the 1949 novel, an enduring icon of state power devoid of moral principle and human concern.

headline: Uber Copter to Offer Flights From Lower Manhattan to J.F.K.
abstract: For an 8-minute, one-way flight, the average ride will cost between $200 and $225 per person and include private ground transportation on both ends of the trip.
lead_paragraph: When Uber announced an aerial ride-hailing division, Uber Elevate, three years ago, the internet and news media buzzed with chatter of flying cars becoming a reality in the not-so-distant future.

headline: What a ‘Living Wage’ Actually Means
keywords: ['Living Wage', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Minimum Wage', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Poverty']
abstract: If you ask a dozen lawmakers what constitutes a “living wage,” you’ll get a dozen answers. Where does the term come from? And is it even accurate?
lead_paragraph: The term “living wage” gets thrown around enough by politicians and advocacy groups that the definition can get muddy. The legal minimum wage in the United States is $7.25 per hour, though some states and cities like New York City and Seattle are experimenting with minimums as high as $15 an hour. But are these wages enough to live on? And what is a living wage, anyway?

headline: ‘The Handmaid’s Tale’ Wants to Be More Than TV Medicine
abstract: Bruce Miller, the showrunner for Hulu’s adaptation of the dystopian novel by Margaret Atwood, discusses how he wanted Season 3 to be entertaining above all else.
lead_paragraph: What do you do when reality starts looking uncomfortably like your dystopian fiction?

headline: In China, a Viral Video Sets Off a Challenge to Rape Culture
keywords: ['#MeToo Movement', 'Sex Crimes', 'Sexual Harassment', 'Politics and Government', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming']
abstract: The images were meant to exonerate Richard Liu, the e-commerce mogul. They have also helped fuel a nascent #NoPerfectVictim movement.
lead_paragraph: Richard Liu, the Chinese e-commerce billionaire, walked into an apartment building around 10 p.m., a young woman on his arm and his assistant in tow. Leaving the assistant behind, the young woman took Mr. Liu to an elevator. Then, she showed him into her apartment.

keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'Customs (Tariff)', 'Immigration and Emigration']
abstract: Tariffs on Mexican imports will ripple across the United States and could cause significant pain for consumers and businesses, even those far from the southwestern border.

keywords: ['Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'United States Economy', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Customs (Tariff)', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Prices have dropped more than 20 percent since late April as investors worry that growth is slowing and trade disputes could slow growth further.
lead_paragraph: A couple of months ago, the bulls ran the oil markets. Now the bears have taken over.

keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'Weather', 'Agriculture and Farming', 'Politics and Government']
abstract: A stark choice for some Guatemalans: watch crops wither, and maybe die with them, or migrate.
lead_paragraph: NENTÓN, Guatemala — To understand why President Trump’s new sanctions and other flailing to end Central American immigration aren’t working, step into the dark, melancholy hovel of Ana Jorge Jorge.

headline: Trump Sets Off Fireworks of a Different Sort With Fourth of July Speech Plan
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Independence Day (US) (July 4)', 'Fireworks', 'Parades', 'Speeches and Statements', 'Monuments and Memorials (Structures)']
abstract: The mayor’s office confirmed that the president intends to speak from the Lincoln Memorial, prompting criticism that he is politicizing a nonpartisan celebration.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Since early in his tenure, President Trump has sought to stage a military parade through the heart of Washington, only to be thwarted. So now he has settled on the next best thing: He will take over an existing patriotic display in the capital.

headline: On Trump’s Ireland Visit, Talk of Brexit and Border Walls
abstract: President Trump predicted that Brexit would be good for Ireland “with your wall, your border.” Ireland’s prime minister replied that the country wanted to avoid “a wall or border” with Britain.
lead_paragraph: SHANNON, Ireland — President Trump reassured Ireland’s prime minister, Leo Varadkar, on Wednesday that Britain’s exit from the European Union would “work out very well,” including for Ireland, “with your wall, your border.”

headline: Murray Polner, Antiwar Editor and Author, Is Dead at 91
keywords: ['Jews and Judaism', 'Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Politics and Government', 'Deaths (Obituaries)']
abstract: An outspoken pacifist, Mr. Polner founded the progressive public affairs journal Present Tense in 1973 and was its only editor until it closed in 1990.
lead_paragraph: Murray Polner, an unswerving voice for pacifism and civil liberties and the founder and only editor of Present Tense magazine, a progressive counterpoint to Commentary that began in a period of one-upmanship among Jewish intellectuals, died on May 30 in Manhasset, N.Y. He was 91.

headline: The Fading Chords of Memory of D-Day
keywords: ['World War II (1939-45)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: An ever-dwindling band of witnesses, including Queen Elizabeth II, mark the 75th anniversary of that momentous day.
lead_paragraph: At each year’s commemorations of D-Day, there will be a dwindling number of survivors like 95-year-old Harry Read and 94-year-old John Hutton, former British paratroopers who jumped with the British Parachute Regiment team on Wednesday to land in Sannerville, France, as they had 75 years ago.

headline: Let’s Ditch Mitch
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: The Senate majority leader comes out of his shell.
lead_paragraph: O.K., throwing this one at you without warning: What’s your opinion of Mitch McConnell?

headline: Fiat Chrysler Withdraws Its Offer for Renault
abstract: The plan had faced resistance by some Renault shareholders who argued that the Italian-American conglomerate was undervaluing a crown jewel of French industry.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Fiat Chrysler late Wednesday abruptly withdrew its proposal to merge with Renault, walking away from a deal that could have fundamentally reshaped the global auto industry.

headline: Insys, the Opioid Drug Maker, to Pay $225 Million to Settle Fraud Charges
keywords: ['Opioids and Opiates', 'Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'your-feed-healthcare', 'Fines (Penalties)']
abstract: Federal prosecutors accused the company of illegally marketing its powerful fentanyl painkiller and of defrauding government health care programs.
lead_paragraph: The opioid manufacturer Insys Therapeutics agreed to pay $225 million to settle federal criminal and civil charges that it illegally marketed a highly addictive fentanyl painkiller to doctors, federal prosecutors said on Wednesday.

headline: Analyzing Elizabeth Warren’s MSNBC Town Hall
abstract: We watched live as Senator Elizabeth Warren took questions from voters in Fort Wayne, Ind., a day after she unveiled her $2 trillion plan for “economic patriotism.”
lead_paragraph: We watched live as Senator Elizabeth Warren took questions from voters in Fort Wayne, Ind., a day after she unveiled her $2 trillion plan for “economic patriotism.”

headline: A Chance for ‘Dreamers’
keywords: ['Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals', 'Dream Act (Development, Relief and Education for Minors Act)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Law and Legislation', 'Illegal Immigration']
abstract: Congress should do its job and pass a bill to protect immigrants brought to the United States as children.
lead_paragraph: In 2017, Donald Trump ended the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals program, or DACA — the Obama administration program that granted a reprieve from deportation to many Dreamers, immigrants who were brought to the United States illegally as children. At the time, the president issued a challenge on Twitter: “Congress, get ready to do your job.”

headline: Elizabeth Warren, on MSNBC, Calls Hyde Amendment an Assault on the ‘Most Vulnerable’ Women
abstract: Ms. Warren sharply criticized Joe Biden for supporting the measure, drawing an explicit link between abortion rights and economic inequality.
lead_paragraph: Senator Elizabeth Warren of Massachusetts, slowly gaining ground in the crowded Democratic presidential primary, appeared on MSNBC on Wednesday for a friendly town-hall event, which gave her ample opportunity to describe her signature policies and deliver some of her most reliable applause lines.

headline: An Orwellian Tale? Trump Denies, Then Confirms, ‘Nasty’ Comments About Meghan Markle
abstract: The president’s comments about the Duchess of Sussex continued an Orwellian saga that he single-handedly created, forcefully denied and then revived.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — By the time he left London on Wednesday, President Trump somehow ended his state visit there a full 360 degrees from where he started. Which was referring to the Duchess of Sussex, the American-born Meghan Markle, as “nasty.”

headline: On the Border, Police Chase Smugglers. The Migrant Body Count Is Getting Higher.
abstract: Six migrants were found dead Wednesday after the latest in a series of deadly crashes involving police chases in South Texas.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — A vehicle packed with undocumented migrants crashed in rural South Texas after it was chased by police, veering into a ditch in rainy weather and killing six people who were found Wednesday morning — the latest in a series of deadly crashes involving immigrants near the border.

headline: It’s All Rooted in White Panic
keywords: ['Race and Ethnicity', 'Whites', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Population']
abstract: Attempts to hold back inevitable shifts in American power are behind Trump’s politics.
lead_paragraph: Every so often it’s important to step back from the freak show of the moment so that you can see the whole circle. That has never been more important than at this moment and under this administration.

headline: North Carolina Legislature Fails to Overturn Governor’s Veto of Anti-Abortion Bill
abstract: The bill would have criminally charged doctors and nurses for neglecting to care for a fetus that survived an abortion.
lead_paragraph: In a rare defeat for anti-abortion activists in the South, North Carolina Republicans failed on Wednesday to overturn a veto of a bill that would have made it a crime to not treat “any infant born alive after an abortion.”

headline: We Expect Police to Be Brave For Us. But What Happens When They’re Not?
keywords: ['School Shootings and Armed Attacks', 'Parkland, Fla, Shooting (2018)', 'Fear (Emotion)', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Police']
abstract: Courage has long been part of the job description. But that doesn’t just mean running toward gunshots.
lead_paragraph: When Lt. Craig Cardinale got to Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School as a mass shooting was unfolding last year, he found Deputy Scot Peterson pacing outside, repeating, “Oh, my God. Oh, my God.”

headline: How the Raptors Won Game 3 of the N.B.A. Finals
abstract: Stephen Curry gave it his best shot, but he couldn’t carry the Golden State Warriors over Toronto in Game 3.
lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — The Golden State Warriors absorbed a blow on Wednesday night before a shot was even attempted. Coach Steve Kerr, prioritizing caution, decided before Game 3 of the N.B.A. finals that Klay Thompson would not play because of a strained left hamstring.

headline: Yankees’ J.A. Happ Wrestles With Being a Fly-Ball Pitcher in a Home-Run Era
abstract: Happ has thrived on inducing fly balls over his 13-year career, but that tendency has become hazardous as baseballs fly farther and farther.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — Through most of his 13-year major league career, J.A. Happ has made a living inducing fly balls. They account for nearly 40 percent of his pitches that hitters put in play, which ranks him fifth among pitchers with at least 1,500 innings since 2009.

headline: The Donald Thinks D-Day Is About Him
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'World War II (1939-45)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: To have Trump commemorate the Normandy landings is to understand the word impostor.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — How small he is! Small in spirit, in valor, in dignity, in statecraft, this American president who knows nothing of history and cares still less and now bestrides Europe with his family in tow like some tin-pot dictator with a terrified entourage.

headline: There Was a Time
abstract: Fred Piscop returns to remind us of a pivotal day in history.
lead_paragraph: THURSDAY PUZZLE — June 6 is the 75th anniversary of a very important day in world and military history, and our Split Decisions puzzle constructor, Fred Piscop, is back in the crossword rotation with a commemorative puzzle.

headline: Corrections: June 6, 2019
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Thursday, June 6, 2019.

headline: Quotation of the Day: ‘Archaeology of D-Day’ Aims to Preserve History
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, June 6, 2019.
lead_paragraph: “We had a rotten job to do, and we did it. You really didn’t think about what you were doing. You were just trying to stay alive.”

headline: Amid Boston Pride Week, ‘Straight Pride Parade’ Draws Attention
abstract: The parade, proposed by three men for late August, has yet to receive a permit from Boston officials. The proposal’s real intent seemed unclear.
lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — As Boston celebrated Pride Week, an annual event honoring the L.G.B.T. rights movement that culminates in a parade, another event was drawing a flurry of attention on social media: a “Straight Pride Parade” that several men say they plan to hold in the city in late August.

headline: These Girls’ Soccer Players Joined Boys’ Leagues. And Dominated.

headline: France’s Men Won the World Cup Last Summer. Its Women Want a Title to Match.
abstract: “We have seen so many emotions in the country last year,” the French captain said. “We want to experience something similar.”
lead_paragraph: ORLÉANS, France — The first Women’s World Cup on French soil was only days away, and Delphine Cascarino, a 22-year-old French wing with the speed and dribbling skills to become a breakout star over the next month, was about to exit the cozy stadium in Orléans where the French team had beaten Thailand, 3-0, in a friendly match. But first she had one last stop to make: A group of about 200 fans, mostly young girls, was waiting for Cascarino and her teammates outside for autographs and pictures.

headline: What’s on TV Thursday: ‘The Cold Blue’ and D-Day Stories
abstract: A World War II documentary debuts on HBO. And two movies about the disorienting horror of D-Day air on the event’s 75th anniversary.
lead_paragraph: THE COLD BLUE 8 p.m. on HBO. World War II was still raging when “The Memphis Belle,” William Wyler’s documentary about the crew of an American bomber, was released in 1944. That government-produced film made for a “thorough and vivid comprehension of what a daylight bombing is actually like for the young men who wing our heavy bombers from English bases into the heart of Germany,” Bosley Crowther wrote in The New York Times that year. To shoot it, cinematographers (including Wyler) flew on bombing missions; one of them, a first lieutenant named Harold J. Tannenbaum, was killed in the process. Restored footage shot for “The Memphis Belle” has been arranged by the director Erik Nelson for “The Cold Blue,” a new documentary, which uses Wyler’s material to give an intimate sense of what life was like in a World War II bomber. “It was more or less like being in death row in a penitentiary waiting on your turn,” one veteran says in a voice-over. “And you knew it was coming.”

headline: On Politics: Border Arrests at 7-Year High
abstract: More than 144,200 migrants were arrested and taken into custody along the southwestern border in May, a 32 percent increase from April.

headline: Are Rechargeable Batteries Better Than Alkaline? Most of the Time
abstract: In some cases, single-use batteries are still the better option.
lead_paragraph: Many of my favorite things as a child — like my Walkman, for example — required AA or AAA batteries. Batteries back then weren’t always reliable. Sometimes I’d flip open the battery slot of a rarely used toy to find a crusty, whitish discharge from a leaky AA inside, or I’d leave the ’90s-era rechargeable batteries juicing up on a bulky charger for an entire day only to have them die after just a few hours of use.

headline: German Nurse Convicted of Killing 85 Patients
keywords: ['Serial Murders', 'Nursing and Nurses', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: Officials suspect Niels Högel may have killed as many as 300 patients while working at two clinics in northern Germany between 2000 and 2005.
lead_paragraph: OLDENBURG, Germany — The former nurse’s crimes were “incomprehensible,” a German judge told the court on Thursday, reaching his arms across the breadth of the bench as if to capture in one gesture what he sensed his words had failed to define — the enormity of murdering 85 patients who had been placed in the care of the nurse but instead had found death.

headline: Poem: The Boys of Summer
abstract: You don’t have to be a baseball enthusiast to feel the spritz of hope, luck and determination our national pastime engenders in this poem.
lead_paragraph: You don’t have to be a baseball enthusiast to feel the spritz of hope, luck and determination our national pastime engenders in E. Ethelbert Miller, who has written a book’s worth of poems in honor of the game. For the autograph-seeking black kids in this poem, life is still a line drive, and all ball players are created equal; ninth-inning defeats and freedom riders are yet to come. Their mothers, knowing better, offer what haven they can — and tuck a note of caution into their stories of uplift.

headline: Are These Teenagers Really Running a Presidential Campaign? Yes. (Maybe.)
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Social Media', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The retired senator Mike Gravel gave two young fans his Twitter password and permission to campaign in his name. It might be a stunt — or the future of politics.
lead_paragraph: Zach Montellaro, a Politico reporter, reads the Federal Election Commission website like a tabloid. He not only trawls the big, dry database in which presidential candidates register to run; he also reads several smaller aftermarket ones that reformat the filings from the first. On Twitter, he follows F.E.C. bots that tweet out campaign filings as they post. On the night of March 19, he was up late when one such tweet, from @CATargetBot, crossed his feed: “NEW FEC F1 #POTUS Mike Gravel for President Exploratory Committee.”

headline: Have App, Will Travel Like a Local. Hopefully.
abstract: The push to get travelers to book tours and activities through mobile apps and websites has never been more vigorous.
lead_paragraph: While on their honeymoon in Hoi An in central Vietnam last month, Sharadhi Gadagkar and Kunal Patel didn’t bother a hotel concierge with questions about things to do. Instead, the couple signed up for their first Airbnb experience, a tour organized by SecretEATS, during which they hit five locations serving original cocktails, including a spiked iced coffee in the wood-planked loft of a designer boutique. It was a perfectly tipsy three hours with two other guests and two guides.

lead_paragraph: The women in these photographs are all serving prison sentences of 18 years or more to life for homicide. For Sara Bennett, the photographer, this fact is just the beginning of their stories, not the end.

headline: Shannon Watts’s Work Diary: The Demanding Job of Running ‘Moms Demand Action’
keywords: ['Gun Control', 'Newtown, Conn, Shooting (2012)', 'School Shootings and Armed Attacks', 'Law and Legislation', 'Workplace Environment']
abstract: One of the most prominent gun-control organizations in the United States got its start at her kitchen table. Now she crisscrosses the country pushing for change.
lead_paragraph: Shannon Watts was a consultant and stay-at-home mother of five in Zionsville, Ind., with maybe 75 Facebook friends when a gunman walked into the Sandy Hook Elementary School in Connecticut in December 2012 and fatally shot 20 children. Ms. Watts sat down at her kitchen table trying to find something similar to Mothers Against Drunk Driving, i.e. a nonpartisan, mom-led advocacy group to protect kids from gun violence. She didn’t find one, so instead wrote a screed on Facebook that eventually became a group called Moms Demand Action for Gun Sense in America.

headline: Hootie & the Blowfish, Great American Rock Band (Yes, Really)
abstract: Twenty-five years after the group’s pop supernova “Cracked Rear View,” it’s time for a reassessment.
lead_paragraph: Hootie & the Blowfish remember all the slights.

headline: 36 Hours in Majorca
abstract: There’s a quieter side to this breezy island off the coast of mainland Spain. So add mountain villages and inland drives to your to-do list.
lead_paragraph: Northern Europeans love Majorca, the breezy Balearic island about 125 miles off the coast of mainland Spain. An easy weekend getaway for sun-seeking Brits, Germans and Scandinavians, the Mediterranean island and its capital, Palma, are sometimes derided as a cheap package-tour destination for hard-partying holidaymakers. And in July and August — the height of the summer season — this is certainly true. But the rest of the year, you’re as likely to hear accented English as Mallorquí, the local dialect of Catalan. So wander the warren of narrow stone alleyways in Palma’s medieval center, drive inland to explore ancient olive groves and rural mountain villages, and along the way, discover another side of this surprising, sun-baked island.

headline: The Revered Crocodiles of This Island Nation Have Suddenly Started Killing People
abstract: Two scientists traveled to East Timor to help solve a national murder mystery. The culprits, they say, might be migrants from Australia with a taste for blood.
lead_paragraph: LOSPALOS, East Timor — The two scientists, crammed in the back of a sweltering car, had come a long way hoping to encounter what most people try to avoid: man-eating crocodiles.

headline: A French Festival Where the Actor Is King
abstract: The Printemps des Comédiens festival features productions uniquely crafted for, and occasionally by, their performers.
lead_paragraph: MONTPELLIER, France — The director is widely considered king in French theater, and is often a bigger name than anyone onstage.  At the Printemps des Comédiens, however, it’s the actors who are in the headline: The name of this festival, first held here in 1987, translates as “Actors’ Spring.” This year’s opening weekend brought uneven productions uniquely crafted for — and occasionally by — their performers.

headline: Who Cares About the Supreme Court’s ‘Legitimacy’?

abstract: Conservatives seem to assume that only the chief justice is moved by fears that he and his colleagues will end up looking like politicians in robes.
lead_paragraph: In a rational world, the Supreme Court would hit the pause button on the pending census case to take account of new evidence that the Trump administration’s stated reason for adding a citizenship question was a fiction that masked its flagrantly partisan motive. True, the case is to be decided within weeks, to meet what the Commerce Department says is the deadline for preparing the 2020 census, but the country will live for years with the impact of the census on political redistricting and the allocation of federal money.

headline: ‘I Am a Problem There Is No Solution To’
abstract: Lessons from a pair of ravaged hands.
lead_paragraph: It was the news of my best friend’s engagement that set me to thinking about it this time. A picture like many others of its kind, a hand with a beautiful sparkling ring, except this hand belonged to someone I love, so I admired it a little longer and thought about it more. It’s a picture I know I’ll never take if I become engaged myself because of what my hands look like, because of what I’ve done to them.

headline: ‘16 Shots’ Review: Chicago’s Rage After a Killing by the Police
keywords: ['Documentary Films and Programs', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Blacks', 'Black People']
abstract: The documentary recounts the shooting of Laquan McDonald and the resulting trial of Jason Van Dyke.
lead_paragraph: Voices are rarely raised in “16 Shots.” But you can feel anger coursing through this film, and it says far more than loud words could.

headline: ‘Funan’ Review: An Unflinching, Animated Story of Survival
abstract: Denis Do tells a grim tale of captivity and oppression in 1970s Cambodia.
lead_paragraph: In 1988, the Japanese director Isao Takahata broke new ground in animation with “Grave of the Fireflies,” an almost unbearably grim story of children in a devastated post-World War II Kobe. That picture used the medium of animation not just to depict the deprivation and suffering of its young characters, but also to show their memories and the better world they imagine.

headline: ‘Papi Chulo’ Review: Another White Person Goes on a Journey
abstract: A lonely weatherman hires a day laborer to be his pal in John Butler’s racially naïve buddy comedy.
lead_paragraph: “Papi Chulo,” a buddy comedy set in Los Angeles that rests on outdated racial tropes, begins with the meltdown of Sean (Matt Bomer), a local weatherman. Newly single, he unravels into sobs live on camera, leading his news station to encourage him to take a leave.

headline: ‘This One’s for the Ladies’ Review: Stripping to Pay the Bills
abstract: Gene Graham’s documentary portrays male exotic dancers as hard-working performers, and their clients as looking for escape.
lead_paragraph: “This One’s for the Ladies,” which exposes the private lives of male exotic dancers, is a rare documentary to be released with an NC-17 rating — a classification that, in this instance, seems as much about marketing as anything else. The whole point of the film is to desexualize stripping: to show it as a job, its practitioners as hard-working performers and their clients as looking for escape.

headline: ‘Ghost Fleet’ Review: A Quest to End Slavery at Sea
abstract: Unwitting migrants are tricked into lives of bondage aboard fishing vessels.
lead_paragraph: The most caustic sequence in “Ghost Fleet” comes at the end, when a montage runs chronologically backward to follow a fish from a plate back to the water. This documentary, directed by Shannon Service and Jeffrey Waldron, describes how trafficking networks trick Southeast Asian migrant workers into lives of forced labor aboard ships to satisfy the demands of Thailand’s sprawling  seafood industry. (Service reported on the issue for National Public Radio in 2012.)
