headline: So You Want to Be a Real Estate Agent?
abstract: If you work in one of these 10 places, you’re more likely to succeed.
lead_paragraph: Real estate agents can make a good living, but how well they do depends a lot on where they’re working, according to a recent study by WalletHub.

headline: Democratic Candidates Woo Silicon Valley for Donations, Then Bash It
keywords: ['Campaign Finance', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Computers and the Internet', 'internal-national collaboration']
abstract: Until recently big tech companies were seen as one of the few relatively untainted sources of big-money donations for Democrats. Now, that’s changing.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Top Democrats in Washington and on the 2020 campaign trail are taking technology giants to task, calling them too big, too powerful and too careless about privacy. “The era of self-regulation is over,” Speaker Nancy Pelosi declared on Monday.

headline: At Paul Taylor Dance, a Generation Departs
abstract: The company enters a new phase with a new leader — and the loss of some of its best-known dancers.
lead_paragraph: There are times when dance companies experience seismic shifts, and for the Paul Taylor Dance Company, that time is now.

headline: The Democrats’ Muddle
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Impeachment', 'Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates']
abstract: They keep saying they’re going to hold hearings. And?
lead_paragraph: This article is part of David Leonhardt’s newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it each weekday.

headline: FIFA Vice President Detained by the French Police
abstract: Ahmad Ahmad, the president of Africa’s soccer confederation and a vice president of FIFA, was detained by the police in a corruption investigation.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The president of Africa’s soccer confederation, a FIFA vice president, was detained for questioning in Paris early Thursday, a day before the start of the Women’s World Cup.

headline: West Point Accident Kills Cadet and Injures 22 Others
abstract: Twenty cadets and two trainers were injured after a military vehicle overturned en route to a training area near the military academy, officials said.
lead_paragraph: [What you need to know to start the day: Get New York Today in your inbox.]

headline: Cubs Sign Craig Kimbrel to Anchor Their Latest Run
abstract: The Cubs have learned this season that they are still very good, but also flawed. Picking up Kimbrel locks down their bullpen — and gives him a chance at another ring.
lead_paragraph: It was surely not this simple. But as soon as Chris Sale stalked from the bullpen to the Dodger Stadium mound for the bottom of the ninth inning in the final game of the World Series last October, Craig Kimbrel was as good as gone from the Boston Red Sox.

headline: A $55 Million Gift Aims to Ensure the Philadelphia Orchestra’s Recovery
abstract: The anonymous donation will buttress the endowment of an ensemble still rebuilding from a 2011 bankruptcy.
lead_paragraph: The Philadelphia Orchestra, known in recent years as much for the fiscal woes that drove it into bankruptcy in 2011 as for its vibrant performances, announced Thursday that it had received a major ship-righting gift of $55 million.

headline: The Myth of Period Syncing
abstract: No, women do not get matching menstrual cycles if they spend too much time together.
lead_paragraph: I’ve always been told the idea that women “sync up” with other women’s menstrual cycles is a myth. But I have sisters, and I swear when we’re together for a few months we sync almost to the day. Many of my female friends have corroborating stories of their own. Can it really just be coincidence?

headline: ‘Nureyev’ Review: His Life Was High Drama. This Film Could Use More.
abstract: A new movie about the superstar ballet dancer has a familiar documentary problem: great story, not-so-great storytelling.
lead_paragraph: The life of the ballet superstar Rudolf Nureyev has all the makings of an exceptional drama, or two or three. His rags-to-princes tale has Cold War intrigue, a thriller-worthy defection, a partnership for the ages with Margot Fonteyn, and a dizzying, pop-star level of fame.

headline: Even Grandpa Is on the Apps Now
abstract: Should I tell my father-in-law that I caught him swiping?
lead_paragraph: On a long car ride, I caught my father-in-law using a gay dating app. I couldn’t believe my eyes! I was sitting diagonally behind him in the car. My husband was driving, and my mother-in-law was in the front passenger seat. My elementary-school-aged kids were also in the vehicle. He was having conversations with various men and typing inappropriate messages to them. I am very upset about this. I don’t care what he does in private, but he should never engage in this behavior in front of my family. I have no idea if his wife is aware. Should I confront him?

headline: How Social-Media Meme-Makers Rescued ‘Game of Thrones’ From Itself
abstract: A viral clip mashing up Arya’s horse and the song “Old Town Road” brought a breath of democratic vitality to an exhausted and stumbling series in its final days.
lead_paragraph: In the final week of the eight-season run of “Game of Thrones,” even as the HBO series devolved into a torment of gaffes — a Starbucks cup and plastic bottles in view, overwrought yet hollow symbols, a series of spectacular continuity errors — we were still trying to salvage meaning. We clung to the cliffhanger ending of the penultimate episode: Arya Stark wanders a city of cinders, trying to save innocent women and children from being doused with dragon flame from above. Struck by tumbling rocks and epiphanies — murder is bad, monarchy loves murder — the ash-covered Arya staggers to her feet, looks over and sees a lone white horse, mane wafting. Slowly, she approaches it, calms it and rides away on it as the credits roll.

headline: Soave Classico Makes a Second Impression
abstract: As with many wines, the quality has never been better. Yet out-of-date impressions get in the way of enjoying what many Italian whites can offer.
lead_paragraph: So much of what we think we know about wine is probably wrong.

headline: Rosés Beyond Provence: In Search of Different Expressions
abstract: Southern France has a stranglehold on the mythology of pink wines, but these rosés come from other places and are made with different grapes.
lead_paragraph: June is here, and in wine shops and on restaurant wine lists that can only mean one thing: The rosés have arrived.

headline: Dutch Teenager’s Death Sets Off Debate, and Media Corrections
keywords: ['Euthanasia and Assisted Suicide', 'News and News Media', 'Rumors and Misinformation', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Sex Crimes', 'Depression (Mental)', 'Social Media']
abstract: The Dutch case of Noa Pothoven, 17, who had written about being a rape victim and her experience with mental illness, ricocheted around the globe. But initial stories got it wrong.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — By the time she was 17, the Dutch teenager had written a harrowing memoir recounting repeated sexual assaults and her subsequent experience with post-traumatic stress disorder, depression and anorexia.

headline: Who Will Survive the Trade War?
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'Customs (Tariff)', 'Protectionism (Trade)', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: History shows that big businesses profit most when tariffs reign.
lead_paragraph: America is entering a new era of tariffs. President Trump is in no hurry to resolve the trade dispute with China, he is adamant about imposing tariffs on Mexico, and farmers and companies are trying to figure how to withstand them for months or years, not weeks.

headline: The Case Against Hope
keywords: ['Commencement Speeches', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Social Conditions and Trends', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: I’m not trying to depress anyone — especially recent graduates — but things are really bad, and what we need to do is act.
lead_paragraph: “Now what?” is a question I ask myself often. It’s a question many recent graduates are asking themselves this spring, after collecting their hard-earned diplomas. And it is a good question for them to contemplate as they try to figure out how to move forward.

headline: Why Pete Buttigieg Is Wrong About the Supreme Court
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Constitution (US)']
abstract: Technocratic reforms won’t clear the way for a progressive agenda.
lead_paragraph: President Trump has not done much for Republican legislative priorities. But he has — with the help of a ruthlessly single-minded Mitch McConnell — branded the federal judiciary with his influence. Judges nominated by Trump will be making law, and interpreting the Constitution, for at least a generation.

headline: Amir Ohana Is Gay and Right-Wing. How Far Can He Go in Israel?
keywords: ['Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Politics and Government', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Jews and Judaism']
abstract: “Being attracted to men doesn’t mean you have to believe in creating a Palestinian state,” says Israel’s first openly L.G.B.T. cabinet minister.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — For Amir Ohana, the shift that led to Israel’s current political moment — and indirectly, to his own unlikely rise — can be pinpointed to one incident in the fall of 2000. Mr. Ohana, who was just appointed this country’s first openly gay cabinet minister, was then a 24-year-old from a desert backwater making his way in Tel Aviv. The Israeli right, his political camp, was out of power, the public still hoping for peace with the Arab world.

headline: Scot Peterson Is Released on Bond. Here’s How He’s Explained His Actions During the Parkland Shooting.
keywords: ['Parkland, Fla, Shooting (2018)', 'School Shootings and Armed Attacks']
abstract: He has denied being scared or a coward. He replays the day over and over in his mind, he has said, wishing he knew then what he knows now. “I’m never going to get over this.”
lead_paragraph: The former sheriff’s deputy Scot Peterson has been ridiculed as the “Coward of Broward” for staying outside while a gunman killed 17 students, teachers and staff members, and wounded 17 others at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School in Parkland, Fla.

headline: Senators Ask Federal Reserve to Review Trump’s Deutsche Bank Transactions
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Seven Democrats, including the presidential candidate Elizabeth Warren, want the Fed to examine the bank’s compliance with anti-money-laundering laws over flagged transactions.
lead_paragraph: A group of Democratic senators wants top officials at the Federal Reserve to examine whether Deutsche Bank complied with anti-money-laundering and other laws after bank employees flagged transactions tied to President Trump as potentially suspicious.

headline: Drag Queen Story Hour Continues Its Reign at Libraries, Despite Backlash
keywords: ['Transvestism', 'Libraries and Librarians', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality']
abstract: The events aimed at entertaining children have spread from cities like New York and San Francisco to more conservative towns, upsetting some people.
lead_paragraph: Once upon a time, at a public library in San Francisco, a drag queen arrived at story time and read to the children she met there.

headline: Novak Djokovic and Dominic Thiem Complete a Top-Heavy Final Four
abstract: By winning on Thursday, No. 1 Novak Djokovic and No. 4 Dominic Thiem joined No. 2 Rafael Nadal and No. 3 Roger Federer in the semifinals.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — In sharp contrast to a women’s singles draw filled with breakthroughs and breakdowns, the final four men in contention at the French Open are a perfectly predictable quartet.

headline: New on the Fiction List This Week: ‘Ask Again, Yes’
abstract: Mary Beth Keane was researching a historical novel when “real life kept intervening,” so she wrote a contemporary saga of suburban New York instead.
lead_paragraph: Mary Beth Keane, who brought Typhoid Mary to life in her last novel, “Fever,” was researching another historical novel when, she says, “real life kept intervening in the form of one crisis after another, either in my own family or those of my friends, so it began feeling more and more odd to turn away from the drama of real life just to step into made-up drama of the past.”

headline: ‘The Inheritance,’ an Epic Gay Play, is Coming to Broadway
abstract: Matthew Lopez’s drama, inspired by the novel “Howards End” and presented in two parts, won this year’s Olivier Award for best new play.
lead_paragraph: “The Inheritance,” an ambitious and award-winning two-part play that explores contemporary gay male lives against the backdrop of recent history, is coming to Broadway this fall.

headline: English Village Seeks a Doctor, Using a Hashtag and a Video
abstract: Residents of Mevagissey, at the southwestern tip of England, have taken to social media to try to ensure their community keeps its local health services.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The picturesque fishing village of Mevagissey in southwestern England has a problem: This spring, the local doctor announced that she would quit, leaving 5,300 area residents facing a future without easy access to medical care.

headline: Hudson River Park Needs Help
keywords: ['Parks and Other Recreation Areas', 'Real Estate (Commercial)', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: A plan to put office space on a West Village pier may be the answer.
lead_paragraph: Hudson River Park, a leafy, breezy stretch along Manhattan’s lower shore, has offered a blissful respite from crowded streets for the better part of two decades.

headline: The President’s ‘Emergency’ Tariffs on Mexican Goods, Explained
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'War and Emergency Powers (US)', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'United States Economy', 'Customs (Tariff)']
abstract: The president is again going beyond his predecessors in using powers that lawmakers granted the presidency for use in exigent circumstances. This time, Republicans say they will push back.
lead_paragraph: Congressional Republicans have suggested that they might join Democrats in pushing back against President Trump’s vow to use emergency powers to impose a sharp tax increase on Americans when they buy Mexican goods, unless and until the Mexican government does more to stop migrants from reaching and illegally crossing the American border.

headline: Mexico and the U.S. Have Made Progress Toward Averting Tariffs
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Customs (Tariff)', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Asylum, Right of', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: They are discussing changes in asylum rules and border enforcement that could forestall the U.S. from imposing tariffs on Mexican imports, officials said.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Mexico and the United States are discussing significant changes in asylum rules and border enforcement that could forestall President Trump from imposing tariffs on all Mexican imports, senior officials from both countries said Thursday.

headline: ‘Dark Phoenix’ Review: X-Women Power? Nah
abstract: The new installment in the long-running franchise has blowouts and Jessica Chastain channeling Tilda Swinton (so it could be worse).
lead_paragraph: The spectacle of superhero franchises trying to engage women can be amusing when it’s not insulting, pandering or straight-up weird. “Dark Phoenix,” the 12th installment in the “X-Men” franchise, certainly tries to do right, but the strain shows. It has a female-driven story but odd ideas about empowerment. On the plus side it has Jessica Chastain playing an otherworldly creature who opens a portal to another dimension and a better movie. She keeps you watching even if at times the director, Simon Kinberg, seems more into her risibly high heels.

headline: A Young Pianist Held Carnegie Hall Rapt in March. She’s Already Back.
abstract: Beatrice Rana, 26, has ferocious technique but is distinguished by her musical intelligence.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — Growing up in a small village in Puglia, in southern Italy, Beatrice Rana so outshone the other piano students that she felt little need to practice.

headline: Coach Brings Fresh Ideas to Nadal’s 39th Match With Federer
abstract: Ahead of a Friday semifinal at the French Open, Carlos Moyá explained the challenges Rafael Nadal has faced in recent years and how, like Roger Federer, he had revived his career.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — You might think that playing 38 tennis matches against someone would mean there is very little left to learn before the 39th.

headline: Anthony Mangieri Will Take His Prized Pizza to New Jersey
abstract: Having charmed New Yorkers at Una Pizza Napoletana, he’ll open another on the Jersey Shore.
lead_paragraph: Anthony Mangieri, one of New York City’s premier pizza makers, will return to his New Jersey roots, opening a branch of his Una Pizza Napoletana this summer in Atlantic Highlands, N.J.

headline: Stonewall Riot Apology: Police Actions Were ‘Wrong,’ Commissioner Admits
keywords: ['Stonewall Riots (1969)', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Apologies']
abstract: The commissioner, James O’Neill, said he was sorry on behalf of the New York Police Department for officers’ actions during a seminal 1969 clash outside a gay bar.
lead_paragraph: [What you need to know to start the day: Get New York Today in your inbox.]

headline: Review: ‘Oscar at the Crown’ Sets the Apocalypse to a Throbbing Dance Beat
abstract: Both a dance party and an Oscar Wilde book club, this musical tries to connect the rise of social media to the end of the world.
lead_paragraph: When a musical as loud and boisterous as “Oscar at the Crown” argues that there’s a direct — though not so straight — line from Oscar Wilde to “The Real Housewives of Orange County” to postapocalyptic America, you may find yourself nodding in agreement. There is, after all, such a thing as being pummeled into submission.

headline: Meet the Money Whisperer to the Super-Rich N.B.A. Elite
abstract: Who’s the guy Klay Thompson and other N.B.A. stars trust to manage their wealth? One who knows how to rebound with $8,000 stuffed into his underwear.
lead_paragraph: Every day of Joe McLean’s job, as the premier wealth manager of the N.B.A. elite, requires him to make the kind of purchases that most of us make only once or twice in a lifetime. He bought 25 cars on behalf of his clients last year, and he probably sold nearly as many. He closed on four houses in February alone. You wouldn’t believe how many pool tables he’s bought, let alone how many pools.

headline: Skills, Not Screens
abstract: A reader encourages schools to offer creative spaces for their students, which can pay off later in life.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Teenagers in The Times: May 2019
abstract: Our roundup of the news stories and features about young people that have recently appeared across sections of NYTimes.com.
lead_paragraph: Here is the May 2019 edition of Teenagers in The Times, the last of the 2018-2019 school year. This roundup of news and feature stories about young people that have recently appeared across sections of NYTimes.com appears on the first Thursday of each month from September until June.

headline: Google to Buy Data Analytics Company Despite New Antitrust Scrutiny
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Data-Mining and Database Marketing', 'Cloud Computing', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Google said it would acquire Looker for $2.6 billion in a bid to catch rivals in the cloud-computing industry.
lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — Just as government officials step up their antitrust scrutiny of the American tech giants, Google had a surprising announcement on Thursday: It is buying another company.

headline: Jail Time for Not Paying Fines
abstract: The MacArthur Foundation says traffic fines affect the poor disproportionately.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: ‘Framing John DeLorean’ Review: The Man Who Flew His Car Too Close to the Sun
keywords: ['Documentary Films and Programs', 'Automobiles', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic']
abstract: Mixing documentary and fictionalized re-enactment, a new film about the mythic automaker tells a quintessentially American story of ambition and greed.
lead_paragraph: “Framing John DeLorean,” a smart, hook-filled blend of documentary and fictionalized re-enactments, opens with a question: Why haven’t more movies been made about John DeLorean? Because the story of the maverick, egocentric automaker, whose name is practically synonymous with the excesses of the midcentury American car industry, is ready-made for the silver screen.

headline: The Harm to Migrant Children
abstract: A child psychologist says removing schooling and services will have developmental and psychological consequences.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Are Republicans ‘Pro-Life’ Beyond Abortion?
keywords: ['ABORTION', 'Religion and Belief', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Readers discuss an Op-Ed by an opponent of abortion who criticized Republicans for “ideological inconsistency.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Afghan War Casualty Report: May 31-June 6
keywords: ['Civilian Casualties', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: At least 50 pro-government forces and 19 civilians were killed in Afghanistan during the past week.
lead_paragraph: At least 50 pro-government forces and 19 civilians were killed in Afghanistan during the past week. The deadliest attack took place in Oruzgan Province, where the Taliban ambushed the police headquarters of Shahid Hasas District with two stolen Humvees packed with explosives. After the initial assault, insurgents entered the compound to target surviving officers. At least 11 soldiers and eight police officers were killed and six police officers were wounded. There are fears that the Taliban will soon capture the district center. Separately, a convoy of American forces was targeted by a car bomb in Kabul City, reportedly wounding four Americans. Four Afghan civilians were killed in the explosion. In Kabul, there were three bombings within 24 hours mostly targeting civilians. Seven civilians were killed and dozens were wounded.

headline: Judge John Hodgman on Disgusting Food Combinations
abstract: Peanut butter and tuna fish sandwich, anyone?
lead_paragraph: Kendall writes: My husband feeds our daughters offensive meals: peanut butter and tuna fish, hard-boiled eggs and strawberries, P.B.&J. on cold tortillas. He says the meals are healthy. I say they’re gross. Please make him stop.

headline: Trump’s D-Day Tribute, and His Own War Avoidance
keywords: ['Draft and Recruitment (Military)', 'World War II (1939-45)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: One reader praises the president’s speech as “perhaps his best ever,” while another faults him for comments to an interviewer about the Vietnam War.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Democratic Candidates Go After Joe Biden, but Not by Name
abstract: Even when criticizing his particular views, like his support of the Hyde Amendment, Mr. Biden’s rivals have avoided calling him out directly.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The leading Democratic presidential contenders have begun criticizing Joseph R. Biden Jr. for, among other things, being too old, too moderate, too fixated on President Trump and too delusional about the state of the Republican Party. But you’d be forgiven if you missed it, because they almost never mention Mr. Biden by name.

headline: Deceased Strategist’s Files Detail Republican Gerrymandering in North Carolina, Advocates Say
abstract: A group challenging North Carolina’s state legislative maps says that documents from the files from the late Thomas Hofeller show that Republicans misled a federal court to avoid a special election.
lead_paragraph: When the hard drives of a deceased Republican strategist revealed new evidence last week about the Trump administration’s decision to add a citizenship question to the 2020 census, many people wondered whether the files hid other revelations.

headline: Herb Sandler, Banker Who Financed ProPublica, Dies at 87
abstract: The investigative journalism group was just one cause backed by Mr. Sandler and his wife, Marion, who built a banking giant and then gave millions away.
lead_paragraph: Herb Sandler, a banker and philanthropist who with his wife, Marion, provided the initial financing for ProPublica, the nonprofit investigative-reporting organization that seeks to be an alternative model for sustaining vigorous journalism, died on Wednesday at his home in San Francisco. He was 87.

headline: Trump Honors D-Day Sacrifices, With Some Legacies Unspoken
keywords: ['World War II (1939-45)', 'Veterans', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States International Relations', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: While paying tribute to veterans, the president said little about the institutions built after World War II that are fraying under populist movements.
lead_paragraph: COLLEVILLE-SUR-MER, France — Standing on a sun-drenched bluff above the Normandy beaches, where 10,000 soldiers sacrificed themselves to a savage fusillade of gunfire and opened the way for Europe’s liberation in 1944, President Trump declared on Thursday, “We are gathered here on freedom’s altar.”

headline: New in Paperback: ‘Amity and Prosperity,’ ‘The Great Believers’
abstract: Six new paperbacks to check out this week.
lead_paragraph: Six new paperbacks to check out this week.

headline: ‘For Colored Girls’ and ‘Soft Power’ Will Be Part of Public Theater Season
abstract: Along with a revival of Ntozake Shange’s “choreopoem” and a new David Henry Hwang musical: work from Tony Kushner, Richard Nelson and Steve Earle.
lead_paragraph: The Public Theater, one of the nation’s most prestigious nonprofits, will stage rare revivals of a Ntozake Shange masterwork and an early piece by Tony Kushner next season.

headline: Warriors Minority Owner Barred for a Year After Shoving Toronto’s Kyle Lowry
abstract: Mark Stevens, a minority investor, was fined $500,000 and told he could not attend games or team activities through the end of the 2019-20 season.
lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — Mark Stevens, a minority investor in the Golden State Warriors, has been barred by the N.B.A. and the Warriors for a year and fined $500,000 for “pushing and directing obscene language” at Kyle Lowry of the Toronto Raptors. Stevens will not be allowed to attend games or other team activities.

headline: Trump Administration Plans to Sell More Than $2 Billion of Arms to Taiwan
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Arms Trade', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States International Relations', '5G (Wireless Communications)']
abstract: The proposed weapons package, including 108 tanks, is the costliest in recent years. The sale would add to tensions between the United States and China.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The Trump administration is proposing to sell more than $2 billion worth of tanks and other military equipment to Taiwan, American officials said on Thursday. The sale would add to tensions between the United States and China, which are already clashing over trade, communications technology and a military buildup in the Pacific region.

headline: Black Democrats Say It’s the Economy, Still
keywords: ['Blacks', 'Black People', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Whites']
abstract: Faring worse in the recovery, they worry more about jobs than white Democrats do, polling shows.
lead_paragraph: A key base of support for the Democratic Party, black America, is lagging in its recovery from the recession and demanding more attention to economic issues than white voters. That divide could complicate presidential contenders’ attempts to woo African-American votes in 2020.

headline: Remembering Tin House, a Literary Haven for ‘Brilliant Weirdos’
abstract: The magazine, which will publish its final issue this month after 20 years, set out to become a home for underrepresented voices in the literary landscape.
lead_paragraph: The great fame of American literary magazines is that almost no one reads them. Some so-called little magazines boast a three-figure readership; to reach the very low five figures is a rare achievement. The second best-known fact about literary magazines is that they are financially vulnerable. No one makes money from a literary magazine, and no one gets rich working at one. And yet these journals persist.

headline: ‘The Last Black Man in San Francisco’ Review: Lost in a Dream City
abstract: An indelibly beautiful story of love, family and loss in America from two childhood friends turned filmmakers.
lead_paragraph: The astonishing “Last Black Man in San Francisco” is about having little in a grab-what-you-can world. It’s the haunting, elegiac story of Jimmie Fails — playing a version of himself — a young man trying to hold onto a sense of home in San Francisco. His parents are missing in action and someone else lives in the family’s old house. Given to dreamy, faraway looks, Jimmie seems not quite there, either. But he remains tethered to the city, somehow exalted by it. And when he slaloms down its hills on his skateboard, he doesn’t descend — he soars.

headline: ‘The Raft’ Review: A Crew of 10 Set Adrift With a Moody Svengali
abstract: A fascinating documentary re-examines a notorious anthropological experiment from the 1970s.
lead_paragraph: There is no collection of human beings too small for conflict, as anyone who has had roommates or endured a family car trip surely knows. But social science exists to test — and sometimes to affirm — our self-knowledge as a species, which is why 11 people spent the summer of 1973 crossing the Atlantic on a small raft powered only by wind, ocean currents and the ambition of a Mexican anthropologist named Santiago Genovés.

headline: What to See in Art Galleries Right Now
abstract: Matthew Ronay’s colorful configurations; Tarek Atoui’s sonic sculptures; Rafal Bujnowski’s arresting grisailles; Kiki Kogelnik’s body of work; and Zheng Guogu’s trippy thangkas.
lead_paragraph: Matthew Ronay’s electric show at Casey Kaplan reveals an artist at the height of his powers. Mr. Ronay has been arranging small shapes made of carved and stained wood into aggregate sculptures for nearly two decades, and they’ve always been appealing. But the best works in the exhibition, “Betrayals of and by the Body,” go beyond appealing in their brilliant colors, myriad textures, suggestive forms and the ease and delicacy with which they fit together.

headline: An Australian Doctor’s Dream: Curing America’s Opioid Curse
keywords: ['NALTREXONE (DRUG)', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Buprenorphine (Drug)', 'Medical Devices', 'Implants', 'Addiction (Psychology)', 'Opioids and Opiates', 'Therapy and Rehabilitation']
abstract: Dr. George O’Neil has implanted a device he invented into thousands of Australians who abuse opioids. But is it an answer for America’s addiction crisis?
lead_paragraph: SUBIACO, Australia — The hazy-eyed sheep shearer was shifting in his seat in a clinic in Western Australia, unsure if he could do what the doctor said would save his life. A heroin user for 20 years, he was now in the depths of a detoxification treatment. “I’m all alone,” he said.

headline: My Stutter Made Me a Better Writer
abstract: At times it caused suffering, but it also gave me a passion for words and language.
lead_paragraph: The J in “juice” was the first letter-sound, according to my mother, that I repeated in staccato, going off like a skipping record. This was when I was 3, before my stutter was stigmatized as shameful. In those earliest years my relationship to language was uncomplicated: I assumed my voice was more like a bird’s or a squirrel’s than my playmates’. This seemed exciting. I imagined, unlike fluent children, I might be able to converse with wild creatures, I’d learn their secrets, tell them mine and forge friendships based on interspecies intimacy.

headline: Trump Honors War Dead — but First a Word About Mueller and Pelosi
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'World War II (1939-45)']
abstract: The president laid into the special counsel and the speaker of the House with the graves of D-Day casualties as a backdrop.
lead_paragraph: COLLEVILLE-SUR-MER, France — With marble crosses and Stars of David marking the graves of those who died fighting the Nazis on D-Day visible in the background, President Trump used the occasion of the 75th anniversary of the invasion of Normandy to bash the special counsel, Robert S. Mueller III, in an interview with Fox News.

headline: Pride in Queer Cinema of the Past Might Show Us Our Future
abstract: How New York is marking the 50th anniversary of the Stonewall Uprising at the movies.
lead_paragraph: For many L.G.B.T.Q. people, June signals rainbows and glitter, but also reflection. With the 50th anniversary of the Stonewall Uprising and the WorldPride festival colliding in New York this Pride Month, it’s an especially momentous time to look to the past to consider what Pride means today, and cinema — long an integral part of queer artistic expression — can be an important tool. Many of the city’s repertory movie theaters have assembled special programs for the occasion, from revivals of “Paris Is Burning” (Film Forum) and “The Queen” (IFC Center) to a series looking at queer cinema before and after Stonewall (Museum of the Moving Image).

headline: Fixing Your Work Environment Will Not Fix Your Life
abstract: Pocket computers, overbearing bosses and the Protestant work ethic conspire to blur the lines between your job and your existence. It’s time to fight back.
lead_paragraph: Send questions about the office, money, careers and work-life balance to workfriend@nytimes.com. Include your name and location, even if you want them withheld. Letters may be edited.

headline: Huawei, Shunned by U.S. Government, Is Welcomed in Russia
abstract: A Russian cellphone company signed an agreement with Huawei for 5G equipment, signaling Russian acceptance of the Chinese supplier.
lead_paragraph: St. PETERSBURG, Russia — Russia has welcomed the Chinese telecommunications company Huawei to develop part of its next-generation wireless technology, even as the United States is trying to convince allies that the company poses a prohibitive security risk.

headline: Last Call: MoMA’s Closing, and Changing
abstract: With the museum shutting down June 15 for a four-month renovation, our critic assesses the challenges it faces.
lead_paragraph: The Museum of Modern Art is slouching toward a shutdown starting June 15, in order to complete its latest expansion — which is really an attempt to fix the last one. With the museum on the brink of change, the art and architecture critics of The New York Times took the occasion to revisit favorite (or famous) artworks, review shows not yet covered and consider the implications of the ghost in the machine — the loss of the American Folk Art Museum, once next door but now part of the Modern’s new footprint.

headline: Celebrating ‘Good Design’ at MoMA: The Nut Dish and Other Populist Gems
abstract: “If most Americans had little patience for Picasso, everybody needed a decent can opener,” our critic writes.
lead_paragraph: Before MoMA shuts down next week to reboot for its expansion, you can still catch “The Value of Good Design.” I joined a crowd the other day, toting up an imaginary shopping list. Covetousness is partly the show’s point.

headline: A Noisy Half-Hour With van Gogh’s Masterpiece
abstract: Our critic spent 30 minutes looking — or trying to look — at “Starry Night.” It wasn’t easy.
lead_paragraph: The Museum of Modern Art owns only three paintings by Vincent van Gogh, but they include its biggest crowd-pleaser: “The Starry Night,” which the Dutchman completed in 1889, shortly after having checked into a psychiatric hospital. It has hung in the first gallery on the fifth floor since 2004, when MoMA opened its expansion by the architect Yoshio Taniguchi.

headline: Will the Renovated MoMA Let Folk Art Back In?
abstract: Still mourning the American Folk Art Museum, a critic says, “We, and MoMA, don’t need any more Rauschenbergs, or Richters.” Bring on the outsider artists.
lead_paragraph: What I’ll miss during the Museum of Modern Art’s four-month public shutdown is something I’ve already been missing for five years and will probably continue to miss when the expanded museum reopens in October. I’m talking about the presence on West 53rd Street of the American Folk Art Museum, which was physically demolished in 2014, and whose site the expanded MoMA absorbs, but whose spirit lives on as a restless ghost in the corporate machine that MoMA is.

headline: Mondrian Sparked My Love of Painting
abstract: Familiarity breeds contentment before MoMA’s “Broadway Boogie Woogie.”
lead_paragraph: The first museum show that ever changed my mind about anything was the Museum of Modern Art’s giant 1995 Piet Mondrian show, organized jointly with Washington’s National Gallery of Art and the Gemeentemuseum in The Hague.

headline: Encountering the ‘New Order’ at MoMA
abstract: The blind spots and new possibilities of the technologies we love (and hate).
lead_paragraph: What differentiates the work in “New Order: Art and Technology in the Twenty-First Century” from much of the art elsewhere at the Museum of Modern Art is that the objects here are made with technologies most of us already know and love (or hate). Flat screens, computer interfaces, video games, digital animation, 3D-printing and photography are transformed here into sprawling installations, canny video art or interactive sculptures.

headline: In Praise of the Great Majority
abstract: At MoMA, Honoré Sharrer’s “Workers and Paintings” asks: “What if great art were more accessible?”
lead_paragraph: I stopped visiting MoMA’s permanent collection years ago. In my early days in New York City, when I was just starting to write about art, it had been a refuge, a place that filled me with inspiration and wonder. The more contemporary art I saw, though, the less I saw myself in the specific and stilted story of modernism — one favoring abstraction and male creators — that MoMA was chronicling. I continued to visit the museum, but I spent my time in special exhibitions, where strange pictures and enchanting surprises could still be found.

headline: Tariff Threats Aside, the Senate Is Where Action Goes to Die
keywords: ['Law and Legislation', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Customs (Tariff)']
abstract: Mitch McConnell, the “grim reaper,” has made the Senate the place where legislation goes to die, so the chances that the chamber blocks President Trump’s tariffs on Mexico are slim.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator John Kennedy of Louisiana reached into his seemingly bottomless well of folksy barbs on Tuesday and said, “There’s a reason that the American people think that members of Congress were born tired and raised lazy.”

headline: Review: ‘Big Little Lies’ Adjusts to Big Little Truths
abstract: Meryl Streep is as stellar as you would expect. But Season 2, while still sharp, feels more like a curtain call than a continuation.
lead_paragraph: We are living in a golden age of TV series that build to big finishes and then just … stick around.

keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'World War II (1939-45)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'Blacks', 'Black People']
abstract: These books — some classics, some published this year — tell the stories of the soldiers and spies who fought to defeat the Axis forces.
lead_paragraph: It’s been 75 years since the Allied forces landed on Omaha Beach in Normandy, France, to fight the Nazi occupation in Europe. These books take a kaleidoscopic view of that momentous day.

headline: ‘I Can’t Sit Still. I Can’t Not Do Anything.’
abstract: What does it mean when a gun control advocate who lost a son to violence also becomes a gun owner who enjoys shooting?
lead_paragraph: Gregory Gibson’s son was killed in 1992 during a shooting at Bard College at Simon’s Rock in Great Barrington, Mass. In 2014, after decades of work with gun violence prevention groups, Mr. Gibson bought a 9-millimeter Sig Sauer P320 and began learning to shoot. In the essay “A Gun Killed My Son. So Why Do I Want to Own One?” Mr. Gibson walks readers down his path to becoming a gun owner and his quest for clarity in the debate around guns in America.

headline: What Megan Rapinoe Can’t Travel Without
abstract: The soccer megastar is in Paris for the 2019 Women’s World Cup. Vitamins, CBD drops and plenty of protein bars went with her.
lead_paragraph: The soccer megastar Megan Rapinoe captains Seattle Reign FC, helped the U.S. women’s soccer team to World Cup victory in 2015, and will lead the national team as co-captain in France for the 2019 World Cup, which begins June 7th.

headline: Runners-Up From Our Sixth Annual Student Editorial Contest
abstract: Tiger parenting, college admissions, criminal justice, mental health and pineapple pizza: 27 teenage runners-up take on the issues that matter most to them.
lead_paragraph: Can you be good without God? Is CBD too dangerous to be so widely available? How should schools teach about slavery? Is “tiger parenting” actually good for children? Does “voluntourism” do more harm than good? And … should pineapple pizza get more respect?

headline: How France’s Intrusive Demands Quashed the Fiat-Renault Deal
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Automobiles', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Politics and Government']
abstract: Talks between Fiat Chrysler and Renault to create one of the world’s largest automakers ran into a familiar problem in France: the government itself.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — It was supposed to be a transformative merger in an industry facing intractable challenges. But Fiat Chrysler and Renault ran headlong this week into a familiar problem in France: the government itself.

headline: Lowell North, World Champion Sailor and Innovative Sailmaker, Dies at 89
abstract: He won five world sailing championships and an Olympic gold medal. He also founded North Sails, which became the largest sailmaker in the world.
lead_paragraph: Lowell North, a five-time world champion and Olympic gold medal-winning sailor who was also the founder of North Sails, the largest sailmaker in the world, died on June 2 at his home in San Diego. He was 89.

keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Fuel Efficiency', 'Fuel Emissions (Transportation)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Global Warming', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Factories and Manufacturing']
abstract: In a letter signed by 17 industry giants including Ford, General Motors and Toyota, the firms asked Mr. Trump to go back to the negotiating table.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The world’s largest automakers warned President Trump on Thursday that one of his most sweeping deregulatory efforts — his plan to weaken tailpipe pollution standards — threatens to cut their profits and produce “untenable” instability in a crucial manufacturing sector.

headline: Here’s What Being a Witch Really Means
abstract: My grandma Trudy used to tell us that she had “healing hands.” I soon discovered that I did, too.
lead_paragraph: You could say I was primed to be a witch from an early age.

headline: 30 Racehorses Have Died at This Track Since Dec. 26
abstract: A terrible season at Santa Anita produced more than two dozen deaths on the track.
lead_paragraph: A season to remember at Santa Anita Park ended Sunday, one day after American Currency became the 30th horse to die at the historic racetrack since the day after Christmas.

headline: Solving a Leafy Mathematical Mystery
abstract: Researchers developed a model that explains a peculiar pattern found in a shrub common in Japan.
lead_paragraph: Next time you go outside, take a minute to look at your local leaf arrangements. You’ll probably notice a few different patterns. In basil plants, each leaf is about 90 degrees — a quarter-turn — from the last, a template called “decussate.”

keywords: ['Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Citizenship and Naturalization', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Nearly 100 Democratic members of Congress, including several presidential hopefuls, signed letters calling for an end to the State Department policy.
lead_paragraph: Nearly 20 Democratic senators and 80 members of the House of Representatives signed sharply worded letters that were sent to Secretary of State Mike Pompeo on Thursday, calling on his department to reverse a policy that has been used to deny citizenship to children of Americans born abroad through assisted reproductive technology.

headline: 10 New Books We Recommend This Week
abstract: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: “No more pencils, no more books,” the song goes, and can we just say that we do not approve? Summer in this hemisphere officially arrives on June 21, but summer reading is upon us already, and more books are frankly just the thing.

headline: Mar-a-Lago Comes for British Health
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Of privatization, cronyism and trade deals.
lead_paragraph: Probably everyone who followed Donald Trump’s visit to Britain has a favorite scene of diplomatic debacle. But the moment that probably did the most to poison relations with our oldest ally — and undermine whatever chance there was for the “phenomenal” trade deal Trump claimed to be offering — was Trump’s apparent suggestion that such a deal would involve opening up Britain’s National Health Service to U.S. private companies.

headline: Dr. John, of Voodoo Beads, Feathers and New Orleans Sound, Dies at 77
abstract: Born Malcolm Rebennack Jr., he was part of a pantheon of New Orleans keyboard wizards that also included Professor Longhair, James Booker and Fats Domino.
lead_paragraph: Mac Rebennack, the pianist, singer, songwriter and producer better known as Dr. John, who embodied the New Orleans sound for generations of music fans, died on Thursday. He was 77.

headline: Rudolf von Ribbentrop, Son of Top Nazi Diplomat, Dies at 98
keywords: ['Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'World War II (1939-45)', 'Deaths (Obituaries)']
abstract: Mr. von Ribbentrop spent nearly six years in combat. His father, Germany’s foreign minister, was hanged as a war criminal.
lead_paragraph: Rudolf von Ribbentrop, an SS officer who shortly before the end of World War II in Europe accompanied his father, Joachim — Nazi Germany’s foreign minister — on a visit to a deluded Adolf Hitler in his bunker in Berlin, died on May 20 in Ratingen, Germany, near Düsseldorf. He was 98.

headline: Joe Biden’s Old-Fashioned Campaign
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2020']
abstract: In the On Politics newsletter: Some of the former vice president’s positions seem more in line with the Democratic Party of 2007.
lead_paragraph: Hi. Welcome to On Politics, your guide to the day in national politics. I’m Lisa Lerer, your host.

headline: Listen to Trump’s Lawyer Make Appeal After Flynn Agreed to Cooperate With Mueller
keywords: ['Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates', 'Audio Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Special Prosecutors (Independent Counsel)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Legal Profession']

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Prosecutors released audio on Thursday of a voice mail message that President Trump’s personal lawyer left for a lawyer for Michael T. Flynn, the former national security adviser, shortly after Mr. Flynn agreed in 2017 to cooperate with the special counsel’s investigation.

headline: House Plans Vote to Fight Barr in Court but Back Off Contempt
keywords: ['Courts and the Judiciary', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Executive Privilege, Doctrine of', 'Impeachment', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct']
abstract: House Democrats revealed a resolution up for a vote next week to take Attorney General William P. Barr and the former White House counsel Donald F. McGahn II to court.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After weeks of pledging to hold Attorney General William P. Barr and the former White House counsel Donald F. McGahn II in contempt for defying subpoenas, House Democrats appear poised to pursue an alternative path to try to force them into sharing information.

headline: Todd Frazier and the Mets Dig In for a Series Win Over the Giants
abstract: Frazier got underneath an eighth-inning curveball to help the Mets to a 7-3 win, delivering a positive end to a series that began with criticism of Mickey Callaway.
lead_paragraph: After watching his teammates hit back-to-back homers in the first inning, bunt for hits twice and rally to tie the score at 3-3 on a bloop single in the seventh, Mets third baseman Todd Frazier stepped to the plate with a runner on second base in the eighth inning.

headline: After Dethroning a ‘Jeopardy!’ Giant, Emma Boettcher Relinquishes the Crown
abstract: The 27-year-old librarian who defeated James Holzhauer went on her own small streak, but it came to an end on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: On Monday, Emma Boettcher grabbed a small piece of television history, dethroning the “Jeopardy!” juggernaut James Holzhauer just as he was poised to break a longstanding record.

headline: Two Veteran Police Officers Die by Suicide in 24 Hours, Stunning Department

headline: The Racial Reckoning Comes
keywords: ['Race and Ethnicity', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Citizenship and Naturalization', 'Native Americans', 'Blacks', 'Black People']
abstract: Trump has changed our national narrative.
lead_paragraph: When I was a boy I was taught a certain story about America. This was the land of opportunity. Immigrants came to this land and found an open field and a fair chance to pursue their dreams. In this story Benjamin Franklin could be held up as the quintessential American — the young hustler, who through his ingenuity and dogged self-improvement created new businesses and communities, a new sort of person and a new sort of country.

headline: Why Are the Australian Police Rummaging Through Journalists’ Files?
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Freedom of the Press', 'News Sources, Confidential Status of', 'Classified Information and State Secrets', 'Politics and Government']
abstract: Two raids this week threaten the ability of news organizations to reveal official wrongdoing.
lead_paragraph: It is typical of authoritarian governments that assail press freedoms to claim they are defending national security, since any effort by the news media to expose official misconduct can be construed as a revelation of state “secrets.” And it is typical of democratic governments to recognize that this role of the press is essential to protect the public from official abuse.

headline: S.E.C. Tells Brokers to Work for You, but Don’t Skip the Fine Print
keywords: ['Financial Planners', 'Financial Brokers', 'Consumer Protection', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Conflicts of Interest', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Consumer advocates say rule changes have weakened the standards governing one class of financial professionals while giving an unwarranted veneer of trustworthiness to another.
lead_paragraph: When you go to the doctor, there’s an expectation that she will act in your best interest. You don’t expect to be prescribed costly pills because the office is getting a commission from the drug company, when a healthier diet will do the trick.

headline: Joe Biden Denounces Hyde Amendment, Reversing His Position
keywords: ['ABORTION', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government']

lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — After two days of intense criticism, Joseph R. Biden Jr. reversed himself Thursday night on one of the issues most important to Democratic voters, saying he no longer supports a measure that bans federal funding for most abortions.

headline: ‘Alles Ist Gut’ Review: Surviving Sexual Assault, and All the Mornings After
abstract: The first-time director Eva Trobisch has made a searing drama about the everyday interactions that all women must navigate carefully.
lead_paragraph: Janne doesn’t want anyone to worry about her. Not her boyfriend, Piet (Andreas Döhler), who’s still smarting from the failure of their shared publishing venture. Not her new boss, Robert (Tilo Nest), who has generously offered her a temp editing job at his own publishing house. Not even  the man who raped her, the extremely apologetic Martin (Hans Löw).

headline: Marine Pleads Guilty to Hazing Death of Green Beret in Mali
keywords: ['Hazing', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'United States Politics and Government', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Staff Sgt. Kevin Maxwell Jr. told a military court that he and three other American commandos engaged in hazing during which the soldier was strangled.
lead_paragraph: NORFOLK, Va. — A Marine commando pleaded guilty on Thursday to negligent homicide charges in the 2017 death of a Green Beret soldier in Mali, describing how he helped duct-tape the wrists and feet of the victim, who was choked in a hazing incident.

headline: Michael Bloomberg Promises $500 Million to Help End Coal
keywords: ['Coal', 'Global Warming', 'Environment', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Carbon Dioxide', 'Natural Gas', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The pledge by the former New York City mayor is part of an effort to close every coal-fired power plant in the United States and halt the growth of natural gas.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Michael R. Bloomberg, the former mayor of New York City, said on Friday he would donate $500 million to a new campaign to close every coal-fired power plant in the United States and halt the growth of natural gas.

headline: Labour Ekes Out a Win Over Brexit Party in a Local U.K. Vote
keywords: ['Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)', 'Elections', 'Legislatures and Parliaments']
abstract: The real losers were the Tories, who finished a humiliating third in the latest in a series of electoral disasters for the ruling party.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Britain’s ruling Conservative Party shed thousands of votes to the insurgent, populist Brexit Party, suffering another crushing election setback early Friday, just hours before Prime Minister Theresa May planned to stand aside as leader.

keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Search and Seizure', 'News Sources, Confidential Status of', 'News and News Media']
abstract: Australia has a global reputation for being a sunny, relaxed democracy. But it also has a deep preference for government secrecy.

headline: Zion Williamson Invited to U.S.A. Basketball Training Camp

headline: ‘Anything Else I Can Help You With?’
abstract: Michael Hawkins wants to know if we need anything.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY PUZZLE — Late in the week — when we can enjoy those large expanses of white space just crying out to be filled in — lie the best opportunities for a constructor to riff on lively and unusual phrases. These entries are fun to write into a puzzle and are especially satisfying because you’ve worked so hard to untangle the tricky Friday clues.

headline: Dispute Arises Over ‘No-No Boy,’ a Classic of Asian-American Literature With a Complex History
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Asian-Americans', 'Japanese-Americans', 'Writing and Writers', 'Book Trade and Publishing', 'World War II (1939-45)', 'Copyrights and Copyright Violations', 'Wills and Estates']
abstract: John Okada’s 1957 novel about a Japanese-American draft resister has been republished by Penguin Classics, raising questions over its ownership.
lead_paragraph: Late last month, Penguin Classics released a new edition of John Okada’s “No-No Boy,” a once-overlooked 1957 novel about a Japanese-American draft resister in World War II. It hailed the release as groundbreaking, noting that “No-No Boy” is “the first ever Japanese-American novel and Okada is the first Japanese-American writer published in Penguin Classics.”

headline: Taking the Future of Manufacturing Into High Schools

headline: Online Classrooms Look to Improve Higher Education Across Africa, but Face Skepticism
abstract: New ventures hope to fill a need as the number of African high school graduates grows, along with demand for a more highly skilled work force.
lead_paragraph: Everywhere is a classroom for Emily Kamizi, even the buses in Lusaka, Zambia’s congested capital. It can take an hour or more to cross the city, so Ms. Kamizi puts on her headphones, turns up Taylor Swift and concentrates on her M.B.A. studies.

headline: Short-Term Programs for Long-Term Success
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Scholarships and Fellowships', 'Entrepreneurship']
abstract: A growing number of intensive programs offered online, or on campuses around the world, can help workers at all stages become more globally minded.
lead_paragraph: It was time for Jon Hanson to step it up. His dream was to start a successful venture. Mr. Hanson, an engineer, now 38, had already taken a few online courses, but it was the intensive weeklong M.I.T. Innovation and Entrepreneurship Bootcamp held in Brisbane, Australia, a world away from his home in Brunswick, Me., that made his quest a reality.

headline: Bulletin Board
keywords: ['Foreign Students (in US)', 'Education (K-12)', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Community Colleges', 'International Study and Teaching', 'Women and Girls', 'Skeleton (Sport)', 'Olympic Games (2018)', 'E-Learning', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: Graduation guidance, e-learning around the globe, a scholarship program for refugees — and more. A collection of views and news from a special report on Learning.
lead_paragraph: For many American universities and colleges, the world is getting farther away. International enrollment in the United States is flat or down after many years when visitors flocked here to learn.

headline: Amanda Anisimova, Playing Fearlessly, Nears an Early Breakthrough
abstract: The 17-year-old from Freehold, N.J., is the latest in a long line of teenagers on the women’s tour who have gotten the better of their elders.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — While Amanda Anisimova’s opponents at the French Open have returned to their lodging to relax after matches, Anisimova has headed back to her Paris hotel to do schoolwork.

headline: Dallas Keuchel Is Returning to the Majors as an Atlanta Brave
abstract: The Braves landed Keuchel, who missed more than a third of the season, after signing free agents like him and Craig Kimbrel no longer meant giving up a draft pick.
lead_paragraph: Dallas Keuchel, the 2015 Cy Young Award winner, reached an agreement on Thursday to join the Atlanta Braves after sitting out more than a third of the season. He made the deal just a day after Craig Kimbrel, one of the best closers in the game, ended a similar exile by agreeing to join the Chicago Cubs on a three-year, $43 million contract.

headline: Women’s Soccer’s Big Moment, Big-Footed by Indifference and a ‘Clerical Error’
abstract: Women’s World Cup supporters were disappointed, but hardly surprised, when two major men’s finals were scheduled against theirs.
lead_paragraph: A lot of thought went into deciding where, and when, the final of this summer’s Gold Cup would be held. It is, after all, a showpiece occasion for Concacaf, the body that governs soccer in North and Central America and the Caribbean.

headline: What’s on TV Friday: ‘XY Chelsea’ and ‘Alles Ist Gut’
abstract: A documentary about Chelsea Manning airs on Showtime. And the German director Eva Trobisch’s award-winning debut feature hits Netflix.
lead_paragraph: XY CHELSEA (2019) 9 p.m. on Showtime. In mid-2017, months after her prison sentence for leaking classified government documents was commuted by former President Barack Obama, Chelsea Manning summed up her motivation in an interview with The New York Times Magazine: “I wanted people to see what I was seeing.” Tim Travers Hawkins digs into the life of Manning, an Army analyst at the time she released  the documents to WikiLeaks in 2010. This new documentary focuses on the period after her sentence is commuted. “Manning’s turbulent, remarkable story — including a troubled Oklahoma childhood with heavy-drinking parents, two suicide attempts and seven years in an all-male prison while transitioning to a woman — is a nonfiction filmmaker’s dream,” Jeannette Catsoulis wrote in her review for The Times. “Hawkins, however, seems content to hover on its surface, a decision that, depending on your viewpoint, feels either cowardly or humane.”

headline: What to Watch Friday at the French Open
abstract: If the threatening skies show mercy, all four singles semifinals will be played. Only one of them involves Roger Federer and Rafael Nadal.
lead_paragraph: The only top-25 player to reach the women’s semifinals, the Australian Barty has devoured American opposition, beating four players from the U.S. in her five previous rounds. She will have a chance for a fifth on Suzanne Lenglen Court (5 a.m. Eastern) against Amanda Anisimova, a New Jersey-born 17-year-old who defeated the defending champion Simona Halep in the quarterfinals Thursday. Barty, the No. 8 seed, had a 2-5 record at this tournament before this year, but suddenly finds herself the oddsmakers’ favorite to win the title.

headline: On Politics: Biden Reverses Hyde Stance
abstract: The Hyde Amendment bans most federal funding for abortion, and Mr. Biden’s support had been subject of criticism from fellow Democrats.
lead_paragraph: Good Friday morning. Here are some of the stories making news in Washington and politics today.

headline: Stephen Colbert Teases G.O.P. for ‘Flirting With Rebellion’ Against Trump
abstract: The next step could be “a dalliance with integrity” or even “a drunken hookup with defending the Constitution,” the “Late Show” host said.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. If you’re interested in hearing from The Times regularly about great TV, sign up for our Watching newsletter and get recommendations straight to your inbox.

headline: Rafael Nadal Owns Roger Federer at Roland Garros
abstract: The longtime rivals, who meet in the semifinals on Friday, have played five other times at the French Open. Here’s how The Times covered those matches.
lead_paragraph: On Friday, tennis fans will be treated to the 39th match between Rafael Nadal and Roger Federer. Nadal holds a 23-15 edge, most of his advantage coming from his 13-2 mark on clay. Though Nadal, 33, has lost their last five meetings, Federer, 37, has never beaten him at the French Open. Federer, in fact, has won only four of the 19 sets they have played at Roland Garros.

headline: Belmont Stakes Experts’ Picks: Who Will Win?
abstract: Joe Drape and Melissa Hoppert weigh in on the contenders for the 151st Belmont Stakes on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: The 151st running of the Belmont Stakes will signify the end of a bizarre Triple Crown season in which Maximum Security was disqualified as the winner of the Kentucky Derby for interference; the horse who was awarded the victory, Country House, skipped the second leg; and a riderless horse, not the winner, War of Will, dominated headlines in the Preakness Stakes.

lead_paragraph: In a land where trucks often start at large and climb to supersize, the new hot thing is not an overpowered dreadnought but a midsize pickup from Jeep.

headline: How Jim Jarmusch Made an All-Star Indie Zombie Movie
abstract: For “The Dead Don’t Die,” the writer-director lured his posse of preternaturally cool actors. Then he killed them off.
lead_paragraph: The writer-director Jim Jarmusch is not a zombie buff “as much as a vampire appreciator,” he said. (See: his 2014 film “Only Lovers Left Alive.”) But he does genuflect at the altar of George A. Romero, whose oeuvre inspired Jarmusch’s latest, “The Dead Don’t Die,” a self-aware dark zombie comedy. It features a cast of Jarmusch all-stars, led by Bill Murray, Adam Driver and Chloë Sevigny as small-town cops, along with Tilda Swinton as a samurai-wielding Scottish mortician. Iggy Pop is a shirtless zombie and Tom Waits is the extravagantly bearded Hermit Bob.

abstract: The artist’s surreal installation is the talk of the Venice Biennale.

headline: He’s Running for President. His Allies Don’t Care.
abstract: As Mayor Bill de Blasio forges ahead with his improbable presidential bid, endorsements seem hard to come by.
lead_paragraph: This week, Bill de Blasio’s presidential campaign, a project that has generated all the promise and enthusiasm of an afternoon in small-claims court, announced that its candidate had received his first endorsements. You might assume that those endorsements came from local elected officials, because that is so often the way of things. They did not. Beto O’Rourke, he of bass guitars and El Paso, has gained more support from New York congressional representatives in his own presidential bid than the mayor of New York City.

headline: What a Reporter Learned From a Cherokee Family
keywords: ['Families and Family Life', 'Cherokee Indians', 'ADOPTIONS', 'Native Americans', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Foster Care']
abstract: Jan Hoffman, a reporter for The Times, traveled to Oklahoma to meet with a Native family who adopts Native children from foster care.
lead_paragraph: After spending time with Chad and Dr. Jennifer Brackeen in a suburb of Fort Worth, I felt I could tell their story about why they are challenging a 40-year-old law that may block them from adopting two Native American children. The Indian Child Welfare Act, in place since 1978, gives preference to Native families who want to adopt Native children through a state’s foster care system. Neither Brackeen is Native American.

headline: The Widows of the Plaza Hotel
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Widows and Widowers', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)']
abstract: Before Eloise became known as the luxury hotel’s most famous guest, a host of wealthy dowagers held court there.
lead_paragraph: The Plaza Hotel’s best known resident may be a fictional 6-year-old named Eloise, but from the moment the imposing French chateau-style structure opened in 1907 until well into the 1980s, it was known for a series of real-life wealthy dowagers who made it their home.

headline: For the Tweens In These Graphic Novels, Friendship Is The Hardest Test Of All
abstract: The characters in Ryan Andrews’s “This Was Our Pact” and Kayla Miller’s “Camp” learn to master the mysterious codes of conduct and ever-changing loyalties of middle school.
lead_paragraph: Middle school is fraught with shifting dynamics. As tweens drift away from adults, they find themselves in the thorny world of friendship, with its ever-changing loyalties, mysterious codes of conduct, and complicated social structure. Middle-grade literature has become increasingly sophisticated in recent years, but even among all the new genres, titles and characters, one element is forever universal: the power of friendship, for better and worse.

headline: A Cleveland River Once Oozed and Burned. It’s Now a Hot Spot.
abstract: The Cuyahoga River burst into flames for the last time in 1969. As tourism climbs, the city celebrates the river’s rebound 50 years later.
lead_paragraph: A misconception still clings to Cleveland and it comes down to three words: river on fire. From 1868 to 1969, the polluted Cuyahoga River, which cleaves Cleveland into east and west, caught fire 13 times. In 1969, a photo in Time magazine dramatically showed a brave little fire department boat battling a wall of angry flames.

headline: How NYC Taxi Drivers Bought Medallions and Became Victims of a Reckless Lending Scheme
keywords: ['Taxicabs and Taxicab Drivers', 'Television', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'United States Economy']
abstract: The taxi industry’s rigged system left drivers hopeless and in financial ruin.
lead_paragraph: How does a New York City taxi driver who makes about $22,000 a year get a loan for almost $1 million? Our reporters investigating the taxi industry for “The Weekly” found that a group of under-regulated industry leaders created a financial bubble in the market for medallions, the permits that let drivers own their own cab. Bankers, brokers, fleet owners and even city officials artificially inflated the prices of medallions and reaped huge profits by steering immigrant drivers into reckless loans.

headline: Why Should Immigrants ‘Respect Our Borders’? The West Never Respected Theirs
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Remittances', 'Reparations', 'Third World and Developing Countries', 'Colonization', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Immigration quotas should be based on how much the host country has ruined other countries.
lead_paragraph: There is a lot of debate these days about whether the United States owes its African-American citizens reparations for slavery. It does. But there is a far bigger bill that the United States and Europe have run up: what they owe to other countries for their colonial adventures, for the wars they imposed on them, for the inequality they have built into the world order, for the excess carbon they have dumped into the atmosphere.

headline: Rebel Girls
abstract: And a few boys, too. When riot grrrl pioneers Bikini Kill played their first New York show in 22 years, these are the fans who showed up — one as early as noon and two who hadn’t told their parents. Hi mom and dad!
lead_paragraph: If the end of this decade is memorialized as a time when women got really angry, and then even angrier, the music of Bikini Kill could provide the soundtrack.

abstract: The writer Simon Kinberg narrates a sequence from his directing debut in the X-Men franchise.
lead_paragraph: In “Anatomy of a Scene,” we ask directors to reveal the secrets that go into making key scenes in their movies. See new episodes in the series each Friday. You can also watch our collection of more than 150 videos on YouTube and subscribe to our YouTube channel.

headline: Australian Who Tested Rockets on His Farm for ISIS Gets 9-Year Sentence
keywords: ['Terrorism', 'Computer Security', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Social Media']
abstract: Prosecutors said Haisem Zahab sent his findings to the Islamic State through an encrypted messaging app.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — An Australian electrician who tested rockets and propellants on his farm and sent his findings to the Islamic State through an encrypted app was sentenced to nine years in prison on Friday by a court in Australia.

headline: The Week in Tech: What Not to Expect From Big Tech’s Antitrust Showdown

abstract: The legal action against Silicon Valley’s giants will be long, difficult, uncertain and, for some people, disappointing.
lead_paragraph: Each week, we review the week’s news, offering analysis about the most important developments in the tech industry. Want this newsletter in your inbox? Sign up here.

headline: Why Is Picking a Paint Color So Hard?
abstract: With endless options, picking the perfect paint color can be overwhelming and feel impossible. Now, companies are helping to make the choices for us.
lead_paragraph: By the time the workers arrived to paint my living and dining rooms, I thought I had it all figured out. I’d spent a solid month sampling colors, so my walls now looked like some strange art project, riddled with stripes of suspiciously similar hues.

headline: Among Some Hate Groups, Porn Is Viewed as a Conspiracy
abstract: Buried in the manifestos of some extremists are attacks on the porn industry, which is blamed for their own struggles and what they perceive as society’s decline.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Buried in the anti-Semitic manifesto of the 19-year-old man who recently opened fire in a synagogue near San Diego is a sentence in which he blames Jews for “causing many to fall into sin with their role in peddling pornography.”

headline: Captain in Budapest Cruise Accident Was Involved in Earlier Boat Crash
keywords: ['Maritime Accidents and Safety', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Accidents and Safety', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Cruises', 'Boats and Boating']
abstract: The captain of the Viking Sigyn, which rammed a smaller tourist boat last week, killing several South Korean tourists, was on a ship that collided with an oil tanker in the Netherlands in April.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The captain of a river cruise ship involved in a deadly accident on the Danube River in Budapest last week was previously involved in a boat collision in the Netherlands in April, prosecutors in Hungary said on Friday.

keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Somali-Americans']

headline: 2019 French Open: Barty and Vondrousova Make the Women’s Final
abstract: Marketa Vondrousova lost the first 10 points against Johanna Konta before claiming a win. Ashleigh Barty recovered from an early collapse to beat Amanda Anisimova.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Under mostly cooperative gray skies and in front of small but enthusiastic crowds at Roland Garros’s secondary stadiums on Friday, Ashleigh Barty and Marketa Vondrousova booked spots in the French Open final, surviving blustery switches in momentum and winds.
