headline: Barnes & Noble Is Sold to Hedge Fund After a Tumultuous Year
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Book Trade and Publishing', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: The bookstore chain’s future was the subject of speculation for months before the hedge fund said it would buy it for $638 million.
lead_paragraph: Barnes & Noble has been acquired by the hedge fund Elliott Advisors for $638 million, a move that has momentarily calmed fears among publishers and agents that the largest bookstore chain in the United States might collapse after one of the most tumultuous periods in its history.

headline: For China’s Leading Investigative Reporter, Enough Is Enough
abstract: Liu Wanyong, “the most important figure in investigative journalism,” has quit the profession. “News is not like news anymore,” he says.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Late at night, a senior police officer guided Liu Wanyong, then a budding investigative journalist, through the inner sanctum of one of the scariest domains in China, the Ministry of Public Security.

headline: At the Newly Opened Hudson Yards, More Closed Sales
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Luxury Goods and Services', 'ARCHITECTURE']
abstract: The month’s biggest purchase, however, was once again at 220 Central Park South.
lead_paragraph: Manhattan’s latest crop of new luxury developments continues to attract a steady stream of buyers.

headline: The Job Market Isn’t as Strong as It Seemed. The Fed Needs to Pay Attention.
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'United States Economy', 'Interest Rates', 'Recession and Depression', 'Wages and Salaries']
abstract: The clearest evidence yet that the economic slowdown isn’t a figment of the bond market’s imagination.
lead_paragraph: As of 8:29 a.m. Friday, things were shaping up for the Federal Reserve to face a real conundrum at its policy meeting in less than two weeks.

headline: Free Outdoor Movies in New York City in August
abstract: Survey the myriad available options and find a movie night that appeals to you.
lead_paragraph: While some swampy summer days can send New Yorkers running to the nearest air-conditioned movie theater, the evenings often make reveling in the park a splendid alternative. Embracing the delight of watching recent and classic films in the great outdoors, New York offers an abundance of free, outdoor movie screenings. We’re here to help you cull the long list of options and find the right movie night for your preferences and location.

headline: Nepal Seeks Help Identifying Bodies Found on Mount Everest
abstract: Four corpses were removed from the mountain this season, one of the deadliest ever. It’s unclear when the climbers died, and some of the bodies are unrecognizable, Nepalese officials said.
lead_paragraph: KATHMANDU, Nepal — Nepalese officials on Friday asked for help in identifying four bodies that were recovered from Mount Everest this climbing season, one of the deadliest yet.

headline: Columbine High School Could Be Torn Down to Deter Copycats
keywords: ['School Shootings and Armed Attacks', 'Demolition', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: Calling the school “a source of inspiration” for potential gun violence, the school superintendent has suggested razing the site of the horrific 1999 shooting.
lead_paragraph: LITTLETON, Colo. — In the 20 years since the massacre at Columbine High School, the building has become a macabre tourist attraction for the curious and the obsessed. They travel from as far as Brazil or Japan, hoping to walk the halls, to look for the two teenage gunmen’s lockers. They come every day, and more come with each passing year.

headline: They Say You Can’t Go Home Again. Laura Linney Just Did.
abstract: She talks about revisiting Armistead Maupin’s “Tales of the City” for a fourth time, and the potential impact of Georgia’s abortion bill on the production of Netflix’s “Ozark.”
lead_paragraph: After starring in three adaptations of the much-beloved “Tales of the City” since 1993, Laura Linney was overflowing with memories — of her first television series, the evolving L.G.B.T.Q. community that embraced it and her friendship with Armistead Maupin, on whose novels the show were based.

headline: How They Made Jessica Chastain Look Not Quite Human in ‘Dark Phoenix’
abstract: The filmmakers behind the latest movie in the “X-Men” franchise created the uncanny valley but with a real person.
lead_paragraph: One scene in “Dark Phoenix” has a woman stepping away from her dinner party to tend to a barking dog. When she returns, she seems a bit … off. The color has drained from her face and she’s moving as if her own body is alien to her. That woman is played by Jessica Chastain, and her body has indeed been snatched by an alien named Smith, also played by Chastain.

headline: Before She Wrote Cookbooks, Maida Heatter Created Hit Recipes for The Times
abstract: This triple-layer chocolate torte, the newspaper’s most requested dessert in 1972, was just one of the recipes developed by the legendary author, who died on Thursday at 102.
lead_paragraph: Maida Heatter made her chocolate mousse torte 20 times before she deemed it good enough to be published in The New York Times in May 1972.

headline: What to Cook This Weekend
abstract: Beets! Make the vegetal, dark-red beet dip that Tejal Rao adapted from Botanica in Los Angeles, a perfect meal with labneh and lots of warm pita.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. Tejal Rao wrote about beets for The Times this week, and about a deeply vegetal, dark-red beet dip (above) that she adapted from one served at Botanica, a vegetable-focused restaurant in the Silver Lake neighborhood of Los Angeles. What I love about the recipe is that while you certainly could make it with a bunch of fancy little heirloom beets from the farmers’ market, each one a delicate rose, Tejal found it just as good with a sturdy old commodity beet from the supermarket, pulverized in a blender with pomegranate molasses, lemon juice, walnuts, lots of olive oil and a hit of chile flakes.

headline: The Warriors’ Room Where It Happens
abstract: Golden State’s video room is the team’s nerve center.
lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — The video room at the Golden State Warriors’ practice facility has the general dimensions and, for much of the season, the atmospheric conditions of an industrial-size freezer. There is enough space for a couple of desks, some computer monitors, an assortment of sneakers and an exposed bundle of cables that must be some sort of fire hazard.

headline: Stedelijk Museum Amsterdam Names Rein Wolfs Its New Director
abstract: The appointment ends a year-and-a-half vacancy at the top of one of Europe’s leading modern art museums.
lead_paragraph: The Stedelijk Museum Amsterdam, the most significant museum of modern art in the Netherlands, named the Dutch curator Rein Wolfs as its new director on Friday. Mr. Wolfs, 58, is currently director of the Bundeskunsthalle, an exhibition space in Bonn, Germany.

headline: Warning of ‘Pig Zero’: One Drugmaker’s Push to Sell More Antibiotics
abstract: Overuse of antibiotics in livestock has given rise to drug-resistant germs. Drugmakers say they want to be part of the solution. But a recent campaign urged farmers to administer the drugs to healthy animals daily.
lead_paragraph: Facing a surge in drug-resistant infections, the World Health Organization issued a plea to farmers two years ago: “Stop using antibiotics in healthy animals.”

headline: The Roots of Big Tech Run Disturbingly Deep
keywords: ['Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Science and Technology', 'Social Media']
abstract: Out of more than 350 mergers by Facebook or Google, none raised serious regulatory concerns. They should have.
lead_paragraph: Out of more than 350 mergers by Facebook or Google, none raised serious regulatory concerns. They should have.

headline: Spying on Children Won’t Keep Them Safe
keywords: ['School Shootings and Armed Attacks', 'Education (K-12)', 'Security and Warning Systems', 'Computer Vision', 'Face']
abstract: This week my daughter’s school became the first in the nation to pilot facial-recognition software. The technology’s potential is chilling.
lead_paragraph: LOCKPORT, N.Y. — I have a 16-year-old daughter, and like every parent in the United States today, I worry about her safety when she’s in school. But here in Western New York’s Lockport City School District, those fears have led to a wasteful and dangerous experiment.

headline: Parenthood Is Still Uneven, but an Hour a Day Could Help
abstract: Men need to spend at least 50 more minutes a day on domestic duties — and women, 50 minutes less — a new report finds.
lead_paragraph: You’re reading In Her Words, where women rule the headlines.

headline: Wild Salmon Season Is Here
abstract: Brilliant red, mildly sweet and velvety, it may be more expensive than its farmed counterpart, but it’s so much finer.
lead_paragraph: Fish, like everything else we eat, is seasonal. I generally don’t eat tomatoes or peppers out of season. Similarly, I prefer to wait for salmon season, which usually runs from late spring through late summer. Call me a snob, but farmed salmon doesn’t hold a candle to the real thing. Consider it an annual splurge.

headline: Fearing China’s Rule, Hong Kong Residents Resist Extradition Plan
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Extradition', 'Political Prisoners', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Hong Kong Protests (2019)']
abstract: The fight against the proposal has become the most serious showdown between the public and the authorities since the Umbrella protests in 2014 demanding free elections.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Politicians have staged sit-ins and exchanged blows in the legislature. Nurses, high school teachers and even anime fans have organized petitions. And the authorities are bracing for protests on Sunday that could be the largest since the pro-democracy Umbrella Movement shut down parts of Hong Kong five years ago.

headline: Case Against Boris Johnson Over Brexit Claims Dismissed in U.K. Court
keywords: ['Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)', 'Politics and Government', 'Referendums']
abstract: Britain’s High Court did not give a reason for scrapping the case against the front-runner to replace Theresa May as prime minister.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Britain’s High Court on Friday threw out an attempt to prosecute Boris Johnson, the top contender to replace Theresa May as prime minister, over accusations that he lied to the public during the 2016 referendum on Brexit.

headline: Want to Buy a Ticket to the Space Station? NASA Says Soon You Can
keywords: ['International Space Station', 'Space and Astronomy', 'Space Stations', 'Private Spaceflight']
abstract: NASA plans to open the International Space Station to commercial business, including tourism. But the tickets won’t be cheap.
lead_paragraph: Becoming a NASA astronaut is far harder than getting into Harvard, but soon, ordinary people — at least rich ones with tens of millions of dollars to blow on a big vacation — will be able to buy a rocket ride into orbit.

headline: Russian Reporter Who Exposed Moscow Graft Is Arrested on Drug Charges
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Corruption (Institutional)', 'Politics and Government', 'Social Media']
abstract: The police announced the detention of Ivan Golunov, an investigative journalist, and later charged him with selling a “large amount” of drugs, a common method to silence independent voices.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — The police in Moscow on Friday announced the detention of an investigative journalist on drug charges, in what appeared to be the latest official effort to muzzle independent voices in Russia.

headline: The Death of Fashion Diplomacy
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'United States Politics and Government', 'First Ladies (US)', 'your-feed-fashion']
abstract: White-tie faux pas? Hat tricks? It’s time we stopped expecting the Trumps to play by any of the old rules.
lead_paragraph: So the Trump state visit to the United Kingdom, with its Irish interlude and European D-Day sojourn, full of carefully choreographed, performative posturing, has come to an end.

headline: Prada: Spring 2020

lead_paragraph: Prada Spring 2020 Collection.

headline: How A.I. Could Be Weaponized to Spread Disinformation
abstract: The world’s top artificial intelligence labs are honing technology that can mimic how humans write, which could one day help disinformation campaigns go undetected by generating huge amounts of subtly different messages.
lead_paragraph: The world’s top artificial intelligence labs are honing technology that can mimic how humans write, which could one day help disinformation campaigns go undetected by generating huge amounts of subtly different messages.

headline: Maida Heatter, Cookbook Writer and the ‘Queen of Cake,’ Dies at 102
abstract: Her many cookbooks were full of sinful recipes, not only for cakes but also for cookies, pies, tortes and more.
lead_paragraph: Maida Heatter, whose cookbooks with recipes for star-spangled banana cake, brown sugar icing and other dessert fare earned her the nickname “the Queen of Cake,” died on Thursday at her home in Miami Beach. She was 102.

headline: One-Pot Wonders
abstract: These dishes are gifts to those sink soldiers out there, easily made in a single pot or pan.
lead_paragraph: Hi and welcome to Five Weeknight Dishes. Let’s talk for a minute about doing the dishes. There’s a Letter of Recommendation in The Times Magazine this week about washing dishes, and the beauty that comes in surrendering to ordinary tasks, written by my old friend Mike Powell.

headline: Pasta Salads to Swoon Over (No, Really)
abstract: Make better pasta salad, because you can.
lead_paragraph: When was the last time a pasta salad made you swoon?

headline: A Piece of Myanmar in Queens
abstract: Asian Bowl’s name is reassuringly vague, but on the table is a more singular story: Burmese dishes like gin thoke and mohinga.
lead_paragraph: Asian Bowl’s name is reassuringly vague, but on the table is a more singular story: Burmese dishes like gin thoke and mohinga.

headline: Burmese, Unassuming but So Inviting, at Asian Bowl
abstract: It’s easy to pass this Forest Hills, Queens, storefront by, but inside the chef, Aye Thida, shares what she’s long cooked at home.
lead_paragraph: It would be so easy to pass this storefront by, here on a slant off the 67th Avenue stop in Forest Hills, Queens. The name is reassuringly vague — there might well be an Asian Bowl in every city across the United States — giving chef and diner alike license to roam.

headline: A Team Tells Its Leader What It Really Thinks
abstract: What would your employees say about your company? The President of U.S. Operations for Brompton Bicycle finds out.
lead_paragraph: What would your employees say about your company? The President of U.S. Operations for Brompton Bicycle finds out.

headline: Take the 7-Day Love Challenge
abstract: Get a week’s worth of simple, science-based steps you can take to help foster a deeper connection between you and your partner. Learn a bit more about each other and discover new ways to strengthen your bond.
lead_paragraph: Get a week’s worth of simple, science-based steps you can take to help foster a deeper connection between you and your partner. Learn a bit more about each other and discover new ways to strengthen your bond.

headline: Opera Lives in Cycles
abstract: From Wagner on, composers have wrestled with uniting grandeur and depth in arcs over multiple works.
lead_paragraph: AMSTERDAM — When Friedrich Nietzsche turned his pen on his onetime friend, Richard Wagner, his overarching critique was that grandeur shouldn’t be mistaken for depth. He worried about the marketplace consequences of blockbusters blotting out substance, not unlike today’s film reviewers warily watching the latest Avengers movie.

headline: Two Women, Divided by Opportunity
abstract: Circumstances of birth may be a lottery, but we all have a responsibility to level the playing field for the underprivileged.
lead_paragraph: EXCHIMAL, Guatemala — When I was 15, I started to learn how to drive a car.

headline: Five Arrested in London Bus Attack on Two Lesbians
abstract: The Metropolitan Police said five teenagers were arrested after two women reported being assaulted, harassed and robbed on a bus by men who had tried to make the couple kiss.
lead_paragraph: The British police said Saturday that they had made five arrests in the case of what they called a homophobic attack on two women who were assaulted and robbed on the deserted top deck of a double-decker bus in North London last month.

headline: University of Alabama Returns Largest-Ever Gift to Donor
abstract: Tensions had publicly bubbled up in recent weeks, with Hugh F. Culverhouse Jr. reportedly dictating how he wanted his $21.5 million donation spent.
lead_paragraph: Nine months ago, a Florida real estate mogul’s pledge to donate $26.5 million to the University of Alabama — the most generous gift in the school’s 188-year history — was announced with great enthusiasm and fanfare. On Friday, the money he had given so far — some $21.5 million — was unceremoniously returned via wire transfer and a campus work crew was removing the businessman’s name from the law school that had been named in his honor.

headline: Robert Earle, 93, Moderator of TV’s ‘College Bowl,’ Is Dead
abstract: In the 1960s he was the man asking tough questions to teams of college students in a fast-paced test of knowledge.
lead_paragraph: Robert Earle, who tested the wits of hundreds of students and countless television viewers as moderator of the long-running quiz show “The General Electric College Bowl,” died on Wednesday in Ithaca, N.Y. He was 93.

headline: For War of Will, the Belmont Is About What Might Have Been
keywords: ['Horse Racing', 'Maximum Security (Race Horse)', 'Triple Crown (Horse Racing)', 'Belmont Stakes']
abstract: The colt was gaining ground before getting cut off in the Kentucky Derby then won the Preakness.
lead_paragraph: It has been a strange Triple Crown season, one that kicked off with the confusing and disputed disqualification of the apparent Kentucky Derby champion Maximum Security and will end Saturday with the 151st running of the Belmont Stakes.

headline: The Playlist: Sheryl Crow’s All-Star Girl Gang, and 12 More New Songs
abstract: Hear tracks by Bon Iver, Future, Avicii, Jai Paul and others.
lead_paragraph: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new songs and videos. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage.

headline: Trump Says He and Queen Elizabeth II ‘Had a Great Time’
abstract: “I feel I know her so well right now, and she certainly knows me well,” President Trump said of the British monarch in an interview with Fox News.
lead_paragraph: When President Trump visited Britain in 2018 and met Queen Elizabeth II, he caused a social media stir by walking in front of the British monarch as they inspected her honor guard, forcing her to step around him — a breach of protocol.

headline: A #MeToo Wave Hits Global Soccer as the Women’s World Cup Begins
abstract: Allegations of sexual misconduct against influential men have been made in several countries and include an accusation against a top-ranking official in world soccer’s governing body.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — As world soccer opens its most important championship for women this week, it is confronting a range of accusations that men with influence over women in the sport repeatedly have used their positions to harass or abuse them.

headline: Harvey Fierstein on the Backstage Nests of Broadway
abstract: The writer and actor describes how he fashions his dressing rooms into “explosions of color and life.”
lead_paragraph: Animals are nesters and, as Mel Brooks noted, “If you don’t think actors are animals, you’ve never eaten with one.”

abstract: The writer recalls his experiences in China before the massacre.

headline: Broadway Stars Getting Ready, Then and Now
abstract: Six visits to six theaters, with decades between them, but the energy backstage is a constant.
lead_paragraph: Even as New York hurtles into the future, many of its celebrated theaters have stayed the same. And that allows entertainers to commune with each other across decades.

headline: The Dressing Rooms of Broadway: 33 Photos Over Nearly a Century
abstract: For decades, our photographers have gotten intimate access backstage. Peek in as they capture stars, before the show and before the mirror.
lead_paragraph: About the last thing a dressing room is is the room where actors get dressed.

headline: Research on Fetal Tissue
abstract: A reader says blocking such research “will lead to more deaths, not more life.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Tyler, the Creator and Kevin Abstract, Self-Invented Hip-Hop Confessionalists
abstract: New albums from two genre innovators cut to the emotional quick.
lead_paragraph: The evolution of Tyler, the Creator from potty-mouth provocateur to aesthetic North Star has been one of this decade’s most vivid transformations, though maybe among its least surprising. Following in the footsteps of Kanye West and Pharrell Williams, he understood from his earliest incarnation that hip-hop was no longer strictly music, but also style, attitude and disruption.

headline: The Met Opera Cuts Back on Screen Time for Berlioz Next Season
abstract: Citing “technical demands,” the company will replace its revival of a video-heavy production of Berlioz’s “La Damnation de Faust” with concert performances.
lead_paragraph: This season, defying the predictions of some operagoers, the Metropolitan Opera managed to tame its technologically temperamental Robert Lepage production of Wagner’s “Ring” cycle, and to largely quiet its mammoth set of rotating planks, designed by Carl Fillion.

headline: Review: A Dark, Modern Version of Beethoven’s Only Opera
abstract: David Lang’s “Prisoner of the State,” a streamlined, seething updating of “Fidelio,” ends the New York Philharmonic’s season on a high note.
lead_paragraph: For 40 years the composer David Lang had toyed with writing his own version of Beethoven’s “Fidelio.” Why? Well, why not? It’s inspiring when a living composer, rather than being intimidated by the work of a past master, pays homage to it, even critiques it, by writing a contemporary version.

headline: The Role of Men in the Debate Over Abortion
keywords: ['ABORTION', 'Pregnancy and Childbirth', 'Men and Boys', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: “Men get off scot-free,” writes a woman. Men should be excused from supporting a child a woman chooses to have against his wishes, writes a man.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: In Chicago’s Vibrant Theater Scene, Two Tales of One City
abstract: A huge new literary adaptation and a tiny old melodrama both find a place in a healthy cultural ecosystem.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Going to the theater while traveling can feel a lot like mall shopping: Many of the offerings look strangely familiar. The same shows, or ones quite similar, keep turning up everywhere, as if they were Cinnabons.

headline: France Opens Women’s World Cup With Rout of South Korea
abstract: Live updates and analysis from the opening match of the 2019 Women’s World Cup: France vs. Korea.
lead_paragraph: France opened a home World Cup that it hopes to win on Friday with a performance that will raise hopes that it is up to the task. Wendie Renard’s two goals, bookended by an early strike by Eugénie Le Sommer and a late one by Amandine Henry, led France to a 4-0 victory over South Korea at the Parc des Princes in Paris.

headline: Stormy Daniels Isn’t the First Sex Worker to Go Into Comedy
abstract: Stand-ups who hail from adult films and strip clubs say sex and humor are a natural fit.
lead_paragraph: When Stormy Daniels announced her first gig as a stand-up comic in March, some comedians recoiled. Though news reports suggested her appearances were more akin to book-tour stops than comedy shows, the fact that the pornographic film star was getting headlining gigs on her first try rankled. After all, Daniels was in the news because she claimed to have an affair with the president, a dalliance he denied.

headline: The Elderly Are Getting Complex Surgeries. Often It Doesn’t End Well.
abstract: Complication rates are high among the oldest patients. Now a surgeons’ group will propose standards for hospitals operating on the elderly.
lead_paragraph: People over 65 represent roughly 16 percent of the American population, but account for 40 percent of patients undergoing surgery in hospitals — and probably more than half of all surgical procedures.

headline: One Small Tweet for Trump, One Giant Question for NASA’s Moon Plans
keywords: ['Moon', 'Space and Astronomy', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: A tweet by the president clashed with earlier statements, including his own, about a renewed focus on moon exploration.
lead_paragraph: For months the Trump administration has been proclaiming an Apollo-like urgency to return astronauts to the moon within five years. On Friday, President Trump appeared to suggest on Twitter that NASA was focusing on the wrong goal.

headline: Caleel Harris, a Young Star of ‘When They See Us,’ About the Central Park Five
abstract: The teenage actor has already worked with Ava DuVernay and J.J. Abrams.

headline: What to Do in New York This Weekend: MoMA and the Tonys
abstract: Also “Late Night” and “The Last Black Man in San Francisco” arrive in theaters, and “Big Little Lies” returns for a second season.
lead_paragraph: With the museum closing on June 15 for a four-month renovation, our critics assess the challenges that lie ahead, pay homage to favorite works and catch up with shows. Roberta Smith, Holland Cotter, Michael Kimmelman and our other critics fanned out, took stock and reported back. Read our package, and then use it as a guide when you visit the museum before it shuts down next weekend.

headline: Rafael Nadal (Again) and the Wind Confound Roger Federer at the French Open
abstract: In their much-anticipated semifinal, the amicable rivals got the chance to experience something new — gust after gust of shot-altering wind.

headline: One Photographer’s Tribute to English Roses
abstract: For his latest book, the British photographer Luke Stephenson captured flowers bred by the esteemed rosarian David Austin.
lead_paragraph: For his latest book, the British photographer Luke Stephenson captured flowers bred by the esteemed rosarian David Austin.

headline: T Suggests: English Roses, a Lost Film by Claire Denis and More
abstract: A roundup of things our editors — and a few contributors — are excited about in a given week.
lead_paragraph: The photographer Luke Stephenson is a self-proclaimed nosy person. His curiosity has led him to capture some fairly esoteric subjects, like the parakeets (“budgies”) raised competitively among a subset of mostly older male Britons, and something called the “Clown Egg Register,” a collection of over 250 eggs painted to look like clowns and owned by Clowns International, a society established in London over half a century ago. Of his anthropological approach, Stephenson explains, “I really enjoy the challenge of discovering the best people to speak to who can open the right doors.” Recently, he trained his lens on the English rose, a flower bred by the renowned British horticulturist David Austin in the 1960s. Austin died earlier this year, but today, more than 150 strains of his English rose are commercially available, each with a name selected by Austin himself. “David was always very fussy about the names he chose for his roses,” explains Michael Marriott, the senior rosarian at David Austin Roses. “He used to say that giving a rose a bad name was the easiest way to kill it. He liked to choose names that were very English, names that immediately evoked Britishness.” The Anne Boleyn, the Dame Judi Dench and the Maid Marion are just a few of the varieties that appear in Stephenson’s new book, “The English Rose.” Each flower is documented in Stephenson’s signature style — a single specimen against a brightly colored backdrop — creating a pop version of an 18th-century nature Wunderkammer. Stephenson continues to focus on singularities of British culture because, he says, “I have lived on this little island all my life, and I like to think I understand it, so I seek out these little oddities. I want to discover more.” “The English Rose” is available to purchase at lukestephenson.com, with prints from the series available at the Photographers’ Gallery, 16-18 Ramillies Street, London, thephotographersgallery.org. — JAMIE SIMS

headline: New Election Security Bills Face a One-Man Roadblock: Mitch McConnell

headline: Anthony Bourdain, in Your Words
abstract: A year after Mr. Bourdain’s death, we’re looking back at what readers at the time had to say about the iconoclastic chef and crusader for food justice.
lead_paragraph: Anthony Bourdain’s death on June 8, 2018, prompted an outpouring of comments from readers of his obituary in The New York Times. They recalled episodes of his television show, “Parts Unknown,” on CNN; his lacerating restaurant book “Kitchen Confidential;” his support of the #MeToo movement; and his example as a culinary — and cultural — adventurer. They expressed anguish at the inner torment that had led him to take his own life, and urged others in similar straits to seek help. A selection of reader comments, excerpted and lightly edited, follows.

The pair split the two opening sets. The match will resume at noon local time (6 a.m. Eastern). The winner will be significantly less rested for the final than Rafael Nadal, who beat Roger Federer in straight sets earlier Friday in somewhat less vexing wind.

headline: What’s on TV Saturday: ‘A Star Is Born’ and ‘The Black Godfather’
abstract: “A Star Is Born” makes its television debut on HBO. And a documentary about Clarence Avant comes to Netflix.
lead_paragraph: A STAR IS BORN (2018) 8 p.m. on HBO; stream on HBO platforms. In the latest and fourth remake of this film, Bradley Cooper plays Jackson Maine, an alcoholic country-rock star, who meets Ally Campana (Lady Gaga), a waitress with a powerful voice and a gift for songwriting. Throughout the film, co-written and directed by Cooper, we watch the two collaborate and fall in love. But as Ally’s music career soars, Jackson’s falters. The film was chosen as a New York Times Critic’s Pick by Manohla Dargis, who wrote in her review: “Like its finest antecedents, it wrings tears from its romance and thrills from a steadfast belief in old-fashioned, big-feeling cinema. That it’s also a perverse fantasy about men, women, love and sacrifice makes it all the better.”

headline: Even as Floods Worsen With Climate Change, Fewer People Insure Against Disaster
keywords: ['Global Warming', 'Environment', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Carbon Dioxide', 'Floods', 'Flood Insurance', 'Disasters and Emergencies']
abstract: The Midwest floods have highlighted a gap in disaster readiness: Fewer Americans are buying flood insurance, even as climate change increases their risk.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Despite years of devastating flooding and hurricanes, the number of Americans with flood insurance remains well below its level a decade ago, undermining the nation’s ability to cope with disasters just as climate change makes them more frequent and severe.In some of the states hardest-hit by the recent brutal flooding in the Midwest, the number of federal flood insurance policies has dropped by at least one-third since 2011. As a result, in Nebraska, Illinois and Missouri, the share of homes in floodplains that have flood insurance is now 15 percent or less.

lead_paragraph: Yashreeka Zehra Huq and Elika Ruth Cokely were married June 7. Ezinne M. Okpo, the mutual friend who introduced the couple, officiated at the Green Building in Brooklyn, having become a Universal Life minister for this event. On June 9, Maheen Kaleem, another friend, is to lead a ceremony incorporating Bangladeshi traditions at the W Loft, also in Brooklyn.

headline: Youths! Go Listen to Your Elders!
abstract: A little neighborly conversation can go a long, long way.
lead_paragraph: On a sunny Sunday afternoon, I was practicing golf with my daughters in the front yard when we saw an older man slowly making his way out of his house, two doors down, and over to us. I heard the screen door clang behind him and watched as the small, hunched figure plodded from his doorway down the steps to the sidewalk, clutching the guardrail, and then in our direction.

headline: They See It. They Like It. They Want It. They Rent It.
keywords: ['Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Furniture', 'Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Luxury Goods and Services', 'Shopping and Retail']
abstract: Owning nothing is now a luxury, thanks to a number of subscription start-ups.
lead_paragraph: Many young American urbanites have resigned themselves to a life of non-ownership, abandoning the dream of their parents and grandparents and great-grandparents before them, often out of financial necessity. But renting isn’t just a matter of necessity these days. It’s become almost posh.

headline: The Mueller Report Sounded the Alarm on Election Attacks. Will Congress Act?
keywords: ['Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates', 'Special Prosecutors (Independent Counsel)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Voting Machines', 'Computer Security']
abstract: Beyond his findings of presidential misconduct, the special counsel made it clear that lawmakers cannot ignore the ongoing risk to the nation.
lead_paragraph: Members of Congress have several major decisions to make after the special counsel Robert Mueller’s investigation into Russian interference in the 2016 election. Whether to pursue an impeachment inquiry is the one that’s gotten the most attention — and reasonable people can disagree about that. But Mr. Mueller’s findings leave no room for debate about the need to address the legal and institutional deficiencies that allowed a foreign adversary to tamper with America’s democracy.

headline: FIFA Bars Afghan Soccer Chief for Life After Sexual Assault Accusations
abstract: Soccer’s governing body said Keramuddin Keram had been found guilty “of having abused his position and sexually abused various female players, in violation of the FIFA Code of Ethics.”
lead_paragraph: PARIS — FIFA on Saturday barred the president of Afghanistan’s soccer association from the sport for life, months after reports emerged that he had sexually assaulted players and had threatened them when they went public with their accusations.

headline: Philippines Hits Back at Call for U.N. Inquiry of Police Killings
keywords: ['Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: A presidential spokesman called the experts’ report “an outrageous interference,” adding that the government’s “primary duty” was to protect its citizens.
lead_paragraph: MANILA — The Philippine government hit back on Saturday at United Nations rights experts seeking an international investigation into the unlawful killings during President Rodrigo Duterte’s drug war, calling the push “an outrageous interference” on the country’s sovereignty.

headline: Lock Your Bike to Private Property at Your Peril
abstract: It’s not always easy to find a place to store your bike. But some places are definitely riskier than others.
lead_paragraph: Q: My girlfriend locked her bike to my neighbor’s side of the wrought-iron fence outside the apartment I rent in a Brooklyn brownstone. We left town the next morning and returned two days later to find the bike gone. The neighbors later informed us that they had left a note on the bike asking for it to be removed and inquired about it with other neighbors. When no one responded, they cut the lock. They say they don’t know what happened to it after that. They had previously told my landlord that they didn’t want people locking bikes to their fence. I did not know this and they have not posted any signs. Is there anything my girlfriend can do?

headline: Liberals Begin Lining Up Young Judges for a Post-Trump Surge
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Federal Courts (US)', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Courts and the Judiciary']
abstract: Liberal advocacy groups have a message for federal judges pondering retirement: Hold on until 2021. In the meantime, they have begun drawing up lists of possible replacements.

Joe Biden moved nearer to the rest of his party’s presidential contenders on Thursday when he dropped his support of a measure restricting use of federal funds for abortions.

headline: Bunny Shaw, the ‘Zion Williamson of Soccer,’ Mixes Size and Spontaneity
abstract: Jamaica striker Khadija Shaw has an uncommon blend of tools that could make her the World Cup’s breakout star.
lead_paragraph: MIRAMAR, Fla. — Upon graduating from the University of Tennessee last month, Khadija Shaw allowed herself a quiet moment of self-congratulation. She was the first in her family to receive a college degree. She had persevered through tragedy, having lost three brothers to gang-related violence in Jamaica and a fourth to a car accident. And now she was headed to the Women’s World Cup with Jamaica’s Reggae Girlz, with a chance to become a breakout star.

headline: Smash the Wellness Industry
abstract: Why are so many smart women falling for its harmful, pseudoscientific claims?
lead_paragraph: A few months ago, I had lunch with the writer behind one of my favorite movies of the year, the agent who made the deal and the producer who packaged the project. I wanted to hear all about the process and perhaps find an opportunity to collaborate. When the server came to take our order, I flashed to that scene in “Romy and Michele’s High School Reunion” when Mira Sorvino walks into a diner in a striped skirt suit and asks the waitress, “Do you have some sort of businesswomen’s special?”

headline: The Business of Health Care Depends on Exploiting Doctors and Nurses
keywords: ['Nursing and Nurses', 'Doctors', 'Hospitals', 'Productivity', 'Electronic Health Records', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: One resource seems infinite and free: the professionalism of caregivers.
lead_paragraph: You are at your daughter’s recital and you get a call that your elderly patient’s son needs to talk to you urgently. A colleague has a family emergency and the hospital needs you to work a double shift. Your patient’s M.R.I. isn’t covered and the only option is for you to call the insurance company and argue it out. You’re only allotted 15 minutes for a visit, but your patient’s medical needs require 45.

abstract: It’s almost as if abortion bans aren’t actually about “life” at all.
lead_paragraph: When, exactly, do abortion opponents think life begins?

headline: PMS Is Not Just a Cliché
abstract: New research suggests the proof is in the brain.
lead_paragraph: My husband found me sobbing on the kitchen floor. My job was in upheaval, my travel schedule was grueling, and with two hours left before my next departure, I’d discovered that my laptop was dead. This was the moment my husband walked in to console me, and in an impressive feat of bad timing, he also asked whether I was premenstrual.

headline: This Teenager Knows a Secret to Slowing Guatemalan Migration

lead_paragraph: HUEHUETENANGO, Guatemala — When Lesly Cano Gómez was 15, she wrote out her plan to migrate to America.

headline: The Anti-College Is on the Rise
abstract: Students, teachers and reformers are pushing back against the failures of mainstream higher education.
lead_paragraph: A small band of students will travel to Sitka, Alaska, this month to help reinvent higher education. They won’t be taking online courses, or abandoning the humanities in favor of classes in business or STEM, or paying high tuition to fund the salaries of more Assistant Vice Provosts for Student Life. They represent a growing movement of students, teachers and reformers who are trying to compensate for mainstream higher education’s failure to help young people find a calling: to figure out what life is really for.

headline: Is It Too Late to Stop a New Cold War With China?
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'United States International Relations', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Cold War Era']
abstract: Led by President Trump, Washington is swiftly and decisively turning against the world’s No. 2 power. That could be disastrous.
lead_paragraph: George Orwell celebrated victory in World War II by warning that a “cold war” would soon commence. A cold war, he wrote in his 1945 essay “You and the Atomic Bomb,” was a “peace that is no peace.” Nuclear weapons would prevent direct invasions, but the superpowers would otherwise lead irreconcilable world orders, each seeking to quarantine and trounce the other. Within a few years, the United States and the Soviet Union squared off in just this fashion. The American diplomat George Kennan forged America’s Cold War consensus by counseling that Soviet power had to be contained until it collapsed.

headline: Yankee Doodle Donnie
keywords: ['Independence Day (US) (July 4)', 'National Mall (Washington, DC)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: President Trump takes a cue from Samuel Johnson, who once declared that “Patriotism is the last refuge of a scoundrel.”
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Halloween is sugary. Thanksgiving is fattening and fraught. Christmas is expensive. New Year’s Eve is annoying. Memorial Day is laced with melancholy. George Washington’s Birthday isn’t even on his birthday anymore. Columbus Day has some issues.

lead_paragraph: An 18-year-old man who was targeting members of the lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender community was charged with first-degree murder in the killings of three people in a Detroit home, the authorities said.

headline: The Black Characters I Wish I Saw More Of
abstract: Diversity on TV could use a lot of diversifying.
lead_paragraph: We’re finally seeing amazing diversity in Hollywood. One-dimensional, stereotypical portrayals have given way to strong characters who drive compelling narratives. That’s because women, the L.G.B.T.Q. community and people of color spent decades demanding to be included in every stage of the storytelling process.

headline: Why Is America So Far Behind Europe on Digital Privacy?
keywords: ['Law and Legislation', 'Data-Mining and Database Marketing', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Privacy', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Consumer Protection', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Legislators should seize the moment to pass meaningful protections for the digital age.
lead_paragraph: In the past year, Congress has been happy to drag tech C.E.O.s into hearings and question them about how they vacuum up and exploit personal information about their users. But so far those hearings haven’t amounted to much more than talk. Lawmakers have yet to do their job and rewrite the law to ensure that such abuses don’t continue.

headline: C.C. Sabathia Says Goodbye to Cleveland. Or Maybe Not.
abstract: Saturday loomed as his last start ever in the city where he began his career. Still, this year’s All-Star Game is in Cleveland. And what if Sabathia takes part?
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — C.C. Sabathia was the starting pitcher at Progressive Field on Saturday for the 125th, and probably last, time in his career. Way back when, he made his major league debut in Cleveland as a hard-throwing 20-year-old on April 8, 2001, and now, nearly two decades later, this season will be his final one.

headline: Don’t Quote Me
abstract: Seth A. Abel, you took the words right out of our mouths.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY PUZZLE — Today’s construction, by Seth A. Abel, is one of those with an informative theme that edified me in an interesting way, rather than one of those puzzles that’s strictly wordplay. It was also greatly entertaining, but I’m sure I’ll misremember most of it. Mr. Abel has brought us a couple of Sunday puzzles with a theme of blooper headlines — the one that I remembered doing, when I looked up his name for this post, was from the end of 2003. I would have sworn up and down that I had seen it no more than three years ago, which is a gross time discrepancy to me, a mortal human, but memory is strange.

headline: 2019 Belmont Stakes: Sir Winston, the ‘Wrong’ Horse, Prevails
abstract: A 10-1 shot gave the trainer Mark Casse two different winners in the final two Triple Crown races, capping a topsy-turvy season that began with the Kentucky Derby victor being disqualified.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes you can win and lose a race at the same time. Horse players have long known this: Many “Dutch” their races, betting two horses to win. Biden Jr. retains a lead among likely Iowa caucusgoers, but both he and Senator Bernie Sanders have lost ground over the past three months while Senator Elizabeth Warren and Pete Buttigieg, the mayor of South Bend, Ind., have made clear gains, according to a new poll from The Des Moines Register and CNN.

headline: What’s on TV Sunday: ‘Big Little Lies’ and ‘Claws’
abstract: “Big Little Lies” returns to HBO, this time with Meryl Streep. And “Claws” comes back on TNT.
lead_paragraph: BIG LITTLE LIES 9 p.m. on HBO. In its first season, this melodramatic murder-mystery defined itself as a whodunit decidedly more interested in its characters than its puzzle. Forget the mystery of the killer; the season took until its final episode to even reveal who had been killed. Instead, the show, created by David E. Kelley (“Ally McBeal”) and based on a novel by Liane Moriarty, trained its eyes on its beautiful Monterey, Calif., location and the lives of its central characters: a tech executive (Laura Dern), a retired lawyer (Nicole Kidman) and a recently remarried, very outspoken mother (Reese Witherspoon). While initially marketed as a mini-series, the show is back for a second season — this time moving past the plot of the novel and adding Meryl Streep, who plays the mother-in-law of Kidman’s character, and Andrea Arnold (“American Honey”), who directs.

headline: Prison Dogs of Angola

abstract: The working dogs of America’s largest maximum-security prison.
lead_paragraph: The Louisiana State Penitentiary in Angola is America’s largest maximum-security prison. Before it became a prison, Angola was a plantation. Its 18,000 acres are worked today by about 5,400 inmates, many of them there for life. Dogs have always been an integral part of prison life at Angola. They patrol the prison’s borders, sniff for narcotics, search for escapees and provide support to the infirm and elderly. There are 55 dogs currently either on active duty or in training.

headline: How Facial Recognition Makes You Safer
abstract: Used properly, the software effectively identifies crime suspects without violating rights.
lead_paragraph: In 1983, when I was sworn in as a police officer, many of the routine tasks of the trade would have seemed more familiar to a cop from my grandfather’s day than to a new police academy graduate today. I took ink fingerprints on paper cards and used a Polaroid camera for mug shots. Reports were handwritten or typed on carbon triplicates. Biological evidence could be analyzed only in terms of blood type.

headline: The Untapped Power of Rural Voters
keywords: ['Rural Areas', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Midterm Elections (2018)', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Voting and Voters']
abstract: They hold enormous potential for progressives.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — I have spent the past 25 years driving through back roads in the rural South to register voters, stop school and hospital closings and listen to families whose children are moving away because they can’t find jobs. The drive can be lonely because there’s often no cellphone coverage or streetlights at night.

headline: Trump Lawyer’s Message Was a Clue for Mueller, Who Set It Aside
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates', 'Legal Profession']
abstract: The special counsel’s prosecutors cited attorney-client privilege, but legal experts were divided on whether they should have pushed to learn more.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As the special counsel’s investigators pursued the question of whether President Trump tried to impede their work, they uncovered compelling evidence — a voice mail recording and statements from a trusted witness — that might have led to him.

headline: Tony Awards Highlights and Analysis
abstract: Did you tune in to the Tony Awards? Our TV and theater critics watched the ceremony, which honors the best of Broadway, and discussed the performances, presenters, winners and more.
lead_paragraph: Did you tune in to the Tony Awards? Our TV and theater critics watched the ceremony, which honors the best of Broadway, and discussed the performances, presenters, winners and more.

headline: Democrats Descend on Iowa for a Chance to Break Through
abstract: Nineteen presidential candidates visited the state this weekend, talking to voters and trying to grab a moment to distinguish themselves.
lead_paragraph: CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa — Senators Kamala Harris and Elizabeth Warren took selfies — with each other. Senator Bernie Sanders marched with striking fast-food workers. Mayor Pete Buttigieg of South Bend, Ind., played the blues on an electric keyboard. And former Representative John Delaney brought a team of bagpipers.

headline: The Enemy of My Enemy
abstract: China and Russia unite under a common foe.
lead_paragraph: President Xi Jinping of China spent three days in Russia last week talking trade with President Vladimir Putin as both leaders manage deteriorating relations with Washington.

abstract: Mr. Porter wore a gown to Sunday night’s awards show and he wasn’t alone.
lead_paragraph: Billy Porter has been shutting down red carpets all year, cutting through seas of traditional gowns and tuxes in gender-bending, head-turning garments.

headline: Delay in Huawei Ban Is Sought by White House Budget Office
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Telephones and Telecommunications']
abstract: The acting director of the Office of Management and Budget said the order could burden companies that work with Huawei but also do business with the U.S. government.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The acting budget chief for the White House has called for a two-year delay of part of a federal measure that is aimed at Huawei Technologies, the Chinese telecom giant.

headline: ‘Hadestown’ Director Rachel Chavkin: Diversity ‘Is Not a Pipeline Issue’
abstract: Ms. Chavkin, the only woman directing a musical on Broadway this season, won for best direction of a musical.
lead_paragraph: In a Broadway season nearly devoid of female directors, the sole woman at the helm of a musical this year — Rachel Chavkin, director of “Hadestown” — took home the Tony Award for best direction of a musical.

headline: ‘Big Little Lies’ Season 2 Premiere Recap: Monsters
abstract: The newly minted “Monterey Five” reckon with the fallout of last season’s fall down the stairs — and with a quietly terrifying visitor.
lead_paragraph: “Do you see yourself as a monster?”

headline: So You’ve Made a Huge Mistake. What Now?
abstract: It’s fine. You’re fine. Everything is O.K.
lead_paragraph: A quick note for New York readers: I’d like to invite you to come hang out with Smarter Living in real life! On June 25, three of your favorite Smarter Living writers — Jen Doll, Jolie Kerr and Kristin Wong — will join me for an evening of life advice and revelry. Tickets are available here. See you there!

headline: ‘Billions’ Season 4 Finale Recap: Collateral Damage
abstract: Chuck and Bobby go all out in hopes of dealing the finishing blow to their enemies. But at what cost?
lead_paragraph: At a key moment in the season finale of “Billions” — although neither character involved knows just how key until it’s too late — Rebecca Cantu and Wendy Rhoades take a day trip to a recreational construction site. Yes, there are recreational construction sites. A small chain of them, actually.

headline: Ali Stroker Makes History as First Wheelchair User to Win a Tony
abstract: “This award is for every kid who is watching tonight who has a disability, who has a limitation or a challenge,” said Ms. Stroker, who won for her role as Ado Annie in “Oklahoma!.”
lead_paragraph: On Sunday night, Ali Stroker became the first person who uses a wheelchair to  win a Tony Award.

headline: Corrections: June 10, 2019
abstract: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, June 10, 2019.
lead_paragraph: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, June 10, 2019.

abstract: Quotation of the Day for Monday, June 10, 2019.
lead_paragraph: “No one comes forward — nobody reports anybody. Individuals with developmental disabilities can’t speak for themselves. So, who is going to speak for them?”

headline: Stanley Cup Finals Headed to Game 7 After Bruins Wallop Blues
abstract: Needing to survive an elimination game on the road in St. Louis, Boston led for most of the game and ended up with a blowout.
lead_paragraph: ST. LOUIS — The final thing the Boston Bruins saw before leaving their locker room at Enterprise Center was a keepsake from eight years ago. A framed photograph hanging above the exit showed Patrice Bergeron clutching a bottle of Champagne, his mouth open in delight, as Brad Marchand, standing to his right, held the Stanley Cup aloft.

headline: Review: As Broadway Gets Bigger, the Tonys Get Blander
abstract: CBS’s broadcast of the 73rd annual ceremony was a safe, unsurprising show that even James Corden couldn’t liven up.
lead_paragraph: It was duly noted, early in the 73rd Tony Awards, that the festivities followed a record year on Broadway — more tickets sold and more dollars grossed than ever. But the tight, tinny, careful show broadcast by CBS on Sunday night didn’t feel celebratory — it seemed alternately self-satisfied and insecure, as if it felt it had to keep making excuses for itself.

headline: Bryan Cranston Praises Journalists in Tony Awards Speech
abstract: “The media is not the enemy of the people,” said Mr. Cranston, who won best leading actor in a play for his performance as a journalist in “Network.”
lead_paragraph: Bryan Cranston, who won a Tony Award for his portrayal of a broadcast journalist, praised real-life journalists in his acceptance speech on Sunday night.

headline: Retired Red Sox Slugger David Ortiz Is Shot in Dominican Republic
abstract: Ortiz, 43, was in stable condition at a hospital on Sunday night after being shot once in the back at a club, the police said.
lead_paragraph: David Ortiz, the retired baseball player who became one of the game’s most respected athletes while playing a key role in Boston ending its 86-year World Series drought, was shot in the Dominican Republic on Sunday, according to the country’s national police.

headline: Chickenpox Vaccine May Protect Against Shingles Years Later
abstract: Children vaccinated against chickenpox had a 78 percent lower rate of shingles than their unvaccinated peers.
lead_paragraph: The chickenpox vaccine not only protects against chickenpox: A new study has found it also lowers the risk for shingles.

keywords: ['Driverless and Semiautonomous Vehicles', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: The agreement, with Aurora Innovation, underscores the heavy emphasis automakers are placing on autonomous cars.
lead_paragraph: Just days after breaking off merger talks with the French carmaker Renault, Fiat Chrysler Automobiles has reached an agreement to source self-driving technology from a California start-up, Aurora Innovation.

headline: What’s on TV Monday: ‘Straight Forward’ and ‘Gentleman Jack’
abstract: A new crime thriller comes to Acorn TV. And the season finale of “Gentleman Jack” is on HBO.
lead_paragraph: STRAIGHT FORWARD Stream on Acorn TV.  When a crime boss kills her father, Sylvia Petersen (Cecilie Stenspil), a Danish con woman, plans her revenge. But the attempt goes awry and she escapes to New Zealand, leaving her mother and daughter behind. Petersen uses her expertise in disguise and deception to stay hidden. Then she learns that her enemy is targeting her family back in Copenhagen.

headline: Suiting Up Hockey’s Stars, One Stitch at a Time
abstract: A diminutive 86-year-old Italian immigrant in Montreal stands tall among the many hockey players he has dressed.
lead_paragraph: MONTREAL — It’s a ritual broadcast widely every year during the N.H.L. playoffs: powerful hockey players in their power suits entering the arena.

headline: On Politics: Who’s the Real William Barr?
abstract: Is he the operator who spun the then-secret Mueller report? Or the straight shooter who later disclosed portions that were damaging to President Trump?
lead_paragraph: Good Monday morning. Here are some of the stories making news in Washington and politics today.

headline: Inside the Stealth Campaign for ‘Responsible Rent Reform’
keywords: ['Rent Control and Stabilization', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Landlords', 'Politics and Government', 'State Legislatures', 'Lobbying and Lobbyists']

lead_paragraph: [What you need to know to start the day: Get New York Today in your inbox.]

headline: Migrants in Custody at Hospitals Are Treated Like Felons, Doctors Say
abstract: Dozens of migrants a day are being taken to community hospitals, where doctors are challenging security procedures that they say are harming patients.
lead_paragraph: Rom Rahimian, a medical student working at Banner-University Medical Center Tucson, was trying to help a 20-year-old Guatemalan woman who had been found late last year in the desert — dehydrated, pregnant and already in labor months before her due date. But the Border Patrol agents lingering in the room were making him uncomfortable.

headline: Marc Gasol Turns Memphis Into Jurassic Park South
abstract: Instead of burning Gasol’s jerseys or booing him, Grizzlies fans want to host a parade for their team’s former center if the Raptors win a title.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — Jason Peters, the former boys’ basketball coach at Lausanne Collegiate School in Memphis, has been having friends over to watch the N.B.A. finals on a giant projection screen on his porch. He used to organize these types of watch parties when the Grizzlies were in the playoffs. But in the wake of another suboptimal season, countless Memphians like Peters are rooting for another team this spring: the Toronto Raptors.

headline: When Japan Lost Its Crown, It Found a Reason to Start Over
abstract: How the 2011 World Cup champions, humbled by the United States four years ago, rebuilt themselves into a title contender.
lead_paragraph: When Yuka Momiki of Japan scored a late goal to salvage a tie against the United States in an important tuneup for the Women’s World Cup in February, she danced a brief shimmy, then laughed about it afterward. Several days later, Momiki cleverly chipped a shot over Brazil’s goalkeeper and set up two other goals in a resilient Japanese victory.

headline: ‘While He Enjoyed the Scene From a Bench, I Walked to Get Us Lunch’
abstract: A visit to Coney Island, watching Charlie Barnett perform and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Pete Alonso, the Giddy Star Rising in Queens
abstract: Amid another largely frustrating season for the Mets and their fans, the 6-foot-3 rookie slugger has provided both awe-inspiring and lighthearted moments.
lead_paragraph: Michelle Alonso arrived at her seat in section 114 at Citi Field shortly before first pitch at the Mets’ home opener in March. Her husband, Peter, was at her side, as they watched her firstborn, also Peter, be announced to the crowd of 44,424 fans as the starting first baseman, batting second.

headline: Afghan Peace Marchers Meet the Taliban and Find ‘People Just Like Us’
abstract: The activists said that rank-and-file fighters shared their desire for an end to the conflict, but that leaders on both sides “insist on fighting.”
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Packing umbrellas and spare sandals, Afghanistan’s quixotic band of peace marchers invaded the heart of Taliban territory earlier this month and finally succeeded in their long-delayed quest to sit down with the Afghan government’s enemy.

headline: Hong Kong’s Government May Cave In to China. Its People Will Not.
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Hong Kong Protests (2019)', 'Constitutions', 'Fugitives', 'Extradition', 'Bribery and Kickbacks', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: Judging by the crowds on Sunday, scorn for the government on the mainland has reached new heights.
lead_paragraph: If Hong Kong’s undoing comes much earlier than 2047, the year that the city’s special arrangement with mainland China formally ends, it may be because of a love story that ended in murder.

headline: Insomnia Can Kill You
abstract: Chronic insomnia is linked to an increased risk of developing hypertension, Type 2 diabetes, heart attack, depression, anxiety and premature death.
lead_paragraph: How did you sleep last night? If you’re over 65, I hope it was better than many others your age. In a study by the National Institute on Aging of over 9,000 Americans aged 65 and older, more than half said they had difficulty falling asleep or staying asleep. Many others who believe they spend an adequate number of hours asleep nonetheless complain of not feeling rested when they get up.

headline: How Safe Is Sunscreen?
abstract: A recent study on absorption into the bloodstream has caused concern, but you should be more worried about skin cancer.
lead_paragraph: Skin cancer is the most common malignancy in the United States, affecting more than three million people each year. Using sunscreen is one mainstay of prevention. But the recent news that sunscreen ingredients can soak into your bloodstream has caused concern.

headline: Hong Kong Leader, Carrie Lam, Says She Won’t Back Down on Extradition Bill
abstract: Hong Kong’s chief executive said the government was pursuing a law that would allow extraditions to mainland China “out of our clear conscience.”
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Hong Kong’s chief executive, Carrie Lam, said Monday that she had no intention of withdrawing contentious legislation that would allow extraditions to mainland China, despite hundreds of thousands of people demonstrating against it the day before.

headline: Mindy Kaling on Not Being the Long-Suffering Indian Woman
abstract: “I always had so much impatience and ambition — these things that if you had them, you were supposed to have them secretly.”
lead_paragraph: “I always had so much impatience and ambition — these things that if you had them, you were supposed to have them secretly.”

headline: Supplements for Weight Loss, Sexual Function and Muscle Building May Be Deadly
abstract: Side effects from dietary supplements can be serious, even fatal, a study of those under 25 found.
lead_paragraph: Dietary supplements for weight loss, energy, sexual function or muscle building are popular among young people. But they led to 1,392 adverse event reports in people under 25 from 2004 to 2015, with more than 40 percent of them severe or even fatal.

headline: Children’s Safety on Wheels
keywords: ['Children and Childhood', 'Bicycles and Bicycling', 'Helmets', 'Parenting', 'Concussions', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Skateboarding']
abstract: On bikes and scooters, “the best way to prevent an injury is to wear a helmet, and children need to follow the rules of the road,” an expert says.
lead_paragraph: A 13-year-old patient recently talked to me about the amount of time he spends playing video games (plenty) and about his weight (heavier than he wants, and on the rise). I asked about exercise, and he told me proudly that he rides his bike a lot, now that the weather is good. And then, of course, I had to be the fun police, and ask whether he wears a helmet, and when he told me no, of course, I had to take the opportunity to deliver more good advice that I suspected he was not going to follow, and his parents were not going to enforce.

headline: The Best Women’s Soccer Team in the World Fights for Equal Pay
keywords: ["Women's World Cup (Soccer)", 'Women and Girls', 'Discrimination', 'Soccer', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: As the U.S. women’s national soccer team defends its World Cup title in France, its members are preparing for a courtroom battle.
lead_paragraph: In spring 2018, Abby Wambach, the most decorated soccer player in American history, gave a commencement address at Barnard College that went viral. The player who had scored more goals than any other, male or female, in international competition described standing onstage at the ESPYs the year after she retired in 2015, receiving the Icon Award alongside two peers, Peyton Manning and Kobe Bryant. “I felt so grateful,” she recalled. “I had a momentary feeling of having arrived; like, we women had finally made it.” As the athletes exited the stage, each having, as Wambach put it, “left it all on the field for decades with the same ferocity, talent and commitment,” it occurred to her that while the sacrifices the men made for their careers were nearly identical to her own, their new lives would not resemble hers in one fundamental way. “Kobe and Peyton walked away from their careers with something I didn’t have: enormous bank accounts,” Wambach said. “Because of that, they had something else I didn’t have: freedom. Their hustling days were over; mine were just beginning.”

headline: Neville Chamberlain: A Failed Leader in a Time of Crisis
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'World War II (1939-45)', 'Nineteen Hundred Thirties', 'Politics and Government']
abstract: Tim Bouverie’s “Appeasement” describes the many ways the British government avoided standing up to Hitler.
lead_paragraph: APPEASEMENTChamberlain, Hitler, Churchill, and the Road to WarBy Tim Bouverie

headline: Tesla, Facing Setbacks and Skeptics, Tries to Get Back on Course
keywords: ['Electric and Hybrid Vehicles', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'Driverless and Semiautonomous Vehicles']
abstract: Elon Musk’s electric-car company began the year with high expectations. But it has confronted a series of problems and a loss of investor confidence.
lead_paragraph: Tesla’s Model 3 electric sedan was heralded this year by Consumer Reports as the most satisfying car on the market. Then owners started to complain that cars had arrived with cracked windows, leaks or unreliable video screens. In some places, Tesla turned to outside body shops to repair scratches and other paint defects before cars were delivered to customers.

headline: Ginsburg Hints at Sharp Divisions Ahead as Supreme Court Term Nears End
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Law and Legislation', 'State Legislatures', 'Census', 'Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Citizenship and Naturalization']
abstract: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg, in remarks at a conference that included references to the census and Justice Brett M. Kavanaugh, gave liberals little reason to be optimistic.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In 2012, as the Supreme Court was mulling the fate of President Barack Obama’s health care law, Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg addressed the American Constitution Society, a liberal group. “This term has been more than usually taxing,” she said.

headline: Coming Home to the Lower East Side
keywords: ['Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: She spent her teenage years in Lower Manhattan before raising a family in Puerto Rico. Now she’s back for good.
lead_paragraph: In 1966, when she was 11, Ruth Santiago moved from Puerto Rico to an apartment on Pitt Street, on the Lower East Side, with her parents and five brothers. The youngest of 17 children, Ms. Santiago had many older siblings already living in New York by then, which made the move feel like an adventure and a homecoming.

headline: Diet for One? Scientists Stalk the Dream of Personalized Nutrition
keywords: ['Diet and Nutrition', 'Food', 'Obesity', 'Weight', 'Carbohydrates', 'Genetics and Heredity', 'Twins', 'Diabetes', 'Preventive Medicine', 'Research', 'Triglycerides', 'DNA (Deoxyribonucleic Acid)', 'your-feed-science']
abstract: No single food regimen works for everyone. A new study is the most comprehensive effort yet to understand why.
lead_paragraph: A decade ago, spurred by the success of the Human Genome Project and the affordability of genetic sequencing, scientists began to explore the promise of “nutrigenomics.” Could personalized nutrition, informed by knowledge of an individual’s DNA, help prevent and even treat diet-related diseases?

headline: Her Evangelical Megachurch Was Her World. Then Her Daughter Said She Was Molested by a Minister.
abstract: Evangelical churches have long distanced themselves from the sexual abuse crisis that has consumed the Catholic Church. But a reckoning has arrived.
lead_paragraph: HURST, Tex. — Christi Bragg listened in disbelief. It was a Sunday in February, and her popular evangelical pastor, Matt Chandler, was preaching on the evil of leaders who sexually abuse those they are called to protect. But at the Village Church, he assured his listeners, victims of assault would be heard, and healed: “We see you.”

headline: To Map a Coral Reef, Peel Back the Seawater
keywords: ['Reefs', 'Coral', 'Oceans and Seas', 'Maps', 'Diving and Divers', 'Fish and Other Marine Life', 'Telescopes and Observatories', 'Forests and Forestry', 'Snorkeling', 'Cameras', 'your-feed-science']
abstract: This scientist couple created an airborne observatory to map tropical forests. Now they’re using it to identify threatened reefs.
lead_paragraph: Coral reefs comprise just 1 percent of the ocean floor yet they are home to 25 percent of the world’s marine fish, a growing source of protein for people. But reefs are imperiled by a range of threats including warming waters, acidifying seas, destructive fishing methods, and agricultural and other runoff.

headline: How a 19th-Century Workman’s Cottage Became a Family Home
abstract: In Gallatin, N.Y., the husband-wife co-founders behind the design firm Workstead converted a 1850s clapboard house into a rural idyll.
lead_paragraph: For most couples, attempting a gut renovation of a historic home in a matter of months — while expecting twins — is a surefire recipe for disaster. But for Stefanie Brechbuehler and Robert Highsmith, the husband-and-wife co-founders of the Brooklyn-based design firm Workstead, the recent revamp of an 1850s residence in upstate New York not only presented them with a thrilling challenge, it also marked a celebratory homecoming after a few years spent living in the South.

headline: It’s Easy for Leaders to Make Promises After Disasters. But What Happens Next?
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Grenfell Tower Fire (June, 2017)', 'Sri Lanka Easter Bombings (April, 2019)', 'Aviation Accidents, Safety and Disasters']
abstract: Our international editor introduces Promises Made, a new series that investigates whether those in power did what they said they would.
lead_paragraph: Of all the tragedies, wars, natural disasters and terrorist attacks we’ve reported on over the years, the one that even now, as I think of it, makes my knees go weak is the sinking of the Sewol ferry in South Korea. More than 300 people died that day in 2014, and most of them were high school students.

headline: An Overloaded Ferry Flipped and Drowned Hundreds of Schoolchildren. Could It Happen Again?
keywords: ['Maritime Accidents and Safety', 'Ferries', 'Freight (Cargo)', 'Corruption (Institutional)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Conflicts of Interest']
abstract: South Korea promised to root out a culture that put profit ahead of safety. But cheating and corruption continue to endanger travelers.
lead_paragraph: When things go wrong, those in power often promise to make it right. But do they? In this series, The Times is going back to the scene of major news events to see if those promises were kept.

headline: Put Off by Venice’s Crowds? Try the Oasis Next Door
abstract: Should tourism be limited in overcrowded European cities? The author ponders the issue as he explores Treviso, Venice’s quieter neighbor, where canals also flow.
lead_paragraph: The website of the city of Venice provides high water advisories to help people avoid flooded areas. Now it also forecasts another kind of flood: tourist inundations. It uses a scale of 1 to 20 stick figures, the kind found on the doors of men’s bathrooms. A recent April day could have been worse: 15 men’s-room men. Still, the city felt crowded, pungent, a little sticky. I boarded a train, eager to breathe in a gulp of fresh, authentic Italian air. I went to Treviso.

headline: New York’s Skyline Is Still for Everyone
abstract: Even if its new skyscrapers aren’t. The Real Estate desk sought out to annotate the view.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

headline: Nissan and Renault Lock Horns as Relationship Sours Further
abstract: The Japanese carmaker criticized its French partner’s vow to block its overhaul effort, further straining the troubled auto alliance.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — The cracks in the world’s largest auto alliance grew wider on Monday, as Nissan Motor condemned as “most regrettable” a decision by its French partner, Renault, to withdraw support for the Japanese automaker’s efforts to overhaul its governance.

headline: I Needed to Save My Mother’s Memories. I Hacked Her Phone.
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Computer Security', 'Privacy', 'Death and Dying', 'Archives and Records', 'Families and Family Life']
abstract: After she died, breaking into her phone was the only way to put together the pieces of her digital life.
lead_paragraph: Several days after my mother died in a car accident, my two sisters and I sat together in her apartment, stunned and overwhelmed. High on our horrible to-do list — along with retrieving her smashed vehicle from the tow lot, making burial plans and meeting with the rabbi — was this: getting into her cellphone.

headline: Trump’s Bullying Won’t Fix the Migrant Crisis
keywords: ['Illegal Immigration', 'Politics and Government', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Customs (Tariff)']
abstract: The problems in Central America won’t go away, and Mexico will struggle to sustain a crackdown.
lead_paragraph: COATZACOALCOS, Mexico — Angelica López crouched beside the train tracks that run through this sweltering city in southern Mexico, cradling her 2-year-old daughter, calling to her 7-year-old son not to stray too far from her. After they were stopped by Mexican federal police officers while trying to board a freight train, they’d slept on the mud, watching out for more police. They hoped to get on the next train north.

headline: I Turned My Back for a Second, Half a Second, and He Was Grown
abstract: Called back to my childhood home in Alabama, I found the past still very much alive.
lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — Driving due south in spring is like speeding up time. My mother, who grew up on a peanut farm in Lower Alabama, believed that the growing season expands northward at the rate of a hundred miles per week. I thought about her theory as I was driving south last month, watching the new-green leaves near home fast forward into a denser, darker verdure. I had set off from Nashville in springtime, but when I arrived at my sister’s house near Birmingham, it was already full summer.

headline: Deepfakes Are Coming. We Can No Longer Believe What We See.
keywords: ['Philosophy', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: It will soon be as easy to produce convincing fake video as it is to lie. We need to be prepared.
lead_paragraph: On June 1, 2019, the Daily Beast published a story exposing the creator of a now infamous fake video that appeared to show House Speaker Nancy Pelosi drunkenly slurring her words. The video was created by taking a genuine clip, slowing it down, and then adjusting the pitch of her voice to disguise the manipulation.

lead_paragraph: Global markets rose modestly on Monday, as the prospect of a trade war between the United States and Mexico subsided.

abstract: Uniting the aerospace unit of United Technologies and Raytheon will create a huge maker of jet engines and missiles — and could force more mergers in the industry.
lead_paragraph: Good Monday. (Was this email forwarded to you? Sign up here.)

headline: Kazakhstan Gets New Leader, but Old System’s Grip on Power Remains
abstract: After quashing protests, the government said that President Nazarbayev’s handpicked successor had won a lopsided vote. Observers cast doubt on the official count.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Ruled by the same authoritarian leader since the 1991 collapse of the Soviet Union, Kazakhstan finally has a new president, with lopsided election results released on Monday confirming the victory of the old order’s handpicked candidate in a tightly controlled vote marred by hundreds of detentions.

lead_paragraph: In November 2016, a black Oberlin College student walked into a family-run shop near the Ohio school to buy wine with a fake ID, according to court records.

keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Sex Crimes', 'Hinduism', 'Kidnapping and Hostages']
