lead_paragraph: HOMESTEAD, Fla. — About half of the roughly 2,300 children confined in a privately run Florida facility intended as a temporary shelter for migrant teenagers have been there for more than 20 days and many of them for months, despite legal standards that require children who cross the border to be speedily released or sent to state-licensed shelters that are equipped to offer longer-term care.

headline: Yankees Hold Off Complacency, and Blue Jays, to Secure Sweep
abstract: The Yankees earned a walk-off victory after coming back twice against Toronto. They next head to London to face the Red Sox.
lead_paragraph: For almost any other team on any other day, a 5-0 deficit in the second inning would have been an excuse to auto-pilot the rest of the afternoon. No one would have blamed the Yankees for looking ahead to their trans-Atlantic trip to London, where they will play a two-game series against the Boston Red Sox this weekend.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Locked Out of Debates, Montana’s Bullock Sees Path Forward for 2020
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, June 27, 2019.
lead_paragraph: “I got in a little late. I’m not on for June, but I am in July.”

headline: Corrections: June 27, 2019
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Thursday, June 27, 2019.
lead_paragraph: FRONT PAGE

headline: Analysis of the First 2020 Democratic Debate
abstract: Ten candidates faced off in the first Democratic primary debate on Wednesday. Here is how our reporters covered it in real time.
lead_paragraph: Ten candidates faced off in the first Democratic primary debate on Wednesday. Here is how our reporters covered it in real time.

headline: Debate Night: Join The Times’s Live Chat
abstract: Join Lisa Lerer and other Times reporters as they chat live about what’s happening in the first Democratic debate.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to a special debate night edition of On Politics. I’m Lisa Lerer, your host.

headline: Amy Klobuchar on Her Record and Bipartisanship
abstract: Ms. Klobuchar, a senator from Minnesota, has focused on issues that can attract bipartisan support.
lead_paragraph: Pragmatism is at the center of Senator Amy Klobuchar’s run for the Democratic presidential nomination. Ask what makes her uniquely qualified to be president, and she’s likely to remind you that she’s from the Midwest and has a long record of getting things done in Congress.

headline: Elizabeth Warren on Breaking Up Big Tech
abstract: Ms. Warren seeks to break up companies like Amazon, Google, Apple and Facebook. And she has taken her fight to Silicon Valley.
lead_paragraph: Senator Elizabeth Warren of Massachusetts believes that the government must break up monopolies and promote competitive markets. That’s why she has taken aim at America’s largest tech companies.

headline: Gabbard and Buttigieg on Their Military Service
abstract: Representative Tulsi Gabbard served two combat tours in the Middle East, and Mayor Pete Buttigieg was deployed to Afghanistan as with the Navy. They often cite their service.
lead_paragraph: In the large Democratic primary field of 24 presidential candidates, only Representative Tulsi Gabbard of Hawaii, Mayor Pete Buttigieg of South Bend, Ind., Representative Seth Moulton of Massachusetts and former Representative Joe Sestak of Pennsylvania are military veterans.

headline: Tulsi Gabbard on Foreign Policy and War
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Presidential Election of 2020']
abstract: Ms. Gabbard, a congresswoman from Hawaii, has railed against “regime change wars” and warned of a nuclear arms race.
lead_paragraph: Representative Tulsi Gabbard of Hawaii is an Army National Guard veteran who deployed twice to the Middle East. Her views on foreign policy and specifically her stance on war have emerged as central issues in her campaign.

headline: Bill de Blasio on Income Inequality
keywords: ['Income Inequality', 'Minimum Wage', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Paid Time Off']
abstract: Many of Mr. de Blasio’s accomplishments as mayor of New York City are tied to closing the wealth gap.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio rose to power by depicting New York as a city defined by its stark inequities. His run for president will test whether his brand of urban progressive leadership can be a model for the country.

headline: Jay Inslee on Job Creation
abstract: The governor of Washington believes that proper investment in a clean energy economy will create 8 million well-paying jobs.
lead_paragraph: Yes, Gov. Jay Inslee’s primary focus is combating climate change. But there’s more to it than that. Mr. Inslee believes that investing in a clean energy economy will lead to the creation of millions of jobs in communities across the country.

headline: Tim Ryan on Manufacturing Jobs
abstract: Mr. Ryan, a congressman from a working-class district in Ohio, wants to create jobs in places whose economies have long depended on the auto industry.
lead_paragraph: As a congressman from a working-class district in Ohio, Tim Ryan has centered his presidential campaign on his ability to appeal to the white working class voters who swung from Barack Obama to Donald Trump — and especially the voters whose livelihoods are threatened by the decline of Midwestern manufacturing.

headline: John Delaney on Universal Health Care
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Presidential Election of 2020']
abstract: Mr. Delaney, a former congressman from Maryland, argues his proposal would guarantee universal coverage without forcing people to use a government health plan.
lead_paragraph: John Delaney, a former congressman from Maryland, has proposed a universal health care system based on a combination of government coverage and private insurance.

headline: ‘Don’t Talk to Her’: We Toured the Troubled Border Station Housing Migrant Children
abstract: A look inside the Border Patrol station at Clint, Tex., where visiting lawyers said they saw migrant children being held in filthy conditions.
lead_paragraph: CLINT, Tex. — Children as young as 3 pressed their faces against the windows of one crowded cell holding nearly 20 migrant girls, some sprawled on the floor. Boys gazed through the fencing of a containment zone exposed to the 101-degree heat.

headline: Julián Castro on Immigration
abstract: Mr. Castro, a former housing secretary and San Antonio mayor, was the first Democratic candidate in the 2020 campaign to release an immigration plan.
lead_paragraph: Julián Castro, a former housing secretary under President Barack Obama, was the first candidate to release an immigration plan. It’s one of the centerpieces of what he refers to as his “People First” platform.

headline: Beto O’Rourke on Immigration
abstract: Mr. O’Rourke, a former congressman from Texas, seeks to undo the Trump administration’s work at the border with his own immigration plan.
lead_paragraph: Leaning on his ties to El Paso, former Representative Beto O’Rourke of Texas has made immigration reform a central pillar of his presidential campaign. His plan seeks to directly undo the work of the Trump administration at the border.

headline: Fact-Checking Night 1 of the 2020 Democratic Debates
abstract: New York Times reporters followed the exchanges and provided context around the candidates’ claims.
lead_paragraph: Ten candidates vying for the 2020 Democratic presidential nomination took the stage on Wednesday in Miami for the first of back-to-back debate nights. Another 10 candidates who qualified for the debates will appear on the same stage on Thursday.

headline: Fulfill Requirements
abstract: Hoang-Kim Vu makes his New York Times Crossword debut.
lead_paragraph: THURSDAY PUZZLE — A quick one, as I have been filing my column from an undisclosed location for the past few days (Florida, actually, where I have been visiting my parents and encountering insects the size of dinosaurs). Today I will be traveling — hopefully, as yesterday’s flight was unceremoniously canceled right before take off — and fortunately, I have qualified for T.S.A. PreCheck. Which brings me to this debut by Hoang-Kim Vu. It definitely fulfilled my requirements for a satisfying Thursday puzzle.

headline: 5 Cheap(ish) Things for the Perfect Picnic
abstract: The person who wields the corkscrew is always the hero.
lead_paragraph: My favorite kind of picnics happen under the stars, maybe at an outdoor concert or a beach. But since I live in a city, my picnics are more likely to consist of a sandwich and iced coffee on a scratchy patch of grass at a public park. Whatever. I’ll take it!

headline: Cory Booker on Gun Control
abstract: Mr. Booker, a senator from New Jersey, has put forth a 14-part plan, the most notable piece of which is a gun-licensing program.
lead_paragraph: Senator Cory Booker of New Jersey introduced a 14-part plan earlier this year to address gun violence, and it is one of the most progressive gun-control measures suggested by a candidate seeking the Democratic presidential nomination.

headline: Overlooked No More: Bill Larson, Who Became a Symbol of Gay Loss in New Orleans
keywords: ['Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Biographical Information', 'Fires and Firefighters', 'Bars and Nightclubs']
abstract: Larson died in the city’s deadliest fire ever, at a gay bar called the Up Stairs Lounge, but his death — and those of the 31 other victims — was treated with indifference.
lead_paragraph: Overlooked is a series of obituaries about remarkable people whose deaths, beginning in 1851, went unreported in The Times. This month we’re adding the stories of important L.G.B.T.Q. figures.

headline: I’m 20. I Have 32 Half Siblings. This Is My Family Portrait.
keywords: ['Families and Family Life', 'ARTIFICIAL INSEMINATION', 'Photography', 'Sperm', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality']
abstract: I always knew I was conceived using a sperm donor. But I never really understood what that meant until I went searching for my brothers and sisters.
lead_paragraph: I always knew I was conceived using a sperm donor. But I never really understood what that meant until I went searching for my brothers and sisters.

headline: Sperm Donors Can’t Stay Secret Anymore. Here’s What That Means.
keywords: ['Families and Family Life', 'ARTIFICIAL INSEMINATION', 'Single Mothers', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Sperm', 'Parenting', 'Infertility']
abstract: Sperm banks never imagined a world where donors could be tracked down by DNA. But now children can find their biological fathers — and each other.
lead_paragraph: To be the biological child of an anonymous sperm donor today is to live in a state of perpetual anticipation. Having never imagined a world in which donors could be tracked down by DNA, in their early years sperm banks did not limit the number of families to whom one donor’s sperm would be sold — means that many of the children conceived have half-siblings in the dozens. There are hundreds of biological half-sibling groups that number more than 20, according to the Donor Sibling Registry, where siblings can find one another, using their donor number. Groups larger than 100, the registry reports, are far from rare.

headline: Jay Inslee on Climate Change
abstract: The governor of Washington has made climate change his campaign’s singular focus, going so far as to call for a climate debate.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Jay Inslee of Washington is running a campaign almost singularly focused on combating climate change. It is his signature issue.

headline: Photo of Migrants Shocks, but Congress Stalls on Border Aid
keywords: ['Illegal Immigration', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Asylum, Right of', 'Immigration Detention', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: A photo of a migrant father and his 23-month-old daughter appeared to crystallize the human tragedy at the border, and it was everywhere — on cable, the internet and on the Senate floor.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A photograph of a migrant father and his 23-month-old daughter lying face down on the muddy bank of the Rio Grande added an emotional charge on Wednesday to the immigration policy debate consuming Washington.

headline: Democrats Diverge on Economy and Immigration in First Debate
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Debates (Political)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Elizabeth Warren set the tone for the party’s progressive wing, but others among the 10 candidates were more cautious, producing clashes along ideological lines.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Democratic presidential candidates leveled a stark critique of President Trump’s immigration policies and the condition of the American working class in the first primary debate on Wednesday, but split in unmistakable terms over just how aggressively the next president should seek to transform the country along more liberal lines.

headline: NBC’s Technical Difficulties Lead to an Awkward Pause in the Democratic Debate
abstract: Chuck Todd told the audience that the microphones of the previous moderators were still live, scrambling the audio feed.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Technical difficulties are every news producer’s nightmare.

headline: Cory Booker on Criminal Justice Reform
abstract: Mr. Booker, a senator from New Jersey, has made numerous proposals to overhaul the justice system, including one that was signed into law.
lead_paragraph: Perhaps no issue is more central to the career of Senator Cory Booker of New Jersey than criminal justice reform. His bipartisan criminal justice bill, the First Step Act, was signed into law in December, and Mr. Booker has made numerous other proposals to overhaul the justice system.

headline: Which Candidates and Topics Got the Most Time During the Democratic Debate
abstract: Candidates discussed several issues including immigration, climate change, health care and gun control.
lead_paragraph: Candidates discussed several issues including immigration, climate change, health care and gun control.

headline: Full Transcript: Democratic Presidential Debates, Night 1
abstract: Read the transcript from Night One of the Democratic presidential debate.
lead_paragraph: Following is a transcript of the Democratic debate, reprinted with permission from CQ-Roll Call, Inc.

headline: There Were 3 Women Onstage, and a Man Had a Lot to Say About His Work on Abortion
keywords: ['Debates (Political)', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: When Gov. Jay Inslee boasted of being “the only candidate here who has passed a law protecting a woman’s right of reproductive health,” Senator Amy Klobuchar pointed out that “there’s three women up here.”
lead_paragraph: It took 30 minutes or so for Senator Elizabeth Warren to wind toward well-worn territory for her: a riff on the evils of insurance companies. “It’s not working for families,” she said, “But it’s sure as heck working for them. It’s time for us to make families come first.”

headline: Your Thursday Briefing
abstract: Iran, Turkey, Boris Johnson: Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: Iran, responding to American sanctions, has said that by Thursday its uranium stockpile will have exceeded the limits set in the 2015 deal that President Trump pulled the United States out of last year.

headline: Asylum Officers’ Union Says Trump Migration Policy ‘Abandons’ American Tradition
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'Asylum, Right of', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']
abstract: The union said that migrants could face persecution under the policy, which forces them to wait in Mexico while their immigration cases are decided.
lead_paragraph: A union representing federal asylum officers said in a court filing Wednesday that the Trump administration’s policy forcing migrants to wait in Mexico while their asylum cases are decided risks violating international treaty obligations and “abandons our tradition of providing a safe haven to the persecuted.”

headline: Why Is Everyone Drinking Celery Juice as if It Will Save Them From Dying?
abstract: Wellness gurus have extolled its benefits, but there’s no science that supports their claims.
lead_paragraph: In May 2018, Perelandra, a natural foods store and juice bar in Brooklyn Heights, sold 698 pounds of celery; in May 2019, they sold 1,245 pounds of it, according to Roland Auer, the store’s co-owner. He’s seen these patterns before.

headline: Highlights From the First Democratic Debate
keywords: ['Debates (Political)', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: Ten candidates in the presidential primary faced off on immigration, health care and the economy.
lead_paragraph: Ten candidates in the presidential primary faced off on immigration, health care and the economy.

headline: Saudi Arabia Is Running Out of Friends
abstract: The Anglo-American relationship with the House of Saud may be entering a perfect storm.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Last week was especially bad for the monarchy of Saudi Arabia.

headline: What’s on TV Thursday: ‘Anima’ and ‘Laurence Anyways’
abstract: A short film from Paul Thomas Anderson and Thom Yorke hits Netflix. And stream Xavier Dolan’s “Laurence Anyways.”
lead_paragraph: ANIMA Stream on Netflix. The director Paul Thomas Anderson takes a break from his collaborations with the Radiohead guitarist Jonny Greenwood here, but he doesn’t stray far. In this short film, Anderson works instead with the Radiohead frontman Thom Yorke. The film is set to music by Yorke, stars Yorke and is being released alongside Yorke’s new solo album of the same name. The teaser trailer for the film offered little indication of what it’s actually about, which is both in keeping with the Radiohead frontman’s enigmatic tendencies and catnip for fans.

headline: Debate Night 1: The ‘On Politics’ Breakdown
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Debates (Political)']
abstract: What we learned from the first debate of the 2020 presidential race.
lead_paragraph: Hi, and welcome to a special post-debate edition of On Politics. I’m Lisa Lerer, your host.

headline: At G20, Trump Seeks Fresh Start With Putin After End of Mueller Inquiry
keywords: ['ARMS CONTROL AND LIMITATION AND DISARMAMENT', 'Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates', 'Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: President Trump’s advisers hope to use the session to pivot the relationship toward arms control, a paradoxical priority given the administration’s recent moves to dismantle treaties.
lead_paragraph: OSAKA, Japan — The last time he was to meet with President Vladimir V. Putin, President Trump called it off at the last minute, citing Russia’s seizure of three Ukrainian ships and detention of two dozen Ukrainian sailors. They would meet, Mr. Trump declared, only after “this situation is resolved.”

headline: Would You Pay $30 a Month to Check Your Email?
abstract: One of Silicon Valley’s buzziest start-ups, Superhuman, is betting its app’s shiny features are worth a premium price.
lead_paragraph: The year is 2019, and the brainy engineers of Silicon Valley are hunkered down, working on transformative, next-generation technologies like self-driving cars, digital currencies and quantum computing.

headline: Australian Student Is Missing in North Korea, His Family Says
abstract: The family said that it had not heard in days from Alek Sigley, 29, who has offered a close look at his life inside the reclusive North on social media.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — The family of an Australian man studying at a university in North Korea said on Thursday that it had lost contact with him in recent days, and Australian officials said they were “urgently seeking clarification” about his whereabouts.

headline: Jimmy Fallon Thinks the Democratic Debate Was a Bit Overcrowded
abstract: “To qualify, all a candidate needed was to poll at 1 percent or higher,” the “Tonight Show” host said. “That’s it? One percent? I mean, even O.J.’s at 2 percent.”
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. If you’re interested in hearing from The Times regularly about great TV, sign up for our Watching newsletter and get recommendations straight to your inbox.

headline: Trump Once Again Assails America’s Friends as He Opens Overseas Visit
abstract: President Trump complained that Japan would sit back if the United States were attacked and watch “on a Sony television.” He also assailed Germany and India.
lead_paragraph: OSAKA, Japan — President Trump plunged back into the world of international diplomacy on Friday with characteristic provocation, keeping some of America’s closest allies, including his hosts, off balance even as he sought advantage on an array of economic and security disputes with profound consequences.

headline: Judge John Hodgman on the Dangers of Turtles
abstract: What do we owe to our local snapping turtles?
lead_paragraph: Alex writes: My parents’ yard abuts a protected marshland. I recently observed a snapping-turtle nest by a bird feeder at the yard’s edge. My research suggests the hatchlings will head to the marsh. I want to protect the nest. My father wants to destroy it: He’s concerned the turtles will antagonize the birds.

headline: 10 Ways to Lower the Cancer Risk of Grilling
abstract: If you plan to grill often experts suggest taking some small steps to make a big difference in lowering your exposure to compounds that are tied to cancer.
lead_paragraph: Many people would be surprised to hear that grilling carries potential cancer risks. But each year, the American Institute for Cancer Research publishes guidance for “cancer-safe grilling,” cautioning consumers to avoid two types of compounds that have been tied to cancer. These compounds, called polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons and heterocyclic amines, get generated when food, especially meat, is cooked on a grill. They have not been proven to cause cancer in people, but lab studies have shown they alter DNA in a way that could lead to cancer.

headline: Poem: Dutch Elm Disease
abstract: Whether in far-off Vietnam or on a nearby bridge, death is waiting in Milwaukee.
lead_paragraph: How does Valencia Robin’s beautiful poem work its melancholy magic? Whether in far-off Vietnam or on a nearby bridge, death is waiting in Milwaukee. The narrator can’t stop remembering; she turns the events of one summer over in her mind until her voice gets in our heads too. The constant patter — desperate yet determined — is like a doomed wish, as if you could talk some sense into memory: sorrow spilling out of a neighbor’s house, the family staggering under a mortal anguish that overwhelms the boundaries of the yard, the street, the city and, finally, even time itself. Selected by Rita Dove

headline: You Make the Call: Maximizing Space in Manhattan
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)']
abstract: Three college friends team up to ‘flex’ a small apartment and save on rent. Which one did they choose?
lead_paragraph: Three college friends team up to ‘flex’ a small apartment and save on rent. Which one did they choose?

headline: The Democratic Debates, Night 2: Four Heavyweights Face Off
abstract: Biden, Sanders, Buttigieg and Harris: Top-tier candidates face off tonight. Here’s a guide to the second night of the first Democratic presidential debates.
lead_paragraph: Biden, Sanders, Buttigieg and Harris: Top-tier candidates face off tonight. Here’s a guide to the second night of the first Democratic presidential debates.

headline: My Son Got Lyme Disease. He’s Totally Fine.
abstract: Horror stories about lingering Lyme disease proliferate, but the illness is easily treated.
lead_paragraph: When I mentioned to various people last December that my 9-year-old son, Akash, had Lyme disease, many immediately told me horror stories. A parent at the school bus stop told me about a family friend in her 20s who has never recovered from her infection. A co-worker at the neighborhood co-op told me that his father-in-law has had seizures ever since his diagnosis. Even a fellow science journalist told me she knows some people never recover.

headline: Elizabeth Warren Aced the First Democratic Debate
abstract: But is she really her party’s best bet?
lead_paragraph: Elizabeth Warren came into Wednesday night’s debate as the candidate to watch most closely, the only one of the 10 onstage who had double-digit support in polls, with an apparent momentum that none of those rivals could claim.

headline: Is Customer Service the New Therapy?
abstract: Unloading on an anonymous customer service representative who is obligated to listen has a certain appeal. And it’s free.
lead_paragraph: When Kate Lacroix was driving alone from Seattle to Vancouver for a funeral, she called AT&T to get an international wireless plan. By the time she arrived, not only did she have a new phone plan, she also had a refreshed outlook on life and death.

headline: By the Book: Greg Iles
abstract: The author, most recently, of the novel “Cemetery Road,” finds electronic books easier on his eyes these days: “I still love the scent and feel of ink and paper, but — we do what we must.”
lead_paragraph: The author, most recently, of the novel “Cemetery Road,” finds electronic books easier on his eyes these days: “I still love the scent and feel of ink and paper, but — we do what we must.”

headline: Girl Hit by Foul Ball in Houston Had Serious Head Injuries, Lawyer Says
abstract: The lawyer said the Astros had been informed of the girl’s injuries but he was not sure whether the family would file a lawsuit against the club.
lead_paragraph: A 2-year-old girl who was struck in the head by a foul ball last month at a Cubs-Astros game in Houston sustained a skull fracture, bleeding on the brain and seizures, according to a lawyer hired by the girl’s family.

headline: Drugmaker Deals Are Near Record Pace in 2019, but Investors Don’t Love Them All
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Humira (Drug)', 'Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Inventions and Patents', 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: A rush of transactions is transforming the industry, as blockbuster medicines lose patent protection. The latest acquisition cost AbbVie 16 percent of its share price.
lead_paragraph: A rush of acquisitions this year is reshaping the drug industry. But investors haven’t universally welcomed the deal-making.

headline: Climate Change Is Scaring Kids. Here’s How to Talk to Them.
abstract: How to talk about it: “A lot of people, when they talk to children, are processing their own anxiety and fears,” a psychologist said.
lead_paragraph: Hollywood has produced quite a few fictionalized depictions of dramatic climate change. Scores of people die after Manhattan freezes in 2004’s “The Day After Tomorrow.” In “Geostorm,” released in 2017, the weather goes haywire after satellites malfunction.

headline: Who Won the First Debate? Experts on the Left and Right Weigh In
abstract: Elizabeth Warren delivered on expectations, while Julián Castro made a big splash.
lead_paragraph: Senator Elizabeth Warren, the only person on the stage Wednesday polling in double digits, was expected to be the star of the first Democratic debate — and for the first half-hour, she was. But by the end, several lower-polling candidates had taken the spotlight: Senators Cory Booker and Amy Klobuchar, and especially Julián Castro.

headline: Identical Twin Sisters, a Boyfriend, a Knife and a Dead Body
abstract: The stabbing of a 27-year-old in Camden may have resulted from a “love triangle” dispute, a law enforcement official said.
lead_paragraph: [What you need to know to start the day: Get New York Today in your inbox.]

headline: The Night the Stonewall Inn Became a Proud Shrine
keywords: ['Stonewall Riots (1969)', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'WorldPride NYC 2019', 'Transgender and Transsexuals']
abstract: It was “a bar for the people who were too young, too poor or just too much to get in anywhere else.”
lead_paragraph: Hours before it was to become a flash point in the modern gay rights movement and a landmark visited with awe and reverence half a century later as if a shrine, it was just a dark, dingy bar called the Stonewall Inn, just another Friday night in June.

headline: What You Need to Know About the Census Citizenship Question
keywords: ['Census', 'Redistricting and Reapportionment', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Population', 'Citizenship and Naturalization', 'Minorities']
abstract: An attack on immigrants or a need to protect minority voters? With a deadline to print 2020 forms looming, the Supreme Court left the question undecided.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court did not give a final answer Thursday to a seemingly simple issue with big, complex ramifications: Can the federal government legally ask people whether they are American citizens as part of the 2020 census?

headline: A School With No Heat or Computers but Many College-Bound Students. Mostly Girls.
abstract: At an Afghan mountain school, there are no computers, lights or heat. Even books are few. Yet 90 percent of graduates get into college. Most of them are girls.
lead_paragraph: YAKAWLANG, Afghanistan — The girls began appearing about seven in the morning. Seen from a distance, they made up thin blue lines snaking across the barren tan mountainside along narrow trails traced in the dirt, converging from several directions on the little school in the bottom of the valley.

headline: What Is Gerrymandering? And How Does it Work?
keywords: ['Redistricting and Reapportionment', 'State Legislatures', 'States (US)', 'Elections, House of Representatives', 'Elections, State Legislature', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Here’s what you need to know about the legal battle over the rigging of district maps to entrench a governing party’s political power.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court ruled on Thursday that the federal courts cannot decide a question with momentous political consequences: Whether congressional district maps in Maryland and North Carolina that were drawn specifically to tilt political power in favor of one party — a practice known as partisan gerrymandering — are acceptable.

headline: Bare Feet, Selfies and Silence: The World Cup Walk-Through as an Oasis
abstract: For 30 minutes the day before each game, World Cup squads get the stadiums to themselves.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Ever see an immaculately trimmed field of perfectly green grass and feel a sudden urge to frolic on it with your shoes off?

headline: For the Black Keys, Rock Lives. It Just Had to Wait
abstract: Success led to burnout for the blues-rock duo. But after a five-year break, Dan Auerbach and Patrick Carney return with their ninth album, “Let’s Rock.”
lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — It was hard for the Black Keys to say no. When they finally did, it took them years to decompress from a decade on the road.

headline: ‘Hot Dogs! Cold Beer!’ M.L.B. Will Bring the Familiar to London Stadium
abstract: The Yankees and Red Sox will bring the peanuts and Cracker Jack to an overseas series. But there will also be British twists, like appearances by Churchill and Henry VIII.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Imagine stirring renditions of “Sweet Caroline” and “Take Me Out to the Ball Game” belted out by fans munching on Cracker Jack sold by roving vendors.

headline: Discovering Maurice Sendak, the Opera Designer
abstract: The Morgan Library & Museum explores a dense, underappreciated period in the artist’s career in an exhibition of sketches, dioramas and more.
lead_paragraph: There is a drawing that gets to the root of Maurice Sendak’s ominous sweetness, his work’s potent mixture of childhood idyll and threatening night.

headline: 36 Hours in Camden and Rockport, Maine (and Environs)
abstract: On the central coast of Maine, visitors will find a beguiling nexus of arts, dining and outdoor activities.
lead_paragraph: If Maine’s much-debated slogan, “the way life should be,” were a place, the towns of Camden and Rockport and their surroundings might be it. On the Eastern Seaboard, where mountains meet ocean, the area has long attracted rusticators and “vacationlanders” who far outnumber residents in summer. These clapboard-and-brick towns sit two miles apart on schooner-spotted harbors next to rounded mountains and sparkling freshwater lakes. What more does a rural getaway need? In this case, it’s a vibrant community of year-round locals who’ve created a nexus of arts, dining and outdoor activities to rival some cities. The area’s charm lies in an authentic belief in family businesses, locally grown food and ingenuity against the odds. Not to mention, they made it through the winter, and summer is everyone’s reward.

headline: Nissan of Japan Discloses a New Recall, Adding to Its Problems
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Recalls and Bans of Products', 'Boards of Directors']
abstract: Its management faces quality problems and a slide in profitability in addition to a management crisis prompted by the arrest of Carlos Ghosn.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Nissan revealed two new blows to its embattled management on Thursday, as it announced a recall of 490,000 vehicles in Japan and disclosed that its shareholders remained split over its chief executive, Hiroto Saikawa.

headline: Angela Merkel Is Seen Shaking Again, but Spokesman Insists She’s Fine
abstract: The German chancellor began trembling at a ceremony in Berlin on Thursday, 10 days after she blamed high temperatures for another shaking episode.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — For the second time in 10 days, Chancellor Angela Merkel on Thursday was seen shaking at a public event and struggling to maintain control of her body as her limbs trembled visibly. And for the second time in 10 days, Germany largely did not discuss it.

headline: To Back Warren Is to Treat Politics as a Matter of Substance
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Presidential Election of 2000', 'Primaries and Caucuses']
abstract: Detailed plans can tell a candidate’s story about what kind of person she is — and what kind of president she would be.
lead_paragraph: There are plenty of good arguments against running a presidential campaign the way Senator Elizabeth Warren is doing it, with a heavy emphasis on detailed policy proposals.

headline: A Major Police Body Cam Company Just Banned Facial Recognition

lead_paragraph: Axon, the company that supplies 47 out of the 69 largest police agencies in the United States with body cameras and software, announced Thursday  that it would ban the use of facial recognition systems on its devices.

headline: When An Abortion Doctor Becomes a Mother
abstract: There is a connection between my work as a doctor and my work as a mother; it’s just not what most people imagine.
lead_paragraph: Recently a colleague asked me if I’d had trouble working while I was pregnant.

headline: What It’s Like To Be a Teenager in Putin’s Russia
abstract: Russian teenagers are not fans of Putin — and now they’re almost old enough to vote.
lead_paragraph: Russian teenagers are not fans of Putin — and now they’re almost old enough to vote.

headline: The Cars Are Newer, the Buyers Younger as Auto Collecting Moves Forward
keywords: ['Antique and Classic Cars', 'Automobiles', 'Collectors and Collections', 'Millennial Generation', 'Hobbies']
abstract: The new generation of desirable models includes specimens most serious collectors wouldn’t have sniffed at a few years ago.
lead_paragraph: When Kurt Glaubitz bought a vintage British automobile, it wasn’t for its sweeping curves or coach-built looks. Despite its scrawny-necked snorkel (for fording rivers) and boxy lines, however, his 1992 Land Rover Defender fits right into the latest wave of cars being scooped up by a new generation of collectors.

headline: What It’s Like To Be a Teenager in Putin’s Russia
abstract: Russian teenagers are not fans of Putin — and now they’re almost old enough to vote.
lead_paragraph: Update, Aug. 20, 2020: Aleksei A. Navalny, a famous critic of Russian President Vladimir Putin, was reportedly poisoned and is in critical condition. We produced this video a year ago with his daughter Daria. Teenagers who have grown up in Russia have known only one leader in their lifetimes: Vladimir Putin. In the video Op-Ed above, Daria Navalnaya, host of an influential YouTube channel and daughter of the opposition leader Aleksei A. Navalny, interviews a cross-section of young Russians about how they feel about Mr. Putin, politics and their country’s future. Her interviews reveal a generation frustrated with the status quo, pessimistic about the possibility of change, and torn between their dreams for the future and their deep sense of patriotism.

headline: ‘Killers Anonymous’ Review: 12 Steps to Disaster
abstract: Gary Oldman and Jessica Alba wisely keep to the periphery of this fiasco about a support group for assassins.
lead_paragraph: “Killers Anonymous” is the kind of movie that makes critics despair and otherwise decent actors rue their involvement. Those with the highest name recognition, however (Gary Oldman, Jessica Alba), mostly keep to the periphery, maintaining a judicious distance from the movie’s soft, sticky center.

headline: ‘Euphoria’ Review: Death Wishes
abstract: In this drama featuring Eva Green and Alicia Vikander, a bucolic haven hides a dark secret.
lead_paragraph: With a few tweaks, “Euphoria” — a mopey tale of suicide and sisterhood — would make a pretty good horror movie. As it is, this English-language debut from the Swedish director Lisa Langseth wastes its skin-crawling setup on an extended wallow in resentment and reconciliation.

headline: At 75, Taking Care of Mom, 99: ‘We Did Not Think She Would Live This Long’
abstract: The phenomenon some experts call “aging together” — people in their 60s and 70s, usually women, helping much older relatives — can take a financial toll.
lead_paragraph: Not many years ago, Lynda Faye planned to spend her retirement gardening in Amherst, Mass., and visiting her eight grandchildren. Not on the list of golden-years pursuits: caring for a frail elderly parent.

headline: ‘The Plagiarists’ Review: A Sharp Satire Built on Social Discomfort
abstract: Shot on low-resolution video, Peter Parlow’s film deserves to be the summer’s art house conversation starter.
lead_paragraph: A social and philosophical investigation disguised as a gleefully barbed satire, “The Plagiarists,” directed by Peter Parlow from a script by James N. Kienitz Wilkins and Robin Schavoir, deserves to be the summer’s art house conversation starter.

headline: ‘Mine 9’ Review: A Tense Disaster Drama, Undermined by Clichés
abstract: Eddie Mensore’s bracing simulation of a mine collapse is more compelling than the material that surrounds it.
lead_paragraph: There’s some effective filmmaking in the central section of this picture written and directed by Eddie Mensore. These scenes depict the collapse of a section of a West Virginia coal mine, trapping nine men inside. Flooding and gas buildup combine with very cramped quarters as the men await rescue, unsure if anyone on the ground miles above them even knows they’re alive.

headline: ‘Three Peaks’ Review: On Vacation With Mom’s Boyfriend
abstract: A tense domestic drama follows a provisional family on a mountain vacation.
lead_paragraph: “Three Peaks,” an insinuating, sometimes tense and pleasingly open-ended domestic drama from the Berlin-born director Jan Zabeil, opens with a shot of three side-by-side pools. A man, Aaron (Alexander Fehling), is teaching Tristan (Arian Montgomery), to swim. Lea (Bérénice Bejo), the boy’s mother, joins them, but soon it becomes clear that Aaron is not Tristan’s father — and that young Tristan is still getting used to living as a family with his mom’s boyfriend.

headline: ‘The Other Story’ Review: Thwarting a Marriage to Save the Family
abstract: Religious tensions and fraught family dynamics are at the heart of Avi Nesher’s busy but compelling drama.
lead_paragraph: “The Other Story,” an unwieldy but reasonably compelling Israeli drama from the director Avi Nesher, recalls the old Jewish joke about how two disputing parties can’t both be right. (Or can they?) Given the complexity of the tensions the movie deals with — between religious Jews and secular Israelis, and between secular Israelis and other religions — perhaps its thematic murkiness is a feature, not a bug.

headline: The Most Fabulous Old Folks Home
keywords: ['Retirement Communities and Assisted Living', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality']
abstract: An illustrated visit to Openhouse, an organization for L.G.B.T.Q. seniors.
lead_paragraph: Wendy MacNaughton is a graphic journalist based in San Francisco. You can find her via website and Instagram.

headline: What Is the G20?
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Global Warming']
abstract: Here is a look at what the Group of 20 is and does, and some of the important things to watch as world leaders gather in Japan over the next two days.
lead_paragraph: OSAKA, Japan — The annual Group of 20 summit meeting, which brings together President Trump and other world leaders, is intended to foster global economic cooperation. But with so many top officials in one place, it also serves as an all-purpose jamboree of nonstop formal and informal diplomatic activity.

headline: Trump Said He’d Sit Out the Debate, but He Couldn’t Quite Do It
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Debates (Political)', 'News and News Media']
abstract: Even from thousands of feet in the air, the president could not quite stay out of the fray on a night when prime-time TV was dedicated to prospective 2020 rivals.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — His aides teased that President Trump might insert himself into the 2020 Democratic presidential primary debate by live-tweeting the two-hour conversation that unfolded Wednesday night.

headline: Putting ‘Hiroshima Mon Amour’ Onstage
abstract: Two adaptations of works by the writer Marguerite Duras are playing as one-woman shows in Paris.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — When the film “Hiroshima Mon Amour” was released 60 years ago, the French author Marguerite Duras was still relatively unknown. Directed by Alain Resnais, the  meditation on love, war and destruction earned Duras an Oscar nomination for best original screenplay. She became one of France’s most original 20th-century writers, and the spare intensity of her prose continues to be imitated.

headline: Suicide Bombers Attack Security Forces in Tunisia
keywords: ['Attacks on Police', 'Terrorism', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates']
abstract: Twin bombings in the capital, Tunis, hit a security patrol and a police station, killing one officer and injuring several others, officials said.
lead_paragraph: TUNIS — Two suicide bombers struck security forces in quick succession on Thursday morning in the Tunisian capital, killing at least one police officer and wounding at least eight other people, the Interior Ministry said.

headline: Four Takeaways From a 1-0 Victory for the U.S. Men
abstract: A listless game featured 11 new American players.
lead_paragraph: KANSAS CITY, Kan. — Jozy Altidore, one of the United States men’s soccer team’s stalwarts, rescued a listless game against Panama on Wednesday night. His bicycle kick goal off a corner kick in the second half was the difference in a 1-0 United States victory, helping the Americans top their Gold Cup group and advance to face Curacao in the quarterfinals in Philadelphia on Sunday night.

headline: Not Enough Homes, and the Wrong Kind
abstract: In the midst of a housing shortage, the American household is shrinking, but the share of larger new homes is growing.
lead_paragraph: Home building has barely kept pace with the number of new households — a household “consists of all the people who occupy a housing unit,” according to the U.S. Census — in the United States over the last eight years, and much of what is being built is aimed at the higher end of the market, according to a report released this week by the Harvard Joint Center for Housing Studies.

headline: At the First Debate, an Audio Snarl and a Traffic Jam
keywords: ['Television', 'Debates (Political)', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The Democrats’ prime-time debut was like a big ensemble TV pilot, with a lot of characters to manage.
lead_paragraph: Halfway through the first Democratic primary debate in Miami Wednesday night, NBC brought on a second shift of moderators — four hours over two nights, you’ve got to conserve your energy. Chuck Todd began to ask a question about gun violence. Then he stopped.

headline: Dutch Railway Will Pay Millions to Holocaust Survivors
keywords: ['Reparations', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'World War II (1939-45)', 'Railroads']
abstract: The company had set up special trains on behalf of the Nazis to carry Jews and other victims to transit points for deportation to death camps.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — At the height of World War II, the Dutch railway ran special trains to transit camps where Jews and other minorities awaited deportation to Nazi death camps.

headline: This Man Has Got to Stop Looking in My Window
abstract: What should I do about his unneighborly — and unnerving — behavior?
lead_paragraph: I am a single woman who bought a house next to a small apartment building. The owner of the building visits several times a week. Every time he comes, he knocks on my door to chat or request needless access to my yard (to cut tree limbs that could easily be cut from his side, for example). If I don’t answer, he peers in my window. Worse, his body language is salacious, and he makes me uncomfortable. I’m afraid that eventually he will ask to come inside my house. How can I be assertive about being left alone without causing hostility?

headline: When Fritz Lang Shot the Moon
abstract: The first movie to dramatize space travel as a realistic possibility, Lang’s spectacular “Woman in the Moon” was the “2001” of 1929.
lead_paragraph: Fritz Lang’s last silent film, “Die Frau im Mond” (1929), known in English as “Woman in the Moon,” was also a first — the earliest movie to depict space travel as a realistic possibility.

headline: When Jaap Met Yannick: New Maestros in New York
abstract: At the end of Jaap van Zweden’s rookie season at the New York Philharmonic, and Yannick Nézet-Séguin’s at the Met Opera, they chatted. On neutral ground.
lead_paragraph: “Maître!” Yannick Nézet-Séguin, the new music director of the Metropolitan Opera, cried out, using the French word for maestro, as he greeted Jaap van Zweden, the new music director of the New York Philharmonic. “Cher maître, good to see you!”

headline: Supreme Court Bars Challenges to Partisan Gerrymandering
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Redistricting and Reapportionment', 'Elections, House of Representatives', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Constitution (US)', 'Decisions and Verdicts']
abstract: The court has ruled that racial gerrymanders can violate the Constitution, but it has struggled with voting maps warped by politics.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Thursday ruled that federal courts are powerless to hear challenges to partisan gerrymandering, the practice in which the party that controls the state legislature draws voting maps to help elect its candidates.

headline: We Want to Hear About Your Thanksgivings Spent in War Zones
keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'Iraq War (2003-11)', 'Thanksgiving Day', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Veterans']
abstract: Tell us about your experiences and memories of celebrating this most American holiday while deployed in a conflict zone.
lead_paragraph: This fall will mark the United States’ 18th year since the start of the global war on terror. And in each of those years, thousands of Americans found themselves commemorating Thanksgiving in conflict zones far from home and apart from their families.

headline: In ‘The Queen,’ Rivals Pour Their Hearts Out
abstract: Frank Simon’s 1968 vérité documentary about the drag pageant world is revived in a new 4K digital restoration.
lead_paragraph: The human comedy struts the boards in “The Queen,” Frank Simon’s 1968 documentary of the Miss All-American Camp Beauty Pageant — a small movie with a big heart that is being revived at the IFC Center in a new 4K digital restoration.

headline: ‘Charlie’s Angels’ Trailer: Elizabeth Banks Tries to Reboot the Franchise
abstract: The promo features Kristen Stewart in mainstream-action mode, along with Naomi Scott and Ella Balinska.
lead_paragraph: Can a remnant from the Jiggle TV era be reinvented as a female-empowerment action flick for the Time’s Up generation? That’s the task undertaken by Elizabeth Banks, and judging by the first trailer for her take on “Charlie’s Angels,” she just might pull it off.

headline: Waxing or Sugaring for a Hairy Situation
abstract: Is either method better for removing unwanted body hair?
lead_paragraph: I have two questions regarding “sugaring.”: Is it true that hair growth is slower and finer after sugaring or waxing? Is it true that the sugar scrub helps prevent ingrown hairs? And is it beneficial or unnecessary? Thank you.

headline: House Passes Senate Border Bill in Striking Defeat for Pelosi
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Politics and Government', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Immigration Detention', 'Humanitarian Aid']
abstract: Speaker Nancy Pelosi, in a stinging defeat after a show of Democratic disunity, let a Senate border spending bill pass the House without controls that liberals had demanded.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Congress sent President Trump a $4.6 billion humanitarian aid package on Thursday after Speaker Nancy Pelosi capitulated to Republicans and Democratic moderates and dropped her insistence on stronger protections for migrant children in overcrowded border shelters.

headline: Indonesia Court Rejects Presidential Candidate’s Voting Fraud Claims
abstract: Judges threw out accusations by Prabowo Subianto, the son-in-law of the former dictator Suharto, clearing the way for a second term for President Joko Widodo.
lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — Indonesia’s Constitutional Court on Thursday rejected a claim by the presidential candidate Prabowo Subianto that he was the victim of widespread fraud in last month’s election.

headline: Supreme Court Leaves Census Question on Citizenship in Doubt
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Census', 'Redistricting and Reapportionment', 'Voting Rights Act (1965)', 'Voter Registration and Requirements']
abstract: In a setback for the Trump administration, the court said the reason for adding the question was inadequate. Government experts said adding the question could suppress participation among immigrants.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In a setback for the Trump administration, the Supreme Court on Thursday rejected its stated reason for adding a question on citizenship to the census, leaving in doubt whether the question would appear on the census forms sent to every household in the nation next year.

headline: When a Politician Is Called a ‘Lousy Traitor,’ Should Facebook Censor It?
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Social Media', 'Libel and Slander', 'Censorship', 'Artificial Intelligence']
abstract: A case could give European courts enormous power to force the worldwide removal of defamatory statements.
lead_paragraph: In April 2016, a Facebook user shared an article featuring a photo of the Austrian Green party’s leader at the time, Eva Glawischnig-Piesczek, along with added comments labeling her a “corrupt oaf,” a “lousy traitor” and “member of a fascist party.” The comments were apparently a protest of her support for refugees. Ms. Glawischnig-Piesczek claimed that she had been defamed and demanded that Facebook take down the post.

headline: The British Stole Tipu’s Magic Box. It Should Not Be for Sale.
abstract: Christie’s auctioned $109 million of Indian artifacts, items that should not be privately owned.
lead_paragraph: Last week, Christie’s auctioned Indian and Mughal-era jewels, daggers and royal portraits from a collection owned by a member of the Qatari royal family. The sale took in $109 million, the highest total for any auction of Indian art and Mughal objects, and the second highest for a private jewelry collection.

headline: How Mueller Can ‘Fix His Mistakes’
keywords: ['Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates', 'Law and Legislation', 'Campaign Finance', 'First Amendment (US Constitution)']
abstract: In his July testimony, he can help Congress and the Federal Election Commission clarify our vague campaign-finance law.
lead_paragraph: When Robert Mueller testifies on July 17, members of Congress should not expect new revelations. Instead, they should ask tough questions about his legal errors and the loopholes he created.

headline: Crocodiles Went Through a Vegetarian Phase, Too
abstract: Ancestors of modern crocodiles evolved to survive on a plant diet at least three times, researchers say.
lead_paragraph: Imagine you’re a small mammal of the Mesozoic. Snuffling around one day, you run into a cat-size, scaly, big-eyed reptile that looks not unlike a  crocodile found later in the 21st century. Spotting you, he opens his mouth wide to reveal … tiny, intricate teeth. Then he turns his head and munches on some leaves.

headline: Kate Soper’s New Opera Opens Next Year
abstract: “The Romance of the Rose” is a highlight of the coming season of Peak Performances at Montclair State University.
lead_paragraph: The composer Kate Soper has made a specialty of turning dense, thorny, seemingly unmusical sources into elegant, surprisingly poignant art. Her “Ipsa Dixit,” a Pulitzer Prize finalist in 2017, drew words from Aristotle, Freud, Plato and others to become that unlikeliest of works: a tender philosophical inquiry in sound.

headline: Beyond the Beach: Rosés with Character and Dimensions
abstract: They are the wines of summer, as escapist as a poolside novel. But good examples can offer so much more than that, and are not bound by the season.
lead_paragraph: I’m sitting in my Manhattan apartment, but in my mind I’m far away, watching the ocean, glass of rosé in hand, staring out at the waves breaking under pale blue skies, sea breezes rustling the leaves above.

headline: Manzanilla Sherry, the Salty Side of Wine
abstract: This distinctive form of fino sherry, from one seaside town in Andalusia, can be as captivating a summer drink as rosé.
lead_paragraph: Manzanilla sherry is about as far as you can get from rosé in wine. That’s one good reason to make it our next subject.

headline: Megan Rapinoe Digs In After Trump Criticism: ‘I Stand by the Remarks’
abstract: The United States soccer star urged her teammates to “think hard” about sharing their platform with the White House after the World Cup.
lead_paragraph: Megan Rapinoe on Thursday tried to quiet a brewing feud with President Trump sparked by her pledge to skip any visit by the United States women’s soccer team to the White House after the World Cup. Ms. Rapinoe said she stood by her remarks, apologizing only for using a obscenity to express them, and urged her teammates to join her in any potential boycott.

headline: The First New York Pride March Was an Act of ‘Desperate Courage’
keywords: ['Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Discrimination', 'Stonewall Riots (1969)', 'Photography', 'Parades', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots']
abstract: It wasn’t always feathers, floats and celebrities.
lead_paragraph: When we hear of Pride marches today, we tend to think of fuss and feathers, of men more than half-naked waving from rainbow-hued, Lurex-draped parade floats, of Dykes on Bikes who gun their motors in defiance of gender norms, of waving gay and trans celebrities. They are fiestas that percolate through the cities and sometimes small towns of the developed world, as well as some parts of the rest of the world, and they mark the fact that gay people exist in numbers, provide documentary evidence that we have more fun and are more fabulous than anyone else, that we are gay in the old sense of the word. The drag queens and gender-nonbinary youth at such events can appear preoccupied with their own ecstatic exhibitionism.

headline: The Editor Will See You Now
keywords: ['Book Trade and Publishing', 'Books and Literature', 'Writing and Writers', 'Psychology and Psychologists']
abstract: Judith Gurewich, the publisher of Other Press, brings an intensity to her editing, hosting authors for days while they read their manuscripts aloud.
lead_paragraph: Every industry has its clichés, and no cliché gets more mileage in and around book publishing than “editors don’t edit anymore.”

headline: Smile, Your City Is Watching You

abstract: Local governments must protect your privacy as they turn to “smart city” technology.
lead_paragraph: Walking through the streets of New York City, you can feel the thrill of being lost in the crowd. As throngs of people filter past, each going about their days, it seems possible to blend in without being noticed.

headline: HPV Vaccine Proving Very Successful
keywords: ['Human Papillomavirus (HPV)', 'Sexually Transmitted Diseases', 'Cervical Cancer', 'Women and Girls', 'Vaccination and Immunization']

lead_paragraph: This restaurant in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, has a hard-working grill in the open kitchen that exhales smoke in billows.

headline: South Africa Meets South Asia at Peri Peri Grill House
abstract: Smoke, spice and an eclectic menu are the hallmarks of this small restaurant in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: It isn’t the smell of smoke that greets you when you walk through the door of Peri Peri Grill House in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn; it’s the sight of it. The hard-working grill in the open kitchen exhales smoke in billows that dissipate quickly into the dining room, but not before leaving a defining mark on all the food it touches.

headline: Female Choreographers Take Center Stage in Ballet Theater’s Fall Season
abstract: The company will give world premieres of ballets by Twyla Tharp and Gemma Bond, and the New York premiere of a Jessica Lang work.

headline: The Supreme Court Is Not Buying the Census Excuses
abstract: It noted a “disconnect” between the Trump administration’s stated reason for including a citizenship question on the census form and the actual rationale for doing so.

headline: Review: A Familiar Set of Laborers Join the Cast of ‘Working’
abstract: This revival of the 1977 musical about the monotony of earning a living custom-tailors the original for City Center’s 75th anniversary.
lead_paragraph: The most engaging workers in the concert revival of “Working,” which opened on Wednesday night at New York City Center, have only recently been added to this 1977 musical’s cast of characters. But they pulse with a vitality and human detail that makes you think, “Tell me more.”

headline: ‘Ophelia’ Review: Out of the Shadows (and Into the Weeds)
abstract: In this revisionist take, Shakespeare’s tragic heroine takes matters, and fate, into her own hands.
lead_paragraph: Soon after “Ophelia” opens, the title character is floating face up in a river. The image evokes John Everett Millais’s 1850s painting that shows a supine Ophelia soon after she has drowned. Her pale palms are turned up, flowers spilling out of one hand. Her eyes are open, her lips prettily parted, as if she had received the gentlest of surprises. It’s quite a vision of Eros and Thanatos in one beautiful necrophiliac package.

headline: Along With Success, the Mets Have Had Their Share of Weirdness
abstract: The unpleasant — and sometimes downright odd — memories coexist with the few joyous ones.

headline: Why the Supreme Court’s Rulings Have Profound Implications for American Politics
keywords: ['Redistricting and Reapportionment', 'Census', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Constitution (US)', 'Citizenship and Naturalization']
abstract: The justices handed Republicans a key victory by refusing to halt even the most extreme gerrymandered maps. But Democrats may have a win on blocking the citizenship question from the census.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The rulings by the Supreme Court on Thursday in bitterly contested battles over partisan gerrymandering and the addition of a citizenship question to the 2020 census grappled with issues fundamental to the nation’s democracy: How power is allocated, and ultimately, how much of a voice the American people have in selecting their leaders.

headline: The Guggenheim’s Collection, as Seen by Six Art Stars
abstract: Everyone’s a curator these days. But when seasoned artists are asked to organize an exhibition from a museum’s collection it can be a great thing.
lead_paragraph: Good things tend to happen when a museum invites an artist to sift through its holdings and curate an exhibition from other people’s works. Artists look at a collection more freely and greedily than most of us, from odd angles. They often ferret out neglected or eccentric treasures, highlighting what museums have but aren’t using; they can also reveal a collection’s weaknesses, its biases and blind spots. And in using the creations of others to make new connections, artists also show new sides of themselves.

headline: How to Host a Relaxed, Italian-Style Late Lunch
keywords: ['Cooking and Cookbooks', 'Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Italian Food (Cuisine)']
abstract: The chef Amber Guinness, who runs the Arniano Painting School from her family’s country house in Tuscany, shares her tips for easygoing entertaining.
lead_paragraph: Set on a remote, grassy hilltop in Tuscany, with a view over the rolling vineyards of Montalcino, the 18th-century brick-and-stone Arniano farmhouse, a former nunnery, has twice been revived by the Guinness family. Jasper and Camilla Guinness, a landscape architect and an interior designer, respectively, both originally from London, purchased the property in 1989, when it was a long-neglected, tumbledown relic, and, over the following years, industriously transformed it into a functional and lively family home where they raised their two daughters — and received a seemingly endless stream of visitors. The couple replanted the long barren scrubland that surrounded the property with olive groves, cypress, fruit trees and lavender; they installed running water and electricity; and they decorated the interiors in a freewheeling mix of British and Tuscan styles, sourcing rustic Italian furniture from nearby junkyards and enlisting local artisans to fabricate antique-style iron bed frames for the five bedrooms. The Guinnesses’ aim was to create a sense of “real comfort, not in the luxury way but in the convivial sense,” Camilla explained on a recent rainy afternoon, seated by the living room fireplace before a Sunday lunch hosted by her daughter Amber.

headline: Politicians Can Pick Their Voters, Thanks to the Supreme Court
keywords: ['Redistricting and Reapportionment', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Elections, House of Representatives']
abstract: The justices said partisan gerrymandering, no matter how flagrant, is beyond the reach of the courts, imperiling the fairness of future elections.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court on Thursday refused to serve as an arbiter for what counts as extreme partisan gerrymandering, opening the door for politicians of both parties essentially to pick their voters, disfavoring parties that are not in power. The decision is anathema to America’s democratic ideals.

headline: Afghan War Casualty Report: June 21-27
keywords: ['Civilian Casualties', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: At least 67 pro-government forces and 12 civilians were killed in Afghanistan during the past week.
lead_paragraph: At least 67 pro-government forces and 12 civilians were killed in Afghanistan during the past week. Casualties among pro-government forces increased compared to last week, as the Taliban intensified their attacks in some parts of the country. The deadliest attack took place in Herat Province, where the Taliban attacked security outposts in the center of Gulran District. Helicopters were sent to medevac casualties, but they were not able to land. Six soldiers and three police officers were killed; three soldiers and two police officers, including the district police chief, were wounded. One soldier and two police officers were taken prisoner by the Taliban. Separately, two American soldiers were killed during a military operation, bringing to nine the number of U.S. military fatalities in the country this year. The soldiers were killed by small-arms fire in southern Uruzgan Province, American defense officials said. They were engaged in a fierce firefight with Taliban militants, with combatants only yards apart at one point, one of the defense officials said.

headline: The Prom Where the City Councilman Dances the Jennifer Grey Part from ‘Dirty Dancing.’ And He’s Not Bad.
abstract: Sneaking a peek at an annual dance in Brooklyn, when a local politician wore a ball gown. He looked fabulous.
lead_paragraph: At a prom earlier this month, Carlos Menchaca, a city councilman from Brooklyn, wore a shiny ball gown to dance the Jennifer Grey role from the climax of “Dirty Dancing.” The prom was an annual fund-raising event for a community school called Cora Dance in Red Hook, Brooklyn, and Shannon Hummel, who runs the school and a dance company of the same name, took the Patrick Swayze role. The dance was Mr. Menchaca’s idea.

headline: 13 Artists Reflect on the Stonewall Riots
keywords: ['Art', 'Stonewall Riots (1969)', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Discrimination', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots']
abstract: 50 years ago, the Stonewall Inn became the center of the gay rights movement after a series of riots broke out. Its influence on these artists still reverberates.
lead_paragraph: The Stonewall Inn, a mob-owned gay bar in New York’s West Village, was an easy target for surprise raids in the late 1960s. Busts were common, riots were not, so when the police began making arrests in the early hours of June 28, 1969, no one expected resistance. But that night, the crowd erupted. People hurled insults, then coins, beer cans and bricks. Reinforcements rushed to the scene as Stonewall supporters poured out of neighboring dives to join the melee. Half destroyed, Stonewall reopened the following night. The rioters returned, singing protest songs, and so did the police, armed with tear gas. The clashes, which continued on Christopher Street for days, were barely covered in the news, but they altered the course of history.

headline: 12 New Books We Recommend This Week
abstract: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: From Sarajevo to New York to Damascus to San Francisco, cities are prominent among this week’s recommended titles: their architecture, their landmarks, their roiling energy and occasional descents into chaos or lawlessness. The real estate journalist Julie Satow delivers a portrait of New York’s iconic Plaza Hotel, once owned by Donald Trump and forever ruled by the fictional Eloise. In twin memoirs, the novelist Aleksandar Hemon (now a Chicagoan) looks back on his childhood in 1970s Sarajevo, before that city was irrevocably altered by war. In “The White Devil’s Daughters,” Julia Flynn Siler offers a history of San Francisco’s Chinatown and the heroic struggle to banish sexual slavery there. And in “Assad or We Burn the Country,” the foreign correspondent Sam Dagher writes about his time in Damascus and the damage the Assad regime has unleashed on Syria.

headline: The Gerrymandering Decision Drags the Supreme Court Further Into the Mud
keywords: ['Redistricting and Reapportionment', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'United States Politics and Government', 'State Legislatures']
abstract: Ignoring the racial redistricting problem won’t make it go away.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court decision on Thursday in Rucho v. Common Cause purports to take federal courts out of the business of policing  partisan gerrymanders and leave the issue for states to handle. But the decision will instead push federal courts further into the political thicket, and, in states with substantial minority voter populations, force courts to make logically impossible determinations about whether racial reasons or partisan motives predominate when a party gerrymanders for political advantage. It didn’t have to be this way.

The fatigue was not surprising. The victory was the end of a road to recovery that had begun over a year before, when Edelman sustained a serious knee injury. That road — and Edelman’s rise to stardom — is the subject of this documentary, which features interviews with Edelman’s fellow Patriot Tom Brady, Edelman’s father, and figures like Mark Wahlberg and Snoop Dogg.
